IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Frailty is frequently observed in HIV patients on long term antiretroviral therapy (ART), and both osteoporosis and sarcopenia are now recognized as co-morbidities among older people with HIV. This project will determine whether inhibiting a key pathway in muscle and bone, the aryl hydrocarbon receptor signaling pathway, can improve muscle and bone function with aging in older people living with HIV.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This work identifies molecular signatures explaining why symptoms are more pronounced on one side of the body in Parkinson’s patients. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: NARRATIVE Prostate cancer survivorship is common and increasing, and may have substantial mental health impacts in patients and their intimate partners that are understudied and preventable. This project will provide the first long-term assessment of mental health outcomes in prostate cancer survivors and their partners by integrating highly complete data from primary care, specialty outpatient, and inpatient settings for a large population- based cohort. The results will identify the long-term mental health sequelae in prostate cancer survivors, their partners, and high-risk subgroups, and guide early interventions to improve their long-term health.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE While AIDS-associated cancers are a major cause of death around the globe, those in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs), particularly in sub-Saharan Africa, are much more likely to die from cancer due to shortages of trained cancer researchers, oncologists, and support staff and a lack of healthcare infrastructure and expertise for diagnosing and treating cancers. The AIDS Malignancies Training and Research International Program (AMTRIP) seeks to address these challenges by training a cadre of Zambian basic biomedical researchers and practitioners from the Cancer Diseases Hospital (the main LMIC institution) and partnering organizations in the skills necessary to further the country's research agenda in cancer biology and genomics, which will translate to better clinical care for cancer patients. Upon completion of master's and doctoral training, program fellows will be provided employment in Zambian medical institutions in order to begin addressing these challenges in-country.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glioblastoma (GBM) is the most common and deadly malignant brain tumor in adults and thus far has been resistant to immunotherapeutic strategies due to its immunosuppressive tumor microenvironment. The gut and tumor microbiome are known immune modulators and gut microbial composition as been demonstrated to significantly impact patient responses to immunotherapy in multiple solid malignances. This project will examine the impact of the microbiome (gut and tumor) on the immune composition of the GBM microenvironment and patient outcome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project narrative Transcription is dysregulated in every human disease as either a cause or an effect and as such represents a potentially powerful intervention point for therapeutics; a significant impediment to progress are the many questions regarding the complex network of protein-protein interactions that regulates this process. In this research plan we implement a combination of chemical biology tools and approaches to define key binding interactions and conformational changes that produce function in vitro and in cells. In doing so, we will discover new opportunities for drug discovery, with a particular focus on transcriptional pathways integral to metabolic disease and cancer.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE More than 40% of children under 5 years in low- and middle-income countries are at risk of not reaching their developmental potential. An important strategy is to promote the capabilities of caregivers and communities to provide nurturing, supportive care to children at risk. In this study, we will evaluate the use of an individualized intervention to caregivers by community health workers—the international Guide for Monitoring Child Development— to promote developmental outcomes. We will also evaluate the barriers, facilitators, and cost-effectiveness of the intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Conventional fluorescence imaging strategies lack the multiplexing capabilities and spatiotemporal resolution required to visualize and track distinct intracellular components simultaneously at the single-molecule level in live cells. This proposal is aimed at overcoming these stringent limitations with the development of synthetic photoactivatable fluorophores specifically designed to allow the parallel monitoring of multiple targets in the interior of live cells with statistical confidence, spatial resolution at the nanometer level and temporal response in the millisecond domain. The resulting unprecedented imaging schemes can contribute to the elucidation of the fundamental factors governing cellular processes at the molecular level and, hence, can have transformative implications in biomedical research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vaccine Hesitancy is complex, influenced by factors at the individual, community, provider, health care system, and societal levels. Despite being a key “super-spreader” population transmitting SARS-Co-V2, the causative agent of COVID-19 (COVID), acceptance of COVID vaccination is lowest among African American and young adult populations. A digital health intervention has the potential to increase the reach and uptake of COVID vaccination among African American young adults which is central to ending the pandemic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The incidence of obesity and type 2 diabetes continues to rise in the United States. Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease is a significant co-morbidity in the pathogenesis of type 2 diabetes. We believe that methylglyoxal restores metabolic and transcriptional homeostasis in the pathogenesis of these disease states and this project is designed to test this hypothesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Treatments that are currently available for antibody-mediated autoimmune diseases such as membranous nephropathy are generally immunosuppressive, are associated with adverse events and/or have limited efficacy. To address this issue, in this application we propose to develop a novel treatment that selectively removes the autoreactive antibodies which are involved in the disease process, without affecting the levels of other antibodies that are important for protection against infectious agents such as bacteria and viruses. This approach has the potential to be a game-changer for the clinical management of membranous nephropathy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The homeless population is aging, with an increasing proportion of individuals over age 50 who experience accelerated aging, high rates of mortality, and a high risk of not having their wishes honored at the end of life. The goal of this proposal is to test the effectiveness of adapted evidence-based advance care planning (ACP) interventions (i.e., an easy-to-read advance directive, an ACP group visit guide, and an ACP one-on-one facilitation guide) for formerly chronically homeless older adults living in Permanent Supportive Housing. The proposed project will compare the effectiveness of facilitated group versus one-on-one ACP visits in a Hybrid (NIH Stage III efficacy/effectiveness), Type 1, two-arm, cluster randomized trial with the goal of reducing health disparities in ACP among formerly chronically homeless older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative A diverse cross-disciplinary workforce highly trained in biomedical sciences is critical for addressing global health concerns. Training of students from underrepresented (UR) ethnic/racial minority and economically disadvantaged groups that matriculate into PhD or MD/PhD programs will help create a diverse biomedical sciences workforce for the Nation. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Identifying early markers of mild cognitive impairment (MCI) and Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) is a national priority. This study aims to develop sensitive, practical, and ecologically acceptable life- space mobility digital indicators that could be used as clinically relevant markers of subsequent cognitive decline among community-dwelling older adults and to examine the influence of social health in the relationship between life-space mobility and cognitive function. The findings from this study will help us design community-based programs to support early detection of cognitive decline and provide highly effective interventions to modify the trajectory of cognitive decline as early as possible.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The study will fill a scientific gap in understanding of non-Hispanic Blacks demand for and access to innovations in AD/ADRD therapeutics and subsequent health and economic outcomes by (1) applying innovative mixed methods in data collection and analysis of demand; (2) utilizing dynamic microsimulation to quantify the health, quality-of-life and economic impacts. The study will change how we prepare for a future with novel and repurposed dementia therapeutics that supports equitable access for improved long-term health and economic outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The New Jersey Institute of Technology (NJIT) is an R1 research-active public university with an educational mission of providing students with research training and mentorship to produce the future generation of scientists and engineers. The goal of this training proposal is to develop a 3 year biomedical research immersion program, focusing on engaging students from all racial and ethnic backgrounds, national origins, gender preferences and abilities. The intended outcomes are to establish a didactic multidisciplinary research training program integrated with academics, enhance the diversity of participation in research, increase competitiveness of trainees, and through successful mentorship, encourage students to consider an academic or professional degree in the biomedical field (i.e. PhD, MD/PhD).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Sarcoidosis is a multisystem inflammatory disease that is known to cause disproportionate morbidity to Black patients, and no interventions have been developed or tested to address this known disparity. We will utilize validated patient reported outcome measures to characterize the prevalence of patient reported barriers to care, their association with outcomes, and the impact of race on these associations. We will use community- based research to develop and pilot an intervention to address the most prevalent and harmful barriers to care in Black sarcoidosis patients, in keeping with the NIMHD's research interests of epidemiological research on population intersectionality and community-based intervention adaptation research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE It has been increasingly recognized that the gut microbiome is associated with colorectal neoplasia; however, the carcinogenesis mechanisms are not clear. This is the first large population-based study that utilizes a multi- omics approach to investigate microbiome-host interplays in the etiology of colorectal neoplasia. The findings will improve our understanding of how microbiome-host interactions impact the development of colorectal neoplasia and have translational potential to develop new tools for CRC prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Astrocytes are a glial subtype that associate intimately with neural circuits and are essential for brain function, but we know very little about how they grow, form contacts with neurons, and regulate dynamic changes in morphology. A deep understanding of how astrocytes regulate their elaborate morphologies and associate with neurons will be essential to study their basic functions, and how dysregulated growth can occur in human disease. This proposal will use Drosophila to characterize the fine details of astrocyte subcellular architecture, and identify and characterize novel conserved signaling pathways regulating astrocyte growth, maintenance and function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genetic mutations in the tumor suppressor BRCA2 engender defects in DNA repair to ultimately cause cancer, and many of these variants still harbor unknown effects on BRCA2 function. Understanding how the DNA-binding domains in BRCA2 contribute to DNA repair would advance our knowledge of how mutations in these domains compromise genomic stability and lead to cancer development. These studies will lay the foundation for future endeavors to devise efficacious cancer treatment regimens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Deterioration of speech and language abilities is the main manifestation of primary progressive aphasia (PPA) and a frequent symptom in related neurodegenerative disorders, such as frontotemporal and Alzheimer's dementias. This proposal will use neuroimaging analyses and multilingual cognitive assessments to detect and diagnose speech and language impairment in diverse patient populations. These methods will provide new knowledge regarding the neural basis of speech and language and result in better detection, refined diagnosis and improved treatments for individuals with speech and language symptoms due to PPA and related neurodegenerative disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project concerns the development and application of multiscale simulation methods to study viral replication in collaboration with experimental structural biologists and biochemists. The specific systems to be studied are implicated in the innate immune response, viral capsid properties, infection of HIV, and SARS- CoV-2 transmission. The findings from this work will advance fundamental knowledge in molecular simulation, virology and biophysics and have the potential to aid in the development of new antiviral strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative  Efforts to improve oncology therapeutic outcomes will be greatly aided by the integration of early detection  and  new  precision  therapies,  reflected  by  the  significantly  improved  survival  rate  of  patients  with  metastatic  colorectal cancer (CRC) that is detected at an early stage when resection is especially effective. In light of the  lack  of  a  generalizable  approach  accessing  specific  diagnostic  biomarkers,  this  proposed  study  seeks  to  leverage  the  molecular  signatures  in  the  tumor  microenvironment  to  develop  multiplexed  in  vivo  sensors  for  precision diagnosis of cancer metastasis.  Successful completion of the proposed research program will exhibit  a preclinical framework of disease detection, stratifying and monitoring and will provide rationale for extending  this modular platform to the general context of cancer through tailored targets specificities.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Endometriosis-associated pelvic pain (EAPP), which often originates during adolescence, evolves into chronic pelvic pain in some women, leading to decreased quality of life and altered life trajectory impacting well into adulthood. The proposed research will leverage unique data from two longitudinal cohorts to identify proteins and pathways that confer increased risk of persistent pain in patients with endometriosis despite receiving current standard treatments. Results from this study will advance our understanding of the underlying mechanisms that contribute to pain and inform strategic selection of treatments and interventions in vulnerable patients before pain becomes entrenched.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Although the FDA-approved BRAF and MEK inhibitors have reduced metastatic melanomas in some patients, these imprecisely targeted small molecule therapeutics have a low therapeutic index since they also alter normal cells, causing undesirable, even fatal, side effects. To address this serious drawback, we will develop a potent, tumor-selective MEK inactivator by engineering an anthrax toxin-based protein delivery system. We will employ a unique set of tumor stromal cell-type-specific anthrax toxin receptor-expressing mice and toxin targeting to unambiguously determine the role of MEK-ERK signaling in both the tumor and the stroma, thereby validating and identifying specific tumor stromal cell types as targets for future therapeutics development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative As preterm infant survival continues to improve, uncertainty regarding the best treatment for hemodynamically significant patent ductus arteriosus (HSPDA) can have serious public health implications for this vulnerable population. A novel, US Food and Drug Administration approved duct occluder (ADO-II AS) now offers clinicians a minimally invasive option for closing HSPDA, but its effectiveness in improving important patient outcomes, relative to supportive, non-interventional HSPDA management, is unknown. This project is relevant to NIH’s mission to understand the processes of human growth and development by determining via a multicenter randomized trial, whether percutaneous HSPDA closure using ADO-II AS improves cardiopulmonary and neurodevelopmental outcomes as compared to supportive, non-invasive therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cytokine Storm is a complication from COVID-19 infection and is thought to induce acute cardiac injuries resulting in arrythmias, reduced ejection fraction, acute heart failure, and even death. While the prevalence has increased from the rising number of COVID19 cases worldwide, it is remains largely unknown how cytokine storm induces adverse cardiac events, and what long term effects this extreme inflammatory response has on the human myocardium. The goal of this study is to use 3D human cardiac organoids to model both the acute and long-term effects of COVID-19 induced inflammation on the heart.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project narrative Three-dimensional human central nervous system tissues (e.g. organoids) derived from induced pluripotent stem cells are a powerful resource for understanding neurological/neurodegenerative diseases and the efficacy of prospective therapeutics. However, current brain organoid platforms do not have properly organized cells and lack vasculature, which limits their representativeness as a model system. This proposal will utilize engineering principles, including biomaterials synthesis and microfabrication techniques, to develop a brain organoid with organized cortical layers interspersed with capillary-sized blood vessels. This ‘neurovascular organoid’ is expected to be a significant improvement over existing organoid models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research substantially advances our understanding of brain circuits that mediate cocaine relapse by exploring the role of newly characterized cell types. By applying innovative genetic and imaging technologies we will improve understanding of cocaine-induced neuropathology in the cell specific subcircuits regulating relapse and provide new drugable targets to inhibit relapse vulnerability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Glioblastoma (GBM) is incurable cancer with a dismal survival rate. Immunotherapy with genetically engineered antibodies such as bi-specific T cell engagers (BiTEs) has the potential to improve patient survival. This study will focus on understanding factors that influence BiTE efficacy, including tumor uptake, pharmacokinetics, and mechanism of action, and preclinically test and characterize a lead BiTE candidate for its use in treating GBM patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Although standing balance control is typically an automatic, involuntary motor function, increasing attention to balance is common in many older adults and is an important fall risk factor. A major clinical barrier is that this engagement of brain activity in gait and balance is inferred through indirect behavioral methods, limiting early detection and targeted intervention approaches. Our proposal provides a novel scientific framework for directly measuring brain activity during balance tasks to enable mechanistic, personalized, approaches to maintain and improve balance health in aging as well as the many neurological and musculoskeletal diseases affecting balance health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Severe Early Childhood Caries (S-ECC) is an infectious disease that continues to be a significant global public health problem among young, preschool children. The clinical, social and public health impact of S-ECC is underscored by its association with increased risk of new cavities in the primary dentition, a higher risk of cavities in the permanent dentition, hospitalizations and emergency room visits, high treatment costs, lost school days, diminished ability to learn and a profound impact on a child’s quality of life. Results of treatment of S-ECC are poor; approximately 40% of children treated for S-ECC will develop new cavities within 12 months after dental surgery. This proposal will assess the efficacy of topical antibacterial therapy in improving clinical outcomes for S-ECC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this proposal we will characterize the local and systemic anticancer immune activating properties of collagen- retained interleukins -2 and -12, in combination with radiotherapy by leveraging the inclusion of pet dogs with naturally-occurring cancers. With this information, we will develop rationally-designed and optimally scheduled combinatorial strategies that exert potent anticancer effects both locally and distantly (abscopal effect) for combating cancer progression. We will assess the safety, pharmacodynamic, immunobiologic activities, and anticancer effects of these immune-based strategies in relevant mouse models and pet dogs with solid tumors and oral melanoma to guide future translation studies in human patients diagnosed with advanced stage melanoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease (AD), a devastating neurodegenerative disease, is estimated that 13.8 million Americans and 90 million people worldwide will be affected by 2050, without disease-modifying treatments. This project will develop capable and intelligent computer-based network medicine, electronic health record (EHRs), and multimodal single-nucleus genomic analytic tools along with functional validation using AD patient-induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSC) and iPSC-derived cerebral organoid and TREM2R47H knock-in mouse models for identifying TREM2 genotype-informed microglia-targeted therapeutics for AD. The successful completion of this project will identify novel aspects of the underlying immune mechanisms in TREM2R47H mutant AD human brains, leading to potential repurposable drugs and combination therapies to be tested in AD clinical trials directly. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative The development and validation of predictive models is a critical step toward improving strategies for an early diagnosis of sporadic frontotemporal dementia (FTD) and other neurodegenerative diseases and improving strategies for personalized treatment. The goal of this proposal is to develop novel imaging genetic biomarkers that can help clinicians with an early and accurate diagnosis and prognosis of sporadic FTD. This project is highly relevant to the NIA’s mission because it supports the conduct of genetic, imaging, and clinical aging research and fosters the development of a clinical research scientist in aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Research is advancing the field of Otolaryngology–Head and Neck Surgery. Here, we have designed a research training program to train the next generation of physician-scientists in areas aligned with NIDCD missions, to ultimately improve human health by combining scientific discovery with clinical care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Tendon experiences substantial age-related impairments in structure, function, and healing capacity. The mechanisms that initiate these age-related disruptions are unknown and there are currently no therapeutic approaches to retain or restore tendon health through the lifespan. Here, we will define the multi-scale signature of tendon aging and define the efficacy of partial reprogramming to maintain and rescue tendon homeostasis and healing capacity in aged mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Effective therapeutic strategies for cartilage degeneration are urgently needed, and our preliminary data sug- gest differential roles of Piezo1 and Piezo2 channels in chondrocyte death and cartilage remodeling. We will use cutting-edge engineering and physiology approaches to identify the joint injury and exercise effect on un- derlying mechanisms of Piezo1/2-mediated cartilage homeostasis and degeneration. Our successful outcome will be useful in understanding cartilage pathology and in future therapeutic strategies for cartilage disorders, including osteoarthritis.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The zebrafish has proven to be a powerful disease model for various disorders, including metabolic disorders, cancer, and neurodegeneration, as well as a model for development and congenital defects. Organism-based meetings like the zebrafish meeting are essential to disseminate novel organism- specific technologies, to initiate collaborations, and to develop future scientific strategies critical for the field. This proposal seeks support for five future conferences in a successful series initiated in 1994, but in a new hybrid format that combines in-person and virtual attendance and thus allows broader participation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE I propose to develop a novel digital treatment, Mindfulness Meditation-enhanced Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT-MM), that integrates MM and CBT for the treatment of Binge Eating Disorder (BED) to target the two important mechanisms in the development and maintenance of BED: dietary over-restriction and emotion dysregulation. The current K23 proposal involves developing digital CBT-MM for BED and conducting a pilot randomized control trial to evaluate its feasibility, acceptability, and within-group changes from pre-to post treatment on indices of: binge eating remission, binge eating frequency, weight, quality of life, depressive symptoms, emotion dysregulation, dietary over-restriction, and trait mindfulness. This innovative research project has the potential to advance research on mindfulness-based treatment for eating disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Infants with brief resolved unexplained events (BRUE) and oropharyngeal dysphagia are a significant driver of pediatric health care expenditure since the mechanism for their swallow dysfunction is incompletely understood and therefore frequently goes unrecognized and untreated. We hypothesize that infants with BRUE have measurable differences in swallowing physiology to explain their symptoms of cyanotic choking spells, that these differences can be quantified using pharyngeal high resolution impedance-manometry compared to videofluoroscopic swallow study results, that this swallowing dysfunction can be safely corrected with a change of formula viscosity, and that patients receiving thickening will have improved clinical outcomes compared to patients who do not receive thickening. Through this career development award, we will systematically investigate the effects of thickened feedings on swallow function and clinical outcomes in infants with BRUE, perform detailed physiology studies on pharyngeal and esophageal motility as critical mediators of improved outcomes, and complete a decision analysis to identify the subgroup of infants with BRUE that can safely receive empiric thickening of feeds as treatment for their oropharyngeal dysphagia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acquired resistance to targeted therapy poses a major barrier to curing cancer, but the molecular mechanisms that allow cancer cells to adapt to therapy remain poorly understood. I propose to elucidate mechanisms of resistance to multiple therapies in use or in trial to treat non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) by identifying novel regulators of the cell cycle and lung cancer cell identity. This work will provide novel insight into the principles that govern cancer cell plasticity and may help identify ways to improve the efficacy of targeted therapies in NSCLC and other cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Health Relevance In this work we propose to develop a novel smart graft engineering platform, which can sensitively measure local tissue signaling would enable practical monitoring and diagnosis of acute rejection episodes, can transform care of transplant patients since compliance issues in medication would be dramatically reduced, and will likely increase the overall efficacy and therefore reduce graft rejections. In the longer term, the preservation methods developed here could also be enabling for tolerance induction in VCA transplants, and therefore allow for their wide-spread use which is not possible currently.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE We propose to develop a novel multiscale machine-learning microscopy platform for automated, large-scale analyses of single cells. By integrating new computational optics with deep learning, this new system will enable high resolution (0.4 μm) and large field-of-view (10 mm2) volumetric imaging and automatically identify hidden phenotypes from millions of single cells. We will apply the developed technology to map out the live cell phenotypes in iPSC(induced Pluripotent Stem Cell)-derived airway epithelium.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a debilitating autoimmune disease affecting over one million Americans, and while first-line therapy with methotrexate (MTX) works for many, in most patients, it is not enough. Our recent studies indicate that the gut microbiome plays important roles in RA treatment and that MTX acts on the microbiota to reduce inflammation. Understanding how MTX acts on the microbes to affect key metabolites may enable the development of new microbially targeted therapies to improve treatment response to MTX.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative The cervical epithelium serves as the first line of defense during pregnancy to prevent ascending infections, a risk factor for preterm birth. Using single cell approaches, diverse subtypes of epithelial cells were identified in pregnancy that were unique in gene expression compared to nonpregnant. In the current study, the lineage and regulation of specialized secretory epithelia that are dominant in pregnancy will be identified and the impact on ascending infection risk determined when the secretory cells are perturbed. Insights from this work will identify biomarkers that predict risk of preterm birth and identify therapeutic clinical targets for prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The vast majority of diseases that severely afflict the public health are consequence of derangements in the molecular mechanisms by which our cells respond to external stimuli. Here we propose studies to identify a new molecular mechanism that regulates signaling via G protein coupled receptors (GPCRs), which are prominent pharmacological targets for a wide range of diseases. The most direct, but not exclusive, implications of these studies are in the area of epilepsy and pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The protein kinase PKA protects against dementia in Alzheimer’s disease and during aging, and drugs that activate PKA are in clinical development for the treatment of dementia. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: Relevance Lynch syndrome (LS) is a hereditary disease which predisposes patients to an increased risk of developing colorectal, endometrial, ovarian and other cancers. Diagnosis of LS is aided by identification of a deleterious, germline mutation in one of four DNA mismatch repair (MMR) genes, however, nearly one-fourth of all suspected patients carry germline missense variants in the MMR genes which alter only a single amino acid in these rather large proteins. This proposal seeks to utilize a human stem cell culture model system for testing whether certain missense variants affect MMR cellular functions; an important step in determining whether the variant truly contributes to disease pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Little is known regarding why children with tracheostomy experience recurrent respiratory infections despite receiving clinically appropriate antibiotic therapy. This proposal seeks to derive a novel prognostic model that incorporates clinical factors and mechanistically-based laboratory measures of pathogen antibiotic resistance and host immune response to identify children at greatest risk for recurrent tracheostomy-associated respiratory infections (TARIs). The findings of this work under a career development award will provide the basis for future risk-stratified interventional trials employing targeted therapies to reduce the frequency of TARI hospitalization among children with tracheostomy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Narrative At the cellular level, mesenchymal stem cells experience physical force (“exercise”) transferred through the actin cytoskeleton and into the nucleus, activating signaling and changing nuclear structure. Recently it has become apparent that nuclear structure itself has a profound effect on gene expression, and alterations in the nucleoskeleton can prevent stem cells from becoming osteoblasts. We propose to find out how different types of force, through their respective induced cytoskeletons, affect nuclear structure and the expression of osteogenic genes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Tourniquet-induced traumatic injuries limit its clinical use for effectively stopping life-threatening bleeding in prehospital settings and creating bloodless operating fields in surgeries. This proposal will explore the potential mechanisms about tourniquet-induced traumatic injuries and test whether a new anti-inflammatory drug promotes long-term recovery of the neuromuscular junction from traumatic injuries. The significance of this project is to resolve the limitations of tourniquet use in the clinic and to provide potential therapeutic targets and strategies for improving outcomes and quality of life in post-traumatic patients.

PHR: Project Narrative The 31 known inborn errors of IFN-γ-mediated immunity underlying MSMD are found in about half of the 900 international patients with MSMD enrolled in the laboratory. We will search for novel MSMD-candidate genotypes in the remaining patients by WES or WGS, testing hypotheses of genetic homogeneity or heterogeneity. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Seasonal changes in day length cause physiological and psychiatric disturbances that relapse every year. There is a large gender disparity in seasonal disorders, with women at least twice as likely as men to be adversely affected. Understanding the basis of seasonal disease and why women are affected so disproportionately is an area of critical unmet need. These studies will generate novel insights into how day length alters the function of neural circuits in both sexes, which will comprise the basic foundations for identifying novel ways to combat seasonal pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Molecular-scale interactions govern cell biology, and super-resolution microscopy has emerged as a powerful tool for attaining nanoscopic maps of the inside of the cell. This work will develop novel super-resolution microscopy tools to characterize the biochemical reactions occurring in bacterial cells in real time. By providing synergistic information—localization maps, interaction maps, and mobility maps—we will investigate broad themes in bacterial cell biology to develop new paradigms for subcellular organization in these small cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research will contribute fundamental knowledge regarding how the primate brain represents and processes the three-dimensional (3D) world during naturalistic, unrestrained behaviors. In the short term, it will provide a novel research platform for investigating how primates encode/update ecologically relevant 3D sensory information to thrive in an ever-changing world. In the long term, it will provide fundamental knowledge for treating neurological disorders, traumatic brain injury, and cognitive dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Pathogenic bacteria have a devastating effect on public health, and new therapies are desperately needed to combat growing antibiotic resistance. Pathogenesis-associated bacterial secretion systems are attractive drug targets, but we lack detailed understanding of their structures and mechanisms. In the proposed project, we will apply state-of-the-art imaging techniques to provide this missing information, generating functional insights into these complex nanomachines and potential drug targets for the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study is directed at increasing the fundamental understanding of the causes and prevention strategies of chronic kidney disease of unknown origin (CKDu) in Latin American women. The of and effect at study's inclusion examining occupational and non-occupational exposures to particulate matter and its constituents (i.e., silica heavy metals), mechanisms of injury, markers of cellular stress and inflammation, and renal biomarkers of among females in Guatemala and Nicaragua will factors that put individuals risk for the development of CKDu. Findings will advance our ability to identify lead to interventions designed to reduce morbidity and mortality from CKDu in vulnerable populations around the world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research proposal seeks to define how vaccination alters the course of gammaherpesvirus infection in immunocompetent mice, using the murine gammaherpesvirus 68 model system. While there is clear evidence that the immune system can limit gammaherpesvirus-induced infection, the stage at which infection is disrupted and the cell type(s) involved in protection remain poorly defined. By analyzing viral infection and immune parameters associated with control of gammaherpesvirus infection in the context of vaccination, these studies seek to address this gap in knowledge of gammaherpesvirus infection and disease in susceptible populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Anti-estrogen therapy is key to the prevention and treatment of estrogen receptor (ER, ESR1) positive breast cancer, but therapy resistance occurs in up to a half of cases resulting in incurable advanced disease. We recently reported that ESR1 fusions are recurrent in endocrine resistant advanced breast cancer, and that these fusions show constitutive activity due to the lack of the ER hormone binding domain. In this proposal our cross-disciplinary team of breast cancer biologists, clinicians, and structural biologists will investigate the biology and clinical relevance of ESR1 fusions to develop information required for targeting this key mechanism of endocrine resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neurodegenerative diseases such as ALS/FTD represent an outsized burden to a progressively aging world population, and no cure exists to alleviate symptoms or stop the progression of these diseases. The proposed research is expected to elucidate at the mechanistic level the novel molecular pathways underlying cellular pathology in human ALS/FTD neurons. We anticipate that this research will contribute to the identification of novel targets in these pathways for the development of innovative therapeutic strategies for ALS/FTD and potentially other neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Splicing factor SF3B1 gene is frequently mutated in chronic lymphocytic leukemia and these mutations significantly co-occur with a deletion of 11q (minimal deleted region contains ATM) as well as ATM mutations (loss-of-function). Our murine model confirmed that co-expression of heterozygous mutant Sf3b1 and deletion of Atm in B cells results in CLL onset. We thus propose to fully understand the molecular mechanisms of how RNA splicing dysregulation and impaired DNA damage signaling synergistically impact pathogenesis of CLL.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: NARRATIVE Notch signaling regulates pancreatic tumor epithelium. Its role in the tumor microenvironment is less clear. We will dissect compartment specific Notch signaling (Aim 1); study Notch-driven myeloid polarization of T cells (Aim 2), and test the role of Notch inhibition of T cell function and activity (Aim 3) in the pancreatic tumor microenvironment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: We propose to develop an implanted device that can measure health status and, in a future study, test this system in individuals with spinal cord injury (SCI) to determine if early prediction of disease states can increase life expectancy. The proposed implanted device, called the Lifeline, measures parameters such as body temperature, photoplethysmogram, electrocardiogram, sound, and acceleration. Taken together, these measures may be able to predict the early onset of autonomic dysreflexia (specific to SCI), pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and pulmonary embolism, which are among the top causes of death in SCI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Thrombocytopenia is a major clinical problem encountered in multiple conditions, and severe thrombocytopenia (platelet counts <50 x 109/L) can lead to life threatening bleeding. We have discovered a novel regulator of megakaryocyte maturation and platelet production during inflammation: platelet-derived microvesicles in the bone marrow. Targeting 1) the generation of microvesicles from platelets and/or 2) the interactions between microvesicles and megakaryocytes may allow development of novel ways modify platelet production in patients with thrombocytopenia or thrombocytosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: The first goal of this research is to develop systematic methods for generating affinity molecules (antibodies) that specifically target different types of toxic and highly complex protein particles (aggregates) linked to Parkinson’s disease and other neurodegenerative diseases. The second goal is to use the novel antibodies generated in this work to understand key structural differences between unique types of toxic protein aggregates that are linked to and potentially cause different neurodegenerative diseases. These findings are expected to improve the diagnosis, evaluation and potentially the treatment of diverse neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative As the burden of Alzheimer’s disease in the United States and worldwide is high, there is a critical need to develop novel PET ligands to image illness-related biological processes in the brain. This work will develop key imaging tools designed to advance the scientific understanding of subtype-specific NMDA receptors in the ionotropic glutamate system and facilitate the discovery of neurotherapeutics for Alzheimer’s disease patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Biobehavioral Human-Machine Co-Adaptation of the Artificial Pancreas Large-scale artificial pancreas studies, including a multi-center pivotal trial recently completed by our team, have established the current capabilities of closed-loop control (CLC) and identified its deficiencies, e.g. inferior control during the day due to slow insulin response to fast biobehavioral perturbations. We therefore propose to develop and test a next-generation CLC system – Adaptive Biobehavioral Control (ABC) based on the novel concept of human-machine co-adaptation – which will use a stochastic-process approximation of the day-to-day variation in human physiology and behavior to individualize and optimize CLC. The ABC concept recognizes both the necessity for the control algorithm to adapt to changes in human physiology and the necessity for the person to adapt to CLC action; thus, ABC is expected to be superior to current state-of-the art CLC systems in terms of glycemic control outcomes, particularly during the day, and technology acceptance by the user.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Viral infections in the prenatal brain lead to severe injury and neurodevelopmental disorders, including cerebral palsy, global developmental delay, epilepsy, and other life-shortening disabilities. Currently, there are no preventive strategies and only few targeted therapies are available for prenatal viral infections. This work will investigate how two neuroviral candidate genes, mTOR and HEXB, regualte prenatal viral autophagy and neuronal survival by integrating novel systems modeling, lab studies, and clinical analyses; its long-term goal is to identify precision therapies for mitigating viral and other risks to the developing prenatal brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative Our goal is to determine the effect gestational age at delivery has on lactation outcomes using state of the science biologic measures including mother's own milk (MOM) volume, secretory activation, and biomarkers (sodium, citrate, lactose, protein) in pump-dependent mothers of preterm and critically ill infants. Results of this prospective cohort study targeting the biology and physiology of insufficient MOM among NICU mothers are expected to move science towards filling the gap in understanding these mechanisms with gestational age as a nonmodifiable factor that may influence MOM volume and secretory activation in NICU mothers to: 1) identify and prioritize evidence based lactation care to increase lactation success in mothers of all gestational aged infants, and 2) gain new knowledge on biomarkers that may hold promise as objective outcome measures and point-of-care testing to identify and proactively manage mothers at risk for delayed and/or impaired secretory activation and compromised lactation, thus improving infant health outcomes and health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This RFA seeks to develop novel cell and gene therapy therapies to treat individuals suffering from T1D. Our underlying hypothesis is that by engineering and re-directing suppressive and/or regulatory T cells to the transplanted islet we block acute allograft rejection resulting in long term tolerance and islet function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Current treatment options for mucormycosis are inadequate, and fail in 50% or more of infected patients. The fungus uses CotH proteins to cause disease, and antibodies targeting CotH are curative in animal models especially when combined with antifungal drugs currently used to treat the disease. We propose to further the manufacturing of a suitable form of an antibody targeting CotH to enable future clinical testing.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative This project, "Research Training for Substance Use Mediated HIV Epidemic in Kazakhstan," will build capacity to address evidence-based interventions related to an IDU- mediated HIV epidemic in Kazakhstan through research training at Asfendiyarov Kazakh National Medical University (KNMU) in Almaty, thereby addressing the NIH HIV research priority of reducing the incidence of HIV. The selected scientific area for which HIV research training is proposed is strengthening in-country expertise in identifying processes to integrate people who inject drugs into HIV care in the era of COVID. The public health relevance of the expected increased HIV research capacity is that all training is designed to bolster research capacity focused on the intersection of substance use disorder and the HIV treatment cascade ultimately reducing both HIV incidence and HIV morbidity and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Our ability to predictably harness the microbiota for beneficial health outcomes requires a fundamental understanding of the physiology of these bacteria, yet most human gut bacteria have never been studied using molecular genetic tools. In this proposal, we aim to address this major gap in our functional understanding of gene functions in human gut bacteria through systematic efforts to optimize transformation efficiency, construct barcoded transposon-insertion libraries, and map gene-phenotype relationships in vitro and in vivo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: This project addresses the fundamental mission of NIDCD (National Institute for Deafness and Communication Disorders) to provide novel means of assisting communication for people with severe motor impairments caused by congenital and/or acquired disabilities such as stroke, high-level spinal cord injury, neural degeneration, or neuromuscular disease. Leveraging advances in wearable access technology, which has not been explored sufficiently for AAC users, we are developing MyAACTM, the first AAC device that enables versatile access and automatically learns and customizes a keyboard interface to an individual’s residual motor capabilities. MyAACTM represents a unique AAC device that provides alternative communication access by accommodating the residual motor function of individuals with severe motor impairments for improved societal integration and quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The bacterial type II topoisomerases, gyrase and topoisomerase IV, are the targets for fluoroquinolones, which are among the most widely prescribed antibacterial drugs worldwide and are ranked by the World Health Organization among the five classes of “highest priority critically important antimicrobials.” Unfortunately, the use of fluoroquinolones is being undercut by a high incidence of target-mediated resistance. Given the crisis in antibacterial resistance and the fact that gyrase and topoisomerase IV are validated antibacterial targets, our goals are to determine the underlying basis for drug action and resistance against these enzymes in purified systems and bacterial cells and to determine the basis for the actions of novel bacterial topoisomerase inhibitors (NBTIs) and spiropyrimidinetriones (SPTs), new agents that target these enzymes and bypass fluoroquinolone resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: NARRATIVE Cells and tissues experience diverse forms of stress, that lead to protein misfolding and aggregation, negatively impacting survival. How stresses like oxidative damage or xenobiotics cause misfolding, and how they are sensed to allow mobilization of appropriate defense countermeasures including protein chaperones with the capacity to block protein aggregation and the formation of amyloid structures are poorly understood. This research proposal aims to elucidate the mechanisms responsible for ensuring proper protein homeostasis in single-cell (yeast) and animals (fruit fly) as a prelude to enabling therapeutic interventions to promote human health.

PHR: One in three children in the United States will experience an adverse childhood experience (ACE) before adulthood. Pre-natal and early post-natal environments contribute notably to the development of negative psychiatric endophenotypes related to schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, major depression, anxiety disorders, etc. all of which are highly prevalent in the United States. This proposal is aimed at identifying the contextspecific regulatory logic of risk during neurodevelopment, with the translational potential to promote the mitigation of environmental stressors during fetal development and early childhood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study aims to establish the physiological role of a previously unreported soluble Platelet-Derived Growth Factor Receptor-β (sPDGFRβ) that appears to be broadly expressed in healthy tissues. Similar to related soluble growth factor receptors, sPDGFRβ may regulate the bioavailability of a key growth factor that contributes to microvascular stability, with aberrant sPDGFRβ expression associated with vessel dysfunction. The purpose of this study is to advance our understanding of how and where sPDGFRβ may regulate vessel function, with the long-term goal of exploring how sPDGFRβ may be developed as a diagnostic tool and/or a target for bioengineered therapies.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is tightly aligned with the NIH mission by unveiling new molecular and pathogenic mechanisms that account for T cell lymphoma, with a focus on the TET-mediated epigenetic modifications and the RHO GTPase pathway. Our studies will furnish important insights that are immediately relevant to the clinic by elucidating how mutations in TET2 and RHOA cooperate to drive blood cancer. Our discoveries will advance the development of novel therapeutics by targeting abnormal DNA modifications and GTPase activity for the prevention and treatment of blood cancers to benefit millions of patients suffering from leukemia and lymphoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Abnormally increased muscle tone, is a significant dysfunction in stroke, cerebral palsy, spinal cord injury and traumatic brain injury. Electrical nerve block is a promising candidate for producing a reliable, rapid, gradable and reversible motor nerve block. We propose an innovative, non-invasive direct current muscle block, delivered through the skin, that will aid in the rehabilitation of limb movement by reducing spasticity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adults with chronic communication (speech) disabilities are at a high risk for social isolation and resulting poorer health outcomes and quality of life. Family members and others who may be assumed to provide support for these patients to enable them to engage in home, social, and work life may be unable to provide the needed accommodations because of the third-party disability they experience as a result of increased burden of care and loss of emotional connection with their loved one with the communication impairment. This project targets reducing social isolation and improving life participation for adults with communication disabilities and their families by examining the reciprocal relationships among participation in daily communication activities, the novel construct of perceived social support for communication provided by family / key communication partners, and the third party disability impact of communication disorders on family / key communication partners for people with speech disabilities due to Parkinson’s disease, laryngeal dystonia, laryngectomy, and oral-pharyngeal cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Diffusion MRI is a powerful contrast mechanism sensitive to cortical microstructure and structural connectivity in the brain, yet technical and physiological barriers preclude high spatial resolution diffusion MRI of the medial temporal lobe in Alzheimer’s disease. We will develop high-resolution and high-fidelity diffusion MRI acquisition technology tailored to the medial temporal lobe to overcome these barriers and provide noninvasive diagnostic markers sensitive to very early microstructural and connectivity changes in Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE. Astrocytes contribute to neuronal activity, blood-brain-barrier function, inflammatory response, and more, but how astrocytes change during aging and in age-related neurological disorders is not well understood. Here we report a novel astrocyte phenotype in normal aging, that is exacerbated in the APPNL-G-F mouse model of Alzheimer’s Disease (AD), known as “atypical astrocytes” (AtAs) in which astrocytes lose multiple functional proteins but do not appear to be reactive. In this proposal we will determine the molecular characteristics of AtA, their functional consequences, and the role of vascular dysfunction in driving AtA formation during healthy aging and in a mouse model of AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pulmonary disease due to non-tuberculous mycobacteria, including Mycobacterium avium Complex Pulmonary Disease (MAC-PD), is increasing worldwide, and treatment remains challenging because a) some patients will improve without antibiotics, while b) not all patients that receive antibiotics will recover. We will leverage existing clinical data, together with newly collected clinical, immune and drug data, to predict which patients are likely to get better with or without antibiotics by using a combination of computational tools (machine learning (top-down) and mechanistic (bottom-up) models). This work will help us understand how bacteria, host immune response and antibiotics work together to drive infection outcomes; but also provide predictive tools that will improve clinical management and treatment outcomes for MAC-PD patients by determining patient-specific risks for different treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is the main cause of death in older adults in the US and the burden of aging- associated CVD is expected to increase as the percentage of the older population steadily grows. A key characteristic of vascular aging is arterial stiffening, which is a causal factor and independent prognosticator of cardiovascular morbidity and mortality. This project will determine the molecular mechanisms underlying arterial stiffening in aging and, for the first time, examine the efficacy of SGLT2 inhibition in reversing aging- associated arterial stiffening.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative: The proposed research is relevant to public health because narcolepsy, a REM sleep-related disorder, affects 1 in 2000 individuals in the US and there are significant health and financial costs associated with this disease. Understanding the neural mechanisms that underlie narcolepsy, particularly how monoaminergic and limbic systems contribute to excessive sleepiness and abnormal motor control across states, is necessary to identify new targets and approaches to treating narcolepsy, as well as sleep disorders more broadly. Thus, this proposal is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that pertains to fostering fundamental basic science discoveries, using innovative approaches, with the goal of ultimately improving health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Both the psychotic-like symptoms and the motivational deficits characteristic of schizophrenia, including its risk states, may be related to impairments in the processing of salience or importance. Psychotic-like symptoms may result from aberrant salience, which is giving undue importance to neutral events or stimuli, whereas motivational deficits may result from blunted adaptive salience, which is not giving enough importance to what may be good or pleasurable. In this proposal we will study, over time, young people at risk for schizophrenia, in whom both types of symptoms are evolving, to determine the extent to which forms of “salience processing” may be related to their symptoms and function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Chromatin context is a critical determinant of all DNA transactions that is frequently perturbed in cancer cells. Genome-scale approaches to study chromatin are largely based on the detection of a single protein or molecular feature, resulting in one-dimensional data sets that fail to uncover the functional diversity of the target protein. We will establish a versatile and broadly applicable technique for the genome-wide mapping of complex chromatin features and will apply this method to advance the epigenomic characterization of pathological RNA:DNA hybrids, a poorly understood hallmark of many cancer genomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The 2024 Environmental Science: Water Gordon Research Conference will feature a program of leading researchers whose work strives to improve water quality and protect public health. The conference sessions will include topics on (i) challenges and opportunities in managing global pollutants, (ii) environmental toxicology and toxins, (iii) environmentally persistent chemicals and materials, and (iv) environmental justice issues related to water. The unique and immersive format of this meeting provides an ideal setting to foster cross fertilization and stimulate new ideas amongst researchers from multiple disciplines and diverse backgrounds, as well as between early-career and established career stages. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Public Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a common chronic neurodegenerative disorder regarded as a highly significant public health issue. Neuroinflammation accompanies AD pathology, but the etiology for this disorder is not yet fully understood and, no treatment is available that can reverse or stop the neurodegenerative process in AD. In this study, we will apply ultra-sensitive genomic technologies for tracking immunogenetic and epigenomic profiles in AD patients and AD model animals that may provide paradigm-shifting findings and identify new types of biological markers and targets for the effective treatments of AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are currently 6.7 million Americans living with dementia and, without significant breakthroughs, this figure will double to 12.7 million by 2050 (Rajan et al., 2021). Dementia interferes with a person’s ability to function by impairing memory, reasoning, judgment, language, initiation, and socialization, leading to many unfortunate outcomes, including social isolation / withdrawal (Semple, et al., 1982; Alexander & Geschwind, 1984; Liu, Gauthier, & Gauthier, 1991, Social Care Institute, 2019). With this in mind, the proposed Phase II study will involve the further development and testing of a multi-faceted software application called “Building Relationships using Artificial Intelligence and Nostalgia” or BRAIN.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Pulmonary hypertension (PH) is a heterogeneous high mortality condition arising as a primary condition as well as a complication of COPD, heart failure, and clots in the lung. In carrying out the research outlined in the following proposal, we plan to develop and apply computational methods based on deep learning to quantify the structural and functional changes that can be seen using CT scans in the lung of patients with PH arising as a comorbidly of COPD. The result of this work will help us develop non-invasive ways of detecting PH in smokers, improve our understanding of the disease, and potentially enable better, targeted therapies.

PHR: Project Narrative Reverse cholesterol transport is a key mechanism preventing atherosclerotic heart disease. This project will train junior investigators on using patient-oriented research to improve heart health.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite significant time and money spent on post-stroke rehabilitation, stroke survivors are left with reduced walking capacity and significant disability. After stroke, individuals must relearn movements that have been disrupted due to damage to the brain, therefore, enhancing motor learning is critical to improving the rehabilitation of walking after stroke. In this project we will examine how individual factors influence motor learning after stroke and use this information to personalize post-stroke rehabilitation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Cancer incidence and mortality are growing worldwide and there is an urgent need for new treatment options for patients with aggressive forms of cancer. Current treatments include the use of cytotoxic agents such as doxorubicin (Dox) to promote tumor regression, which unfortunately after prolonged use can result in severe and sometimes life-threatening side effects. Shasqi has developed a novel drug product, SQ3370, that serves to inhibit tumor growth and protection against tumor rechallenge, while exhibiting enhanced tolerability and reduced systemic side effects in comparison to conventional Dox treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The objective of this program is to implement, evaluate, and disseminate rigorous, nutrition focused, evidence-based nutrition research skills training and mentored research experiences for trainees and health professionals in both conventional and integrative nutritional science. While numerous successful models of evidence-based health care skills training exist, these programs are not sufficient for nutrition trainees who conduct systematic reviews and who apply nutrition in clinical practice. Evidence-based Nutrition & Research Guidance (ENER-G) will lead to robust research and clinical practice skills across the Evidence Lifecycle that supports improvement in the management of diabetes, obesity, and digestive diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Conditions such as osteoporosis, osteoarthritis, osteomyelitis; developmental skeletal abnormalities; and malignancies such as multiple myeloma and breast cancer, negatively affect the skeleton. There is an ongoing need to better understand the causes of these diseases to support the development of more effective and well- tolerated therapies. Comprehensive analyses of the molecular changes that contribute to these conditions may lead to the development of such therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative The goal of this project is to collect continuous glucose monitoring data in a healthy community-based sample to determine whether patterns identified in the rise and fall of glucose levels throughout the day can help predict risk of developing diabetes mellitus. Through linking patterns of dynamic glucose levels with diet and physical activity (among other factors like genetics, bacteria in the gut, and the prevalence of cardiovascular disease), this project may also lead to new discoveries that will tailor and target prevention of diabetes mellitus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  The quest for newer and more effective ways of treating cancer has now led to an extensive focus on the involvement of the immune system and its capacity to recognize and engage tumor cells. In the proposed research we plan to improve the therapeutic efficacy of several known HDAC6 inhibitors (HDAC6i) in order to identify drug-like compounds that are best able to reduce the expression of negative immune check-point molecules. We believe that this HDAC approach will allow for the restoration of immune surveillance mechanisms in cancer cells, especially when the HDAC6i are combined with immunotherapeutic agents such as anti-PD-1 blocking antibodies, thereby leading to improved anti-tumor immune responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Monitoring of tumor progression and/or response to therapy in pathologically indistinguishable (yet biologically and clinically diverse) cohorts of prostate cancer patients remains a substantial unmet need, so here we seek to integrate an adaptive theranostic gene therapy-based approach using highly engineered phage-AAV chimeric vectors to specifically deliver both an imaging and therapeutic agent. Novel tumor targeting vectors will be available for potential evaluation in first-in-human studies. This work addresses an unmet need in prostate cancer and, if successful, it will ultimately lead to a blueprint towards translational applications in an accelerated framework.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: OVERALL – PROJECT NARRATIVE Nearly 1 in 54 children will be diagnosed with Autism Spectrum disorder (ASD), which is associated with life - long challenges. Other common neurodevelopmental disorders (NDDs), including attention-deficit and hyperactivity disorder, intellectual disability, seizure disorders, and traumatic injury to the developing brain, also have major social and economic costs associated. This initiative will establish a center of research excellence in Neurodevelopment and Its Disorders in South Carolina, where the rate of ASD is estimated to be higher, that will ultimately improve the health and well-being of individuals diagnosed with NDDs, including ASD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The evolving needs of the specialty of Anesthesiology include: a strengthening of the scientific foundation to grow new fundamental insights and offer the highest quality of care to the expanding complex patient population requiring anesthesia perioperative care. The purpose of the STAT Training Program is to develop a subset of outstanding investigators trained to conduct precise and impactful research of relevance to anesthesiology and perioperative medicine. This new application will build upon our past success with developing physician scientists from diverse backgrounds, will reveal a strong pipeline of candidates, and will describe expert faculty mentors that will broaden our approach to innovation with Anesthesiology.
PROJECT_TERMS: Anesthesiology;Science;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Specialized Training in Anesthesiology Team Science

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will advance our fundamental understanding of G protein-coupled receptor (GPCR) signaling and unconventional myosin function in cells. Insights gained from research into GPCR signaling can be used to identify new drugs that selectively target GPCRs in diseases such as heart failure, neuropsychiatric disorders, and diabetes. Research into the molecular basis of myosin motility in cells will pave the way to understand the disease mechanisms that stem from deregulated myosin function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Health Relevance After DNA damage, the fate for a cell to die or to survive with a stable or an altered genome, is a critical determinant for tumor development and therapeutic outcomes. This study aims to investigate the mechanisms by which Ku70 methylation regulates DNA repair and cell fate through apoptosis. It will contribute to new in- depth understanding of the cause and therapeutic outcomes of cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Most cancers spread first to lymph nodes and later to distant tissues. We recently discovered that cancer cells in lymph nodes cause immune cells there to help the cancer spread throughout the body. In this project, we will use new technologies to identify the genes and molecules responsible for this process and investigate new therapies to overcome it.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cardiovascular disease remains the number one cause of death globally, and > 70% of cases can be attributed to cardiometabolic risk factors. The new research proposed in this program will evaluate cardiometabolic risk factors among diverse patient populations by leveraging new technological advances in precision medicine. Dr, Mora is a nationally recognized leader in patient-oriented cardiovascular prevention research, education, and mentoring. Her research and mentoring opportunities are enabled by the availability and recruitment of outstanding junior investigators, the strong multidisciplinary backgrounds of her collaborations, and the depth and breadth of resources at the Brigham and Women's Hospital, Harvard Medical School, the Harvard T,H, Chan School of Public Health, and multiple nearby Boston teaching hospitals and academic institutions, providing rich mentoring opportunities to train the next-generation of cardiovascular researchers.

PHR: Program Director/Principal Investigator (Last, First, Middle): Fishe, Jennifer, N Project Narrative This pilot cluster randomized controlled trial of EMS-administered CS for pediatric asthma patients will help fill a knowledge gap in the EMS treatment of this common pediatric emergency condition. This study innovatively combines clinical, economic, and geospatial analysis to see how EMS-administered CS affects patient outcomes, healthcare costs, and EMS operations. That novel combination of analyses lays the foundation for developing adaptable pediatric asthma guidelines for implementation by diverse EMS agencies nationwide as part of a future multicenter trial. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES

PHR: Project Narrative: Plasma membrane-anchored KRAS small GTPase selectively interacts with distinct phosphatidylserine (PS) species with mixed-chain acyl chains in the regulation of cell proliferation of normal or tumor cells. We propose to investigate how remodeling PS acyl chain profile, by lysophosphatidylcholine acyltransferase 1 (LPCAT1) and LPCAT4, modulates KRAS nanoclustering and function. Because of the key roles of KRAS in human cancer, our new findings allow us to better appreciate how lipid acyl chain profile contributes to cancer biology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: This proposal represents an interdisciplinary and collaborative effort between dental and medical experts, towards improving outcomes for PLWH by proposing a prospective study for the identification of oral-systemic non-AIDS- associated comorbid diseases (NCDs) in a large population of HIV individuals, who have been on ART for at least one year. Results from our study will lead to a better understanding of key oral health manifestations among PLWH and their impact on the development and severity of NCDs. In addition, better understanding the interplay of oral and systemic inflammation in PLWH on long-term ART has the potential to improve oral and systemic outcomes and inform clinicians on novel interdisciplinary approaches (e.g. oral- systemic-connection) of reducing inflammation among PLWH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE SRD5A2 is a critical enzyme for prostatic development and growth, and the SRD5A2 inhibitor, finasteride, is commonly used to treat benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). SRD5A2 is absent in 30% of normal adult men, which explains the resistance of a subset of patients to finasteride and other BPH therapies. This project assesses utilization of SR5A2 as a marker to identify patients who may be resistant to 5-alpha reductase inhibitor therapy for management of BPH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The opioid crisis has escalated dramatically among women, but women face many unique challenges in obtaining treatment for opioid use disorder (OUD), highlighting the importance of women-centered strategies for engagement in care. To address these gendered needs and barriers to care, we propose a novel women- centered recovery navigation system. The proposed research will 1) identify key barriers to engagement in care for women with OUD, as well as potential solutions; 2) develop and evaluate a pilot women-centered recovery navigator program; and 3) develop and evaluate a web-based recovery platform to engage women with OUD in care.
