IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The relationship between migration and mental health is complex given the heterogeneous and context specific nature of migration and, generally speaking, forcibly displaced populations are at increased risk for developing mental health disorders. Yet, despite the recent Venezuelan forced displacement being the greatest diaspora in the recorded history of Latin America, little is known about the mental health effects and potential treatment targets for this at risk, stigmatized, and underserved population. In order to address a significant lack of mental health care seeking and retention in this population, the current multi-disciplinary study proposes a comprehensive examination of factors that serve as facilitators and barriers to mental health treatment seeking and treatment retention in forcibly displaced populations, which will then be leveraged to adapt and pilot an evidence-based treatment approach to increase retention of Venezuelan migrants in care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Although we have a good idea of the risk factors for type II diabetes, the ultimate causes are not known at the molecular-level. This application focuses on achieving a molecular-level understanding of how the human-IAPP (islet amyloid polypeptide; also known as amylin) protein may attack the islet cells that produce insulin. Such molecular features are unique to human-IAPP, when compared to non-toxic rat-IAPP, indicating the need for a better understanding of the molecular processes underlying the pathology of type II diabetes. Therefore, the outcome of the proposed study will aid in the development of drugs to treat the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Functional magnetic resonance imaging is a popular tool in studies of neurodevelopmental disorders, but re- producibility is a major issue, in part due to biases and inefﬁciencies related to head motion during MRI collection. We develop statistical methods that account for issues created by head motion, and we propose a model for brain dynamics during a task. We conduct a reproducibility study to learn how the brain functions in autism spectrum disorder and develop tools that can be used by other research groups to improve our understanding of brain disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many human patients who suffer from Alzheimer's disease, dementia and the broad spectrum of psychosis, including schizophrenia, show a range of memory deficits along with the hippocampal-entorhinal cortex damage, yet little is known about how specific memories are accessed and formed into meaningful memories to accomplish given tasks, especially at the systems level. This proposed study focuses on the neural dynamics for successful memory access and retrieval during episodic working memory tasks to elucidate the neural circuit mechanism in the hippocampal-cortical network. Our proposed studies will uncover the neural dynamics of hippocampal-entorhinal memory system to extend our understanding of how the system malfunctions during psychotic states and to establish novel early-stage diagnostic measurements / analyses in human patients that are hinted by the animal in vivo recordings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite recent advances in treatment, multiple myeloma (MM), the second most frequent human hematologic cancer remains incurable and there is an urgent need for novel and more effective therapies. MicroRNAs (miRs) play critical roles in the progression of MM-associated immune evasion and have an exciting potential for the development of novel and more effective therapies if they can efficiently be delivered in vivo. Here we propose to apply nanomedicine to study the role of miRs in MM biology and as therapeutic tools utilizing non-toxic polymeric nanoparticles (NPs) of proven in vivo miR targeting/delivering capacity to myeloma cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative SAR441236 is a novel synthetic antibody that combines three different anti-HIV-1 specificities into a single molecule. Our study leverages samples from the phase I ACTG study of SAR441236 and investigates the mechanisms of its antiviral effects and the virus adaptation to this neutralization. We believe our approaches test previously unexplored hypotheses that are central to understand how, for the first time, trispecific bnAbs may be used as HIV therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In light of a growing body of evidence which suggests that prolonged duration CPR is a dynamic process, without universally optimal “one-size-fits-all” parameters, advanced methods of CPR individualization may be applied to optimize cardiac and cerebral perfusion for these patients. We propose to study the effects of machine learning and optimal control techniques within the context of CPR, thus creating a closed-loop CPR system that has been trained by pre-clinical data to modify CPR characteristics and optimize blood flow. Our preliminary studies suggest that machine learning and control algorithms can be successfully deployed in a preclinical model to adapt compression and decompression depth, increasing vital organ blood flow as compared to standard CPR techniques. If our hypotheses are verified, a gateway for the first human trials is open.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: We have discovered and characterized a novel structure, called α-sheet, which we believe to be common among the soluble oligomeric forms of multiple amyloid peptides and proteins, including Abeta associated with Alzheimer's Disease. We have designed small peptides to be complementary to this structure, and they inhibit fibril formation via selective binding of the toxic oligomeric form of Abeta. Here we propose to investigate the structure of the amyloid species during the process of amyloidogenesis using different forms of Abeta, and explore the nature of the oligomers in CSF and in more biologically relevant model systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative Homologous recombination and adaptive evolution are key mechanisms driving bacterial adaptation to new environments and new treatments. The proposed study aims to apply new approaches to determine the rates and patterns of recombination across genomic data in order to identify the factors shaping the rates and landscapes of recombination as well as the impact of adaptive evolution on bacteria. Upon completion, this project will provide a global view of the interplay between recombination and adaptative evolution across hundreds of bacterial species.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative  The major goal of this project is to improve the diagnostic, treatment guidance, and research utility of quantitative positron emission tomography (PET) imaging, through the development of robust, near real-time, deep-learning based reconstruction approaches allowing efficacious use of standard, low dose, and novel low activity imaging molecular bio-tracers. The proposed work is relevant to public health, since an improvement in the reconstructed images will lead to more accurate diagnosis of diseases and more accurate treatment guidance and monitoring of the response to therapy, while allowing for decreased patient radiation dose. It will also facilitate quantitatively reliable tools for research investigations with new radiotracers for PET tailored to specific diseases. 2

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The desire to consume alcohol is driven by motivation; it is commonly believed that this motivation is altered in those with substance use disorders. The central nucleus of the amygdala is one potential neural substrate for modulating action selection, both seeking and drinking, based on changes in motivation. The proposed research seeks to explore the neural activity pattern in the central nucleus of the amygdala during instrumental tasks rewarded with ethanol to gain a clearer picture of this region’s role in motivated behaviors.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women in East and Southern Africa experience two-fold higher risk of HIV acquisition during pregnancy and face adherence challenges with existing biomedical prevention methods – daily oral pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP). This project leverages data from an ongoing R01 to evaluate pregnant and postpartum women’s preferences for novel long-acting (LA)-PrEP formulations and identify early process indicators for implementing these options in maternal and child health (MCH) systems. These data will inform tailored HIV prevention strategies for pregnant/postpartum women at risk of HIV and provide opportunities for the F31 candidate to gain expertise in new methods and advance as an independent investigator.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Effective drugs to treat kidney fibrosis, which is the primary cause of end-stage renal failure in chronic kidney disease, are lacking. Transforming growth factor beta2 (TGF-β2) is a protein that triggers fibrosis in the kidney and is thus an important drug target. In the body, TGF-β2 exists mainly in an inactive form, and the goals of this proposal are to determine the mechanisms that keep TGF-β2 inactive and to develop innovative drugs that stop TGF-β2 from becoming active as a way to prevent kidney fibrosis.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Appreciating how chromosomes X and Y regulate sex differences in the brain is critical to understanding how autism spectrum disorder (ASD) develops and why more boys are diagnosed than girls. This proposal will examine how chromosome Y in particular regulates crucial functions of microglia in brain maturation. The ultimate goal of this proposal is to gain insight into microglial dysregulation in atypical neurodevelopment and to identify mechanisms for sex-specific interventions for ASD.

PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and related dementias are characterized by the aggregation of tau protein. The heterogonous nature of the tau aggregates is a challenge for developing detection methods and treatments. The characterization of disease relevant tau polymorphs/strains will advance early diagnostics and development of therapeutic strategies which would improve the health and well-being of millions of people in the US.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Narrative: The Personalized Cross-sector Transitional Care Management (PC-TCM) project seeks to promote care continuity, reduce low value utilization, and reduce the burden of treatment for high-need, high-cost patients receiving care across health, specialty and social care sectors. The project will expand the evidence- based R21 Care Transitions Intervention (CTI) to bring social sector providers as equal partners in HNHC care, refine CTI HIE capacity to include cross-sector care alerts and a personalized care plan, and evaluate the impact of PC-TCM from a patient and provider perspective.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Implementing personalized cross-sector transitional care management to promote care continuity, reduce low value utilization, and reduce the burden of treatment for high-need, high-cost patients

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Chromatin remodelers are the enzymes responsible for establishing and maintaining this genome packaging, acting to physically expose or bury particular DNA sequences within genes. Disruptions of chromatin remodelers have been directly linked to cancer and other human diseases, highlighting the important role of chromatin remodeling for proper cellular growth and survival. By uncovering the mechanisms by which chromatin remodelers reshape the physical packaging of the genome, we hope to better understand fundamental processes that are essential for human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The proposed studies will examine molecular mechanisms regulating potassium secretion in the distal nephron. The studies will define the role of a mechanically regulated ion channel, Piezo1, in increasing intracellular calcium and facilitating potassium secretion into the urine when urinary flow rates increase and in response to a high potassium diet. This work has the potential to uncover mechanisms involved in the development and/or maintenance of potassium disorders, and identify potential targets for novel therapies to treat imbalances in potassium.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease (AD), the most common form of dementia, creates a devastating burden on patients, caregivers, healthcare systems, and the broader society. Because available treatments primarily offer symptom management rather than significant disease modification or reversal, it is imperative to identify potential avenues for delaying the onset of the disease or curbing its progression. Accordingly, the overarching objective of this integrative, clinically-relevant study is to rigorously investigate the extent to which the longevity gene KLOTHO offers resilience against age- and AD-related synaptic dysfunction and modifies the relationship between such dysfunction and cognitive decline with a potential to reduce AD risk and its socio-economic footprint.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The project will identify the optimal intermittent vibration force stimulation to control orthodontic tooth movement rate through a rat study and scale it up for other species, including dogs and humans. The relevance of this project is that, once successful, the technology will enable clinicians to shorten the treatment time with reduced side-effects. The long term goal is to translate this technology into devices that can be used c linic ally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The accurate repair of DNA double-strand breaks is critical for viability in all organisms. Repair mechanisms that rely on DNA synthesis initiated by broken ends were previously thought to compete with mechanisms that join ends independently of sequence homology, but our data shows that these are actually sequential, linked processes. This proposal investigates the coordination between these pathways of double-strand break repair in human cells to understand how this affects the processing of ends during the cell cycle, how this process works globally across the genome, and how the complexes involved in this coordination work at a mechanistic level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Majority of the patients with aggressive prostate cancer develop resistance to therapy and the tumor metastasizes to bones and other visceral organs accounting for high morbidity and mortality. The goal of this project is to define the underlying mechanisms that promote the survival and colonization of prostate tumor cells in the bone microenvironment. Our study will uncover molecular links between mitochondrial metabolism and transcriptional regulation that enables PCa adaptation, survival and ultimately metastatic competency.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Millions of women in the United States (US) face gaps and transitions (disruptions) in insurance coverage during the preconception, pregnancy, and postpartum periods, which has led to recent state- and federal- legislation proposing perinatal insurance eligibility expansions as a solution for addressing preventable maternal morbidity and mortality in the US. We lack an understanding, however, of 1) the associations between maternal insurance disruptions and maternal and child health (MCH) outcomes and 2) whether prior perinatal insurance expansions have been associated with improved MCH outcomes. Correcting these knowledge gaps is the overarching goal of this proposal, data which we believe will be of great public health importance and inform clinical and policy strategies for improving maternal health in the US.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Understanding the impact of perinatal insurance disruptions on maternal and child health outcomes

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: PTSD is a serious psychiatric concern for our Veteran population and the VA is highly motivated to address our current gaps in understanding regarding the biological underpinnings of stress response to traumatic experiences. Leveraging advancements in genetics and brain functioning research may be an important path in improving this understanding. This proposal looks to use publicly available datasets and empirically derived biological markers for PTSD. We provide evidence this approach could help in diagnosing PTSD, as well as uncovering different types of PTSD based on genetic and brain data. This work could pave the way for algorithmically determining care, or provide a foundation for developing tailored care for types of PTSD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is highly relevant to public health and NIH’s mission because transcription-coupled nucleotide excision repair (TC-NER) is an important pathway for removing harmful DNA lesions in the transcribed genome and a critical drug target pathway for anticancer chemotherapy. Mutations in TC-NER proteins cause several human diseases including Cockayne Syndrome, Cerebro-Oculo-Facio-Skeletal Syndrome, and Ultraviolet–Sensitive Syndrome. The new knowledge obtained from proposed research will provide novel mechanistic insights into TC-NER as well as a framework for developing novel TC-NER targeting therapeutics against cancer and other human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This project investigates the daily and long-term patterns of mental health outcomes among Hispanic and Latinx (H&L) caregivers of individuals with Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRDs). Using a multi-time scale design consisting of daily diary surveys and longer, traditional questionnaires, we will examine interactions between contextual, individual-level, and cultural factors that impact mental health trajectories over time. The results from this project will identify modifiable targets that improve resilience and inform ecologically and culturally relevant interventions to support H&L caregivers, an ethnically and racially underrepresented population in the field of aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The project uses a simple cyanobacterial model system to ask questions that cannot be addressed as directly in animals about how the circadian biological clock keeps time, stays synchronized with the environment, and contributes to the well-being of an organism. Circadian dysfunction contributes to a range of disease states in humans, from metabolic syndrome to mental illness. Past discoveries using this system have revealed fundamentally new paradigms of protein biochemistry with relevance for diverse organisms, including humans and pathogens.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative  Child maltreatment is widely recognized as a serious threat to children's well-being and health, and in these cases, the fidelity of the child victim/witness's report is often crucial to securing an outcome in the best interest of the child. There is current debate and a pressing need to identify strategies for obtaining information about time passage and event sequence – elements critical to a child's perceived credibility. We propose to examine (1) how children are questioned, and respond about, event sequence in maltreatment investigations, (2) how differences in children's age, comprehension, attention, executive functioning skills, and memory may impact their ability to accurately report event sequence when prompted with the identified question types, and (3) how questions and child responses regarding event sequence impact mock juror comprehension and decision-making relevant to child maltreatment cases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Arrhythmogenic right ventricular dysplasia/cardiomyopathy (ARVD/C) is termed a cardiac “disease of the desmosome”; however, the mechanisms through which desmosomal mutations drive ARVD/C remain unclear. Proposed studies are aimed to dissect mechanisms by which desmosomal mutations in RNA splicing drive ARVD/C, as well as targeted gene therapy and mutation corrective strategies to alter ARVD/C disease course.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Import of the viral DNA to the nucleus of target cells is an essential, and vulnerable step in the HIV-1 life cycle. This project will investigate the mechanistic basis for the inhibition of HIV-1 nuclear import by Mx2 and the effects of Mx2 activity on viral susceptibility to other innate immune effectors. Understanding the molecular details of these interactions may provide new opportunities for the development of novel therapeutics for HIV-1 infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A central challenge in biology is to understand the genetic basis of complex traits, including those relevant for human health. Genes underlying human metabolic disorders show variation that correlates with climate, suggesting a link between environmental adaptation and disease. Mice are the premier model for humans, and the proposed work will describe the genetic basis of complex traits underlying environmental adaptation in mice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Machine Learning in Atrial Fibrillation Narrative Atrial fibrillation (AF) is an enormous public health problem that affects 2-5 million Americans, causing stroke, rapid heart beats, heart failure and even death. In this project, the applicant will apply numerical analysis and machine learning to detailed data acquired from patients undergoing therapy, to better define individual biological types of AF, which may provide a foundation for personalized patient-tailored diagnosis and therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In traumatic brain injury (TBI), persistent neuroinflammation contributes to disease progression and poor outcome, and microglia plays a critical role in the neuroinflammatory response following injury. We have discovered a mechanism to decrease the inflammatory nature of microglia, so they are more protective rather than disease-inducing by the nasal administration of anti-CD3 that stimulates immune cells to travel to the brain and decreases inflammation. This work seeks to test this treatment in animal models of TBI to determine its effect on the brain and immune system over time and potentially generate novel therapeutic options for the millions of Americans with TBI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Parkinson’s disease (PD) develops insidiously over many years and by the time patients are diagnosed, extensive neurodegeneration has already occurred and it is too late to prevent disability; earlier interventions would be more likely to succeed in arresting or delaying the disease progress. We propose therefore to conduct a large longitudinal investigation to identify individuals with prodromal PD, and to elucidate its natural history, heterogeneity, and rates of progression, including the possible impact of covid-19 and the contribution of novel biomarkers. The project will take advantage of well-established cohorts comprising over 50,000 individuals who have already provided extensive and validated data, and stands to provide in an efficient manner the in-depth knowledge on prodromal PD that is needed to initiate prevention trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Multiple Myeloma is an incurable cancer of the blood that takes the lives of over 12,000 people every year. It remains a difficult disease to treat due to its genetic complexity from the earliest stages of the disease, indicating a need for a precision medicine approach in treating these patients. In this application Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai will partner with Cancer Genetics, Inc. to develop a multi-omics clinical decision assay that will improve long-term outcomes for patients with advanced myeloma and generate valuable insights and tools that can be broadly leveraged for other disease indications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Brackney & Armstrong Narrative. Arthropod-borne (arbo-) viruses poses a continued and significant public health threat despite vast expenditures towards their control. Understanding the transmission dynamics and how vector behavior influences these dynamics will be critical to developing novel control strategies required to reduce human disease risk. Therefore, we will be examining the effect that the biologically-relevant multiple bloodfeeding behavior has on arbovirus infection within vector mosquitoes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative A complete understanding of the mechanisms employed to regulate gene expression is necessary to combat the aberrant regulation that underlies many human developmental conditions and ailments, including cancer. The long-term goals of our research efforts are to determine the regulation imposed on the essential multi-subunit RNA polymerase during each stage of the transcription cycle, including regulation imposed by chromatin structure and to specifically characterize the available mechanisms to regulate transcription through histone- bound DNAs. The results obtained will determine the mechanisms that support transcription regulation, transcription elongation on chromatin templates, describe the activities of conserved and domain-specific transcription factors, and detail the role of extended chromatin structures and genome architecture on gene regulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Recent evidence suggests that up to 10% of patients with Pancreatic Ductal AdenoCarcinoma (PDAC) harbor a germline genetic mutation in a cancer risk gene, and genetic testing is now recommended for all patients. However, the best ways to perform this testing – and to use the resulting information to help patients and their family members – remain unclear. We hypothesize that by using a simulation modeling approach, we can identify effective and high-value genetic testing strategies for patients with PDAC, including potential benefits both to patients and their family members.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Infants of depressed mothers and children diagnosed with autism spectrum disorders show reduced sensitivity to social reward, which may disrupt their ability to prioritize attention to and learning from their caregivers. However, past research examining infants’ attention orienting has emphasized mechanisms based on perceptual salience and endogenous control without addressing the role of social-motivational factors (e.g., caregiving quality). The proposed research investigates the extent to which social-motivational factors and endogenous attention control predict attention orienting to caregivers in infancy, with a long-term goal of understanding mechanisms that link social reward processing to early attention in both typical and atypical development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The optimal diabetes care for nursing home residents with both diabetes and cognitive impairment is unclear. The proposed studies will examine current diabetes care practices in NH residents across the spectrum of cognitive impairment and determine which practices are associated with better (and worse) outcomes. This study will build the evidence base for diabetes care for nursing home residents with diabetes and cognitive impairment, which will ultimately lead to improved guidelines, improved care and improved outcomes for these vulnerable older adults.

PHR: Infants asphyxiated at birth represent a serious problem worldwide. There is a need for development of neurophysiological and neuroimaging biomarkers providing accurate measures of neurovascular and metabolic functions– critical components of brain health in babies. This proposal is relevant to public health as the wavelet biomarkers can improve identification of brain injury at birth, guide patient selection for therapeutic interventions in mild HIE, keeping with the NINDS mission to reduce the burden of neurological disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the United States, young Black males have a substantially greater need for sexual reproductive health (SRH) services and are at a higher risk of contracting sexually transmitted infections (STIs) than other young adult populations. This study aims to examine if new media can positively inform, educate, and reach young Black men, resulting in improved access to sexual reproductive healthcare and safe sex behaviors. The information gained from this study will promote the health and wellness of a community of young men both online and in person and assist in developing culturally relevant sexual health interventions for generations and beyond.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cognitive impairment is a pervasive debilitating feature of sickle cell disease (SCD), with over 50% of children demonstrating early neurodevelopmental delays, ultimately influencing ability for adolescents with SCD to engage in effective decision-making needed for successful transition into adulthood. This study will examine the efficacy of a cognitive remediation program (CRP) to improve decision-making skills in youth with SCD (10-18y) in order to enhance self-care and self-advocacy to improve and maintain transition readiness skills. This research proposal will fill several major gaps in the understanding of remediation of cognitive deficits in SCD and will lay the groundwork for evidence-based interventions aimed to improve transition of care, enhance self-care, and ultimately improve life expectancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Project Narrative Increased access and high prevalence of cannabis use are accompanied by the widespread public perception of cannabis as favorable and therapeutic, despite limited supporting evidence from medical science. However, little is known about where such health claim messages originate and how they may influence the user’s beliefs and behaviors. The project will provide information on the sources, content, and impact of disseminated messages that can guide cannabis regulatory practices and ultimately reduce potential harms from cannabis misuse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Well-designed and well-conducted clinical trials are the primary means for evaluating new cancer therapies, advancing cures, reducing morbidity and mortality, and improving patient outcomes. The SWOG SDMC aims to be a leader in innovative trial design and analysis of science-driven publically funded Phase II and Phase III trials and translational medicine studies. Furthermore, our timely and high-quality trial implementation, management, and reporting ensure that the results of clinical trials have the greatest potential impact on cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with acute respiratory distress syndrome often require artificial nutrition as part of their care, but questions remain about the optimal timing, level, route, and composition for the individual patient. Recent advances in precision medicine may help personalize delivery of nutrition if greater understanding of the clinical and biologic variables determining response to artificial nutrition is achieved. This proposal will perform biologic assays on existing biospecimens stored in the NHLBI Biologic Specimen Repository from one of the largest trials of nutrition in acute respiratory distress syndrome to help identify the variables influencing responses to one specific aspect of nutrition (level of nutrition) with the eventual goal of individualizing care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Despite achieving 44% PrEP coverage in our previous cohort of young Black MSM, HIV incidence in the group was still 6.2%/year. To further increase the impact of PrEP, we propose an early intervention to delay or avert PrEP discontinuations, offering of on-demand PrEP, and offering of STI PEP to a new cohort of 300 YBMSM in Atlanta. These interventions will work together to promote PrEP persistence and decrease new STI and HIV infections in these most vulnerable men.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity is a preventable and treatable condition associated with the leading causes of death worldwide and disproportionately affects sexual minority women, yet little is known about the mechanisms that confer heightened risk for these populations. I propose a mixed methods study to examine development and maintenance of weight-related behaviors among sexual minority women using qualitative life history interviews and experience sampling methods, with study data used to inform a preliminary model by which minority stressors may increase risk for obesity that can be tested in a subsequent longitudinal R01 study. This K01 will result in an independent research program that addresses critical gaps in the understanding of obesity disparities among sexual minority women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Approximately 40 million people worldwide are living with HIV/AIDS; however, a protective vaccine or functional cure remain elusive despite four decades of intense research. The proposed Duke Center for HIV Structural Biology will provide new insights into the dynamics of HIV-1 entry and fusion with the host membrane, the Env-initiated immune activation of B-cell receptors, and the role of anti-Env antibodies in blocking viral rebound. The ultimate goal of these studies is to advance structural biology techniques and knowledge of HIV-1 Env structure-derived disease mechanisms in HIV-1 infection and rebound.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Incarceration disproportionately impacts persons of color and those of low socioeconomic status, groups who are also at high risk for all forms of dementia. By linking administrative data from two national health care systems, we will follow persons age 50 and older to evaluate the relationship between incarceration and dementia over time. Findings from this project will inform strategies to mitigate risk of patients with dementia entering incarceration, will delineate those at highest risk of developing dementia after incarceration, and will identify prime intervention points where optimization of dementia care could reduce health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cancer therapy with a combination of cytotoxic drugs and with immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICIs)—agents that reinvigorate the suppressed immune system to attack cancer cells (e.g., anti-PD-1 antibody)—has revolutionized the treatment of metastatic lung cancer, nevertheless, therapeutic resistance is observed in a significant proportion of patients and a critical determinant of unresponsiveness in these patients is the intra- tumoral accumulation of adenosine, a molecule that actively suppresses the effectiveness of immunotherapies. To deplete the intra-tumoral adenosine, we have explored the use of an FDA approved drug, [PEGylated]- Adenosine Deaminase (PEG-ADA). Our proposed studies will confirm if depletion of adenosine with PEG-ADA can induce anti-tumor immunity and sensitize lung cancer to chemo-immunotherapy and such a therapeutic strategy can further extend the life of patient with a disease that is now a major health problem worldwide.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Social anxiety disorder is highly prevalent in the United States, most commonly emerging during adolescence. Relationships with a pet dog may support adaptive coping for youth with social anxiety by providing social support, fostering social interactions, and reducing physiological responses to anxiety. Longitudinal research assessing when and how dog relationships can effectively support teenagers with anxiety is critical for maximizing translational impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Understanding how memories change over time in the brain is central to the science of memory distortion. This proposal examines how shifting interactions between hippocampal and cortical memory systems give rise to distortions in memory, using computational modeling to make predictions that are tested with functional neuroimaging (fMRI) and non-invasive brain stimulation techniques (TMS). Detailing the interplay of hippocampal and cortical memory systems will provide nuance to current research in memory consolidation, which may lead to improved methods for testing the nature of memory distortions in patients with diffuse cortical damage and potentially provide improved rehabilitation strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative The human skeleton and its major joints, such as the hip and knee, arise developmentally as result of coordinated programs governing cartilage, connective tissue, and bone formation. The proposed research focuses on the role of individual cells in these complex developmental processes in the human hind limb, through the use of state-of-the-art technologies that will define the specific genetic processes cells utilize to give rise to functionally and morphologically distinct tissues and structures. Obtaining this molecular information is both timely and crucial to bridge the gaps in our knowledge of these important skeletal structures, and as such, a new resource will be made available to the scientific and medical communities to promote innovative solutions to orthopedic problems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aging results in a severe decline of skeletal muscle regenerative potential and a diminished response to aerobic exercise, which manifests clinically as impaired muscle function, increased risk of adverse events, and loss of independence. The proposed study will advance our mechanistic understanding of how dysregulation of the hypoxia signaling pathway in aging impacts muscle regeneration and aerobic exercise adaptation. Importantly, it will further evaluate whether restoration of hypoxia signaling improves muscle function in a murine model of aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Skeletal muscle wasting is a major reason for frailty and loss of independence in various disease states, including cancer and in the elderly population. However, cellular and molecular mechanisms of skeletal muscle wasting in remain poorly understood. Our proposed studies will identify novel molecular mechanisms that may lead to the development of novel therapeutic approaches for the prevention of muscle loss in cancer patients and during aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer invading to the nerve, a process termed perineural invasion (PNI), makes cancer more difficult to eradicate and causes significant pain. This proposal explores the potential role of Schwann cells, a group of cells that surround and support nerve axons and become activated in response to insults to the nerves in oral cancer PNI and pain. A better understanding of Schwann cells in cancer PNI and pain will help develop novel strategies for PNI and pain control in oral cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity in childhood is highly prevalent and associated with increased risk of certain cancers, cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and reduced quality of life. Despite much national attention and research, obesity prevalence continues to rise, and substantial disparities persist, suggesting a large gap between research and practice. This proposal will evaluate the dissemination and implementation of an effective intervention using electronic health records to improve the management of overweight and obesity in pediatric primary care within different practice settings serving low-income, minority, and rural children disproportionately impacted by obesity to reduce obesity prevalence and disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE As the genetic counseling field has grown to over 4,000 and the profession has integrated across healthcare specialties, there is greater need for genetic counselors to be able to research the practice in an evidence-based fashion. Genetic counselors are primed to study the profession in their current roles, but additional research training is needed to foster necessary skills and methodology expertise to lead independent research programs in academia, clinic, industry, public and population health settings. To support this advancement of the field, we propose the first ever, two-year, part-time research fellowship for four genetic counselors called the Genetic Counseling Fellowship in Research Training (GC-FIRST) with the overarching aim to train genetic counseling research leaders and future mentors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disorders affecting the musculoskeletal system pose a major challenge to US health, due to their frequency, morbidity and resulting disability. The delivery of improved care for patients with musculoskeletal disorders will require more rapid translation of basic knowledge into approaches that improve clinical practice. The training program described in this application is intended to provide the skill set necessary for producing orthopaedic scientists who will be better able to translate new findings from the laboratory to the bedside.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Pediatric mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI) is a major public health problem in the United States. This study permits a pre-injury and post-injury assessment of biopsychosocial predictors and mechanisms of the behavioral, psychiatric, and neurocognitive impact of mTBI, minimizing error and bias that may occur with post- injury retrospective reports of pre-injury status. This study will foster more accurate prediction, earlier identification and improved treatment of children with behavioral, psychiatric, and neurocognitive complications related to mTBI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Patients treated with radiation therapy for metastatic disease of the spine suffer high risk for pathologic spinal fractures (PVF) an integral part of spinal adverse events (SAE). In this work we will determine whether a prediction model, based on our computed tomography derived assessment of structural analysis protocol (CT- SAP) and the measurement of blood turnover markers, demonstrates significantly higher performance in predicting the risk of PVF compared to current clinical protocols in this patient cohort. This study will provide novel data for establishing quantitative assessment of PVF risk in patients with spinal metastasis, thus addressing a critical gap in the ability to evaluate and treat these patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: 8. Project Narrative This project will be one of the most comprehensive evaluations of supermarket food labeling to date, using real-world data from supermarkets, an experiment in a naturalistic online supermarket, and surveys of shoppers who will report on their use of labels while shopping and barriers to purchasing healthy foods and using labels. The study will evaluate the effect of the revised Nutrition Facts Label, mandated for packaged foods by the US Food and Drug Administration by 2021, and updates to the Guiding Stars labeling system, one of the most commonly used dietary quality labeling programs in US supermarkets. Results will inform policymakers, retailers, and manufacturers regarding how best to improve the dietary quality of Americans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Bicarbonate transporters control the acid-base balance of the body. Our research indicates that some bicarbonate transporters may in fact transport carbonate, or the sodium carbonate ion pair. Furthermore, some might be capable of conducting the gas carbon dioxide across cell membrane as they transport carbonate. We use a variety of highly sophisticated physiological and computational methods to understand the molecular mechanism by which these transporters function both in normal and disease states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Calcium is the most abundant mineral in the human body and its levels are maintained with the help of the extracellular calcium-sensing receptor (CaSR), a cell membrane protein. Genetic and functional defects in CaSR result in diverse diseases related to calcium metabolism: overactive CaSR leads to low blood calcium level (hypocalcemia) that causes muscle cramping and seizures; whereas underactive CaSR results in high blood calcium level (hypercalcemia), hyperactive parathyroid glands (hyperparathyroidism), kidney stones and various neurological disorders. This work will fill the gap in our structural and mechanistic understanding of CaSR function and regulation that are key to human health, and provide insights into the design of new drugs that will alleviate the CaSR associated medical conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative  The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will advance our understanding of the pathogenesis of pancreatitis, a disease with considerable morbidity and mortality and currently without a treatment. The results will establish the importance of maintaining pancreatic cholesterol metabolism as a clinically relevant modulator of this disease; and identify potential molecular targets amenable for pharmacologic intervention to normalize cholesterol metabolism and reduce pancreatitis severity. Thus, this proposal is relevant to the NIH’s goal to develop research strategies as a basis for disease treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is responsible for over 200,000 new cancer cases annually. At present, there are no viral-specific therapies to treat EBV-associated disease. This proposal focuses on viral and cellular mechanisms that coordinate metabolism with gene expression, and how this impacts control of viral infection and tumorigenesis. This study will provide new information on metabolic control of viral latency and new opportunities for therapeutic intervention for EBV-associated cancers.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE    This project involves the collection of data related to connections between the brain, spinal cord and muscles  in stroke survivors before and after they receive a clinically- relevant walking treatment. The goal of this work is  to determine if baseline status of or changes in the strength of these nervous system connections can help  rehabilitation clinicians and researchers identify who is most likely to show a positive response to gait training  treatments comprising treadmill walking with or without electrical stimulation. Our long- term goal is to utilize  non- invasive measures of nervous system excitability to identify likely responders and non- responders to  clinical gait treatments, therefore helping to personalize rehabilitation and maximize its positive impact on  walking function and quality of life in people with neurological disabilities.

PHR: Public Health Relevant Statement  The twinned epidemics of opioid and methamphetamine use have been reported in the US and other countries such as Vietnam. We propose to develop and evaluate optimal combinations of evidence-based interventions to improve HIV outcomes and reduce methamphetamine use among people with opioid use disorders who are in methadone maintenance therapy. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE External cues and sex chromosomes profoundly influence DNA methylation patterns in mouse pluripotent stem cells, yet the underlying mechanisms and their functional relevance remain incompletely understood. We recently discovered that male and female ESCs cultured in naïve conditions (2i) as well as female ESCs cultured in conventional conditions (serum/LIF) exhibit global hypomethylation with a concomitant erosion of genomic imprints, chromosomal instability and an impaired developmental potential due to suppressed MAPK signaling. Based on these strong preliminary data and the notion that the MAPK pathway plays crucial roles in early embryos, this R01 application seeks to explore how the MAPK pathway influences DNA methylation, chromosomal stability and developmental potential in mouse and human pluripotent cells with the goal to understand basic mechanisms and develop safer human stem cell models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative While the concept of the multiple-state GPCR activation model has been accepted in the pharmacological and structural biology communities, we lack an understanding of the roles of intermediate conformational states and their interactions with signaling partners such as Gabg, and as such, an understanding of the signaling efficacy. This proposed project, preceded by our development of receptor conformation-biased mutants, has led to a high-resolution conformational profile for the adenosine A2A receptor, well positioning us to study the individual intermediate conformational states, their interactions with G proteins, and consequent signaling. The completion of this project will promote our understanding of signaling diversity beyond a simple two-state ON/OFF switch model with implications for drug discovery based on GPCR and G protein conformational responses to ligands.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obstructed labor is accountable for 3-8% of the maternal deaths worldwide and, in many countries, is almost as prevalent today as it was 30 years ago. Cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD) is an inadequate size of the maternal pelvis, compared to the fetal head, which prevents the fetus from passing through the pelvic cavity during delivery causing obstructed labor and requires delivery via Caesarean section (C/S), which is not readily available at the time of labor to most women in low-resource settings around the world. This paper presents the use of anthropometry and 3D-camera technology, with or without ultrasound to develop novel, low-cost, safe, easy-to- use, scalable tools to assess risk of obstructive labor due to CPD in Ethiopian women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor (PNET) incidence is on the rise and remains an unmet clinical need. We have identified two new targets for this deadly disease and have a drug (in Phase I) that can interfere with core pathways that promote PNET. Through this proposal we will perform extensive pre-clinical evaluation of the utility of these targets and also identify biomarkers that would position us to initiate a tailored clinical study in the immediate future to positively impact treatment of patients suffering from the devastating PNET disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal seeks support to develop a NextGen novel ionization method and variants thereof for biological mass spectrometry that will transform tissue imaging (molecular microscopy). Furthermore, the tissue imaging data will be derived from serial tissue sections and ablation based 3D imaging with multiple lines of biological readouts (e.g., neurotransmitters, lipids, glycans) providing new insights into important human health and disease (stroke, wound healing, cardiometabolic disease). In summary, we will establish a disruptive enabling bioanalytical technology through detailed characterization using real biological systems; this new technology and the underlying processes, hardware and software components will be fully documented and freely shared with the imaging community, and many of the proposed advances can readily be adapted by other MSI platform technologies to transform the entire MSI field since the MSiReader software is agnostic with respect to mass spectrometry platform, laser wavelength, biological system, or disease and is driven by the needs of the entire MSI community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project narrative During infection, SARS-CoV-2 induces formation of an endoplasmic reticulum (ER)- derived organelle (called the double-membrane vesicle) to support replication of the viral genome, although the molecular basis of this process remains enigmatic. Upon assembly of the replicated genome with virus structural proteins, the newly-formed viral progeny undergoes secretion via a poorly-define mechanism. Accordingly, this application will elucidate how SARS-CoV-2 exploits two ER membrane host factors (RTN3 and SigmaR1) to promote viral replication and secretion, two essential infection steps.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: RESEARCH INST OF FOX CHASE CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH) This study is aimed at investigating in detail the pathogenic role of IL-1-driven inflammatory pathway in anaplastic large cell lymphoma (ALCL). Gaining insight into the mechanisms activating this inflammatory pathway in ALCL as well as its exact involvement in the malignant cell transformation may lead to improved understanding of the molecular circuitry that drives tumor survival and shapes the tumor microenvironment. The therapeutic potential of targeting the pathway will be tested using a specific kinase inhibitor and a recombinant inhibitory protein, which may lead to novel strategies for targeted therapy in this unique group of lymphoid malignancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Morphogenesis is a universally important process in growth and development that involves changes in cell shape and position that must occur at precisely the right time and place and sex, yet a comprehensive understanding of the regulatory mechanisms controlling the cellular machinery is still lacking. In this project, we will determine how morphogenesis of the four-celled tail tip in C. elegans males is temporally scheduled to occur precisely at a key developmental transition point and what effector genes are targeted by the "master regulator" male-specific transcription factor DMD-3 to execute morphogenesis. This study will lead to a model for how genes interact to produce biological form, thus providing a basis to identify key conserved components that control morphogenesis and which could thus provide new targets for pharmaceuticals or other interventions to aid wound healing or mitigate the effects of morphogenetic faults contributing to birth defects or cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative REDD1 upregulation activates autophagy through inhibition of mTORC1. We propose to evaluate the roles that REDD1 plays in renal cell carcinoma progression, the mechanisms of PIM kinase inhibitor-mediated REDD1 induction, and the link between REDD1 expression and sensitivity to autophagy inhibition. Our overall goal is to identify novel strategies to target autophagy for renal cell carcinoma therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative Contact-dependent growth inhibition (CDI) is an important mechanism of inter-cellular competition found in a variety of Gram-negative bacterial pathogens. This proposal utilizes genetic, biochemical and structural analyses to gain mechanistic insights into CDI toxin activities. This research will significantly increase our understanding of the evolution and ecology of bacterial pathogens and could inform novel antimicrobial strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research seeks to develop a functional and mechanistic understanding of how GABAergic neuron modulation by nicotine contributes to the brain metastasis of lung cancer. Here, we aim to define the newly discovered functional role of GABAergic neuron in supporting brain metastasis and provides a scientific basis for pursuing the inhibition of nicotine-activated GABA shunt as a novel therapeutic strategy that could significantly improve the treatment and prevention of brain metastasis in cancer patients with past and current smoking history. Information gleaned from this work may be used in the generation of future clinical trials focusing on therapeutic interventions for preventing brain metastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE OVERALL Genetic complexity and cellular heterogeneity are the greatest challenge to understanding and treating cancer. The Jackson Laboratory Cancer Center is focused on resolving this complexity through applying advanced computational and genomic approaches on novel organismal, cellular, and computational models of cancer, and by investigating the in vivo tumor-stromal-immune interactions. We translate our findings to the clinic through the provision of genetic and genomic technologies to key clinical collaborators.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Molecular mechanisms for diabetes impaired fracture healing are largely unknown. Ciliopathies have very recently been identified as key modulators of the relationship between diabetes and metabolic physiology. We will pursue this relationship to better understand diabetic fracture healing and as a mechanistic tool for the engineering design of novel therapeutic aids for the benefit of diabetic patients suffering from bone fractures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Most young adult (<30 years old) people who inject drugs (PWID) –who are the group at greatest risk for hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection—do not initiate available curative therapy. Building on our extensive foundation of dyadic research and dyadic behavior change theories, we developed the Partner Navigation Intervention a two-session injecting partnership intervention to enhance dyadic capacity for HCV treatment initiation for young adult PWID. The proposed study is a randomized controlled study (RCT) to assess the efficacy and mechanism of action of the first behavioral intervention to increase HCV treatment initiation among young adult PWID.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: CALIFORNIA POLY STATE U SAN LUIS OBISPO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The persistent lack of diversity among scientists in the biomedical field inhibits our ability to effectively address the complex array of health problems and disparities that affect our nation and the world today. U-RISE at Cal Poly is a training program that incorporates best practices from evidence-based training programs, providing underrepresented undergraduate students the experiences needed to pursue a biomedical, research-focused graduate degree. The multi-faceted program includes mentored research experiences, didactic instruction on conceptual and technical research skills, mentoring teams, and specialized curriculum emphasizing the prosocial value of biomedical research, building identity as a scientist, fostering a deep understanding of health equity, and developing knowledge and skills to direct research towards current health challenges.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of our proposal is to increase the diversity of students pursuing a Ph.D. in a STEM field and a research career in biomedical research. To achieve this goal, we have developed a series of activities for high achieving underrepresented students; activities that are designed to facilitate the development of their talent and professional skills in preparation for excelling in their subsequent Ph.D. or Ph.D./M.D. programs and careers in science areas that have biomedical relevance, while contributing to our understanding of minority health disparities and other key issues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The state-of-the-art in practical efficient and stereocontrolled preparation of glycosidic bonds lags far behind that for peptide and oligonucleotide synthesis and consequently seriously hinders the study of the biology of oligosaccharides and their conjugates. This proposal sets out two develop two new photochemical technologies for glycosidic bond formation, with the emphasis on simplicity and ease of operation such as will be required if synthetic glycans are to be made routinely available to the Glycoscience community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: The vast majority of research on environmental health disparities for air pollution, as well as the health effects of ambient air pollution more generally, has been conducted in cities; similarly, research on the health consequences of exposure to low or high temperatures, especially for heat waves, has almost exclusively focused on the urban environment and urban heat island effects. The people, communities, air pollution sources and mixtures, and adaptive capacities to extreme heat and cold may differ in rural settings, such that current strategies (i.e., federal air quality regulations) may not adequately protect rural populations, although these populations have poorer health outcomes, and limited research suggests that racial health disparities may be even larger in rural compared to urban areas. This project will provide scientific evidence on the disproportionate impacts of air pollution and extreme temperature in the rural south, with a focus on Virginia and West Virginia, including rural racial and ethnic minority groups, with an understanding of the range of rural forms and the intersection of multiple health disparity populations (e.g., race/ethnicity, socio-economic status).

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Humans exhibit many physical differences compared to other species, which are ultimately due to genetic changes in our evolution that altered how our body develops. Our goal is to understand the effects of these changes during development using mouse models. The results of our studies will reveal how genetic variation modified developmental processes in humans, providing novel insight into both conserved and unique mechanisms of human development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal focuses on understanding the mechanisms of pancreatic β-cells senescence and the optimal strategy to therapeutically target them. Cell autonomous and non-cell autonomous mechanisms will be studied in biologically relevant models such as primary human and rodent islets. Achievement of the proposed aims will advance our knowledge of senescence biology in a highly metabolically relevant cell type with important implications for type 2 diabetes mellitus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance: We have identified important roles for the ABC transporter ABCG2 in the most difficult to treat Medulloblastoma, Group 3. Our preliminary studies have identified a novel mechanism based ABCG2 inhibitor. These investigations will demonstrate how this inhibitor disrupts ABCG2 function as well as showing how this strategy can enhance chemotherapeutic efficacy against Group 3 Medulloblastoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is one of the most common and fatal forms of hematological malignancies. Here, we will uncover a novel role of RBM33 in m6A RNA demethylation, and define the important role of RBM33 in AML development and maintenance as well as leukemia stem cell self-renewal. This study will significantly advance our understanding of the complex mechanisms underlying the m6A modification-mediated gene regulation and the critical role of m6A modification in leukemogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Swelling within the first week of large ischemic stroke can exert life-threatening pressure (known as mass effect) on vital brain structures essential to survival and good functional outcome. Accurate prediction of this phenomenon is essential to timely interventions and better outcomes. My research aims to improve prediction of life-threatening mass effect by developing dynamically updating risk prediction models using baseline and longitudinal variables.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Low-income women of childbearing age are at disproportionately high risk for depressive syndromes and, despite the availability of efficacious interventions, often do not receive the treatment they need. The proposed study seeks to expand the reach of an effective, Internet- based maternal depression intervention to low-income mothers by expanding implementation into the Head Start environment. This expansion has the potential to reduce maternal depression, improve related deficits in parenting behavior, and promote healthy child outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The engineering of tumor-specific bacteria is a transformative approach to cancer therapy, since bacteria can be genetically programmed to sense and respond to environments and locally release therapeutics. This proposal seeks to understand and engineer immunotherapeutic probiotic bacteria in the context of triple-negative breast cancer. The objective is to create a targeted therapy that locally delivers checkpoint inhibitors and cytokines to primary tumors and associated metastases, and stimulates systemic antitumor immunity with minimal side effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Measurement of tissue pH and protein/metabolite concentrations using chemical exchange saturation transfer (CEST) magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) has been demonstrated to provide crucial insight into many disease pathologies, including tumors as well as to enable the early assessment of disease response to therapies. However, clinical translation of such CEST-MRI methods has been hindered by the qualitative nature of the image contrast, long image acquisition times, and the complex data processing required. This project proposes to develop, optimize, and translate to the clinic a novel Magnetic Resonance Fingerprinting method that allows for rapid and quantitative pH and protein/metabolite imaging and evaluate its potential for predicting response to stereotactic radiosurgery and differentiating progression versus treatment-related changes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Alzheimer’s disease or dementia is one of the fastest growing cognitive disorders and is expected to affect nearly 14 million Americans by 2060. The disorder is preceded by a high-risk state known as mild cognitive impairment (MCI), which represents a viable target for interventions to prevent or slow down conversion to a full disease state. We are proposing to test the utility of a novel, computer-based brain training program to improve working memory in individuals with amnestic mild cognitive impairment, which, if successful could have significant personal, societal, and economic impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The effectiveness of lung cancer targeted therapies is limited by the development of acquired drug resistance which eventually renders the treatments ineffective. This project seeks to identify the biological mechanisms that drive early tumor evolution in lung cancer patients treated with EGFR and ALK targeted therapies and determine if altering these processes may prevent or delay the subsequent development of drug resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ketogenic diets are being investigated in the treatment of Alzheimer’s disease, but their mechanism of action is unknown. Given that spread of the tangle-forming protein tau among nerve cells is a key pathological event in Alzheimer’s disease, this project aims to understand how the ketone body β-hydroxybutyrate reduces tau spread in the brain. Successful execution of the proposed research will provide the mechanistic basis for prevention and treatment of Alzheimer’s disease and related dementia through improved ketone-based therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative While KRAS has long been considered an “undruggable” target, novel covalent inhibitors selective for KRASG12C have entered the clinic, offering the unprecedented opportunity to target KRAS directly. However, early clinical data suggest that adaptive feedback and acquired resistance are major limitations of clinical benefit, especially in CRC patients. Here, we propose to define the key mechanisms of resistance to KRAS inhibition in CRC and devise therapeutic strategies to overcome resistance leveraging a unique collection of patient-derived models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immune cell therapy with chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cells has been shown to cure some patients with leukemia and lymphoma, but the broad application of this therapy has been limited due to the need to engineer T-cells collected from the patient who will receive the therapy. We propose to test the efficacy of an alternative type of T-cell that is mobilized to the blood with exercise and can be safely given to a wider range of patients, potentially serving as an “off the Shelf” CAR T-cell product. We expect to identify how these cells are mobilized with exercise and ascertain the biological pathways that make them better equipped to kill cancer cells so that they can be utilized in a future clinical trial to treat patients with leukemia and lymphoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: A fundamental question in immunology lies in understanding how the immune system can mount robust protective responses to foreign pathogens, while restricting collateral damage to endogenous tissues. Here, we will define the role of Foxp3-expressing regulatory T cells in coordinating this process, and elucidate the mechanisms by which Treg cells are able to suppress the activation of conventional T cells reactive to the same antigenic complex. In all, our work is expected to providing key insight into how the immune system prevents autoimmunity during pathogen infection, which has direct implications for the understanding of autoimmune disorders and inflammatory syndromes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE:  Haploidentical transplantation, where donors are matched at half of the HLA loci is a lifesaving alternative for patients without a suitable donor, and who can only be cured by a hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. Despite significant improvements, this curative treatment is still limited by increased rejection, often requiring high-dose immunosuppression to sustain donor grafts. This proposal seeks to illuminate the mechanisms by which the innate immune system recognizes haploidentical cells as foreign, with the ultimate goal to generate novel therapies that will enhance the efficiency of allogeneic transplantation.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Experiencing child maltreatment is associated with poor physical, mental, social, and economic outcomes, which are often exacerbated by young people’s difficulties in sharing their experiences and accessing appropriate, supportive resources. This project will build the evidence base for interventions that reach maltreated young people through their preferred approaches, support them through their help-seeking efforts, and connect them with appropriate resources. Ultimately, this work may help young people develop resilience and avoid the harmful short- and long-term consequences of child maltreatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inactivity (currently ineligible for transplant) on the kidney transplant (KT) waitlist occurs in 44% of those awaiting KT, disproportionally affecting older adults and incurring greater risk of death and poor KT surgical complications in addition to the high symptom burden (pain, disability and depressive symptoms) already experienced by this population. The purpose of this study is to adapt and pilot test the patient-directed in the home, team-based (nurse, occupational therapist, handy worker) Community Aging in Place- Advancing Better Living for Elders (CAPABLE) intervention to decrease barriers like symptom burden and low health literacy and patient activation in order to lessen time inactive on the KT waitlist. The novel adaptation of CAPABLE to this highly vulnerable population may result in more equitable KT allocation and better patient outcomes while potentially saving money, all of which will be further explored in the resulting R01 application.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Disruption and dysfunction of the circadian and metabolic systems, each increasingly prevalent in the modern world, are commonly associated despite an incomplete understanding of the mechanisms by which the two systems interact. Because the manipulation of the circadian system is notably tractable and safe as a target for disease prevention and intervention, this proposal aims to better characterize the ways in which the circadian and metabolic systems influence one another, how light exposure and feeding activity affect their temporal relationship, and how their relative timing is established. The increased understanding of the circadian- metabolic relationship will improve the ability of clinicians to intervene in the development of metabolic disorders using safe and effective changes to light exposure and diet.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Parents, pediatricians, and clinicians are concerned when children begin to talk late, a condition that affects 15% to 20% of children. Yet, little is known about bilingual late-talkers, their ability to learn information in both languages, and persistence vs. resolution of their language delay. This project examines how Spanish-English bilingual toddlers with typical language, bilingual late-talker, and bilingual children with Developmental Language Disorder (DLD) learn novel words in English and Spanish and what conditions can best facilitate their learning, with a particular interest in identifying risk and protective factors in bilingual late-talkers’ language outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Inappropriate blood coagulation during serious infection leads to the formation of blood clots that contribute to, pulmonary embolism and heart attack, leading to human suffering and death. This proposal seeks to understand how certain viral and bacterial infections converge on a pathway of programmed cell death called pyroptosis that leads to activation of blood clotting. Our data identify an enzyme in lipid metabolism central to this process that may be a new drug target to prevent inappropriate clotting during infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Follicular lymphoma comprises a substantial fraction new lymphoma diagnoses in the US and is essentially considered incurable at advanced stages. This project will develop an approach to target therapeutic drugs to lymph nodes, tissues where lymphoma tumors form and adaptive immune responses are regulated, in order to improve drug bioactivity and immunotherapeutic benefit while minimizing potential toxicities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative As the Canadian Collaborating Clinical Trial Network, the Canadian Cancer Trials Group (CCTG) enhances NCTN's capacity to conduct innovative and potentially practice-changing trials. CCTG's scientific and regulatory expertise and national network of Canadian researchers contributes strategic and operational expertise, leverages Canadian infrastructure and resources to develop new trial proposals, increases the pool of potential trial participants for precision medicine, rare cancer and large definitive trials, and ensures efficient and effective oversight of NCTN trial conduct in Canada. The single most important benefit to public health realized is the improvement in the quantity and quality of survival of patients with cancer. By facilitating the conduct of trials that examine questions developed and driven by clinicians and that take advantage of emerging science and new cancer therapies, patients will have earlier access to new treatments, and results will be translated into practice, policy and improved cancer outcomes.

Anne-Catrin Uhlemann and Magdalena Sobieszczyk, principal investigators). The goal of this proposal is to train postdoctoral fellows with MD or MD-PhD degrees in state-of-the-art infectious disease research technologies and information handling. This interdisciplinary program will provide trainees with the necessary skillset to become leaders in the field of Infectious Diseases and thereby be in position to meet the infectious disease threats of the future and protect the public health.
