IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A prominent alteration in the uterine environment has recently been identified as a prevalent cause of age-related reproductive decline independent of blastocyst aneuploidy. This problem is likely due to a blunted progesterone (P4) responsiveness of the aging uterus, via its cognate nuclear receptor PGR. The goal of this proposal is to investigate the molecular mechanisms that underlie the age-associated uterine adaptability to pregnancy using physiological and genetic aging mouse models at single cell resolution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The discovery of the first tau mutation (A152T) to influence risk for Alzheimer’s disease now provides a major opportunity to finally shed new light on the toxic role of tau in this disease. Our exciting data in a new animal model we have developed is already providing several clues, which all seem to be pointing towards an abnormal form of tau that is invisible by some classic markers of disease, yet a major driver of toxicity. The studies outlined in our proposal will further study how the A152T mutation changes tau to increase this abnormal form, which could identify new strategies to target this toxic species and stop disease progression.

PHR: Adipose tissue contains a network of immune cells that contribute to the metabolic changes associated with obesity and diabetes. The goal of this study is to expand our understanding of the communication pathways between several key immune cells known to reside in adipose tissue. Completing our study can reveal novel mechanisms by which adipose tissue inflammation is generated and can be suppressed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Small molecules that modulate endocannabinoid (eCB) signaling in brain represent promising therapeutics for the treatment of neurological diseases, including drug addiction. Here we will study how the two eCB-hydrolyzing enzymes, α/β hydrolase domain-contain 6 (ABHD6) and monoacylglycerol lipase (MAGL), differentially control the stimulated production of 2-arachidonoyl glycerol (2-AG, a major eCB in brain), and its ensuing activity at cannabinoid 1 receptors (CB1R) using a genetically encoded biosensor (GRABeCB2.0) that detects real-time changes in 2-AG levels. This research will provide a comprehensive understanding of the mechanistic differences by which ABHD6 and MAGL control 2-AG-CB1R signaling in brain, a body of work that will help the development of novel therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Peripheral artery disease (PAD) affects millions of people around the world, causing decreased mobility, non- healing wounds, gangrene and amputations. Patients with chronic kidney disease have a higher risk for PAD and its complications, but relatively little is known about what treatments are effective in this population. Our project aims to narrow some of these knowledge gaps to improve PAD treatment practices for patients with chronic kidney disease.

PHR: Project Narrative This project is relevant to public health because it will produce a diverse group of rigorously trained, motivated undergraduate students who will be competitive for highly selective doctoral programs and, as biomedical researchers, contribute to the quality and diversity of the scientific workforce. These talented University of the Virgin Islands students will be future leaders in addressing the health research needs of the Nation. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The molecular mechanisms via which cells measure available nutrients and, in response, make critical decisions toward their growth, proliferation and differentiation remain largely unknown. Building on our recent discoveries, the current proposal aims to determine how the mTORC1 kinase, a nutrient-responsive master growth regulator implicated in numerous human diseases, senses cholesterol to regulate organelle homeostasis and communication in cellular space and time. The resulting discoveries will illuminate fundamental rules of metabolic organization, and will point to new strategies to inhibit mTORC1 signaling and boost lysosomal catabolic functions in disease settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. This proposal seeks to evaluate the risks and benefits of deprescribing versus continuing bisphosphonates in older nursing home residents with Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) and AD-Related Dementias (AD/ADRD). This study will evaluate the qualitative perceptions of providers and caregivers, clinical outcomes, and healthcare- related costs to determine whether deprescribing bisphosphonates is a safe and reasonable strategy to reduce the medication burden for certain individuals in this population. The results from this study will contribute to the development of recommendations for the management of fracture prevention in older nursing home residents with AD/ADRD, a population not addressed in current guidelines

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Every year, 0.4-1.9% of individuals with mitral valve prolapse (MVP) will develop sudden cardiac death or arrest. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hepatic stellate cell plasticity and maladaptive fibrogenic memory in chronic liver disease Liver fibrosis associated with chronic liver injury is a strong predictor of patient mortality thus an ideal therapeutic target for chronic liver disease patients. With acute injury, hepatic stellate cells activate to repair tissue damage and then return to quiescence, but with repeated injury, these cells hyperactivate to produce exuberant extracellular matrix that make up liver fibrosis. In this proposal, we will investigate the molecular changes that take place in hepatic stellate cells that drive their maladaptive behavior switch with repeated injury, which may shed light on novel antifibrotic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Spatially Responsive Mass Vaccination Campaigns for Urban Rabies NARRATIVE Mass vaccination campaigns can prevent and control epidemics of infectious diseases among humans and animals. However, many campaigns leave spatial 'pockets' of under-vaccinated individuals. In this study, we propose to use a mass canine rabies vaccination campaign to field test computational approaches to increase vaccination equity and coverage, and use implementation science to assess the acceptability, scalability, and transferability of our new vaccination strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Opioid use disorders (OUDs) are complex psychiatric conditions in which use of opioids followed by periods of withdrawal/abstinence are thought to engender both tolerance and physical dependence, leading to excessive opioid consumption despite aversive consequences (loss of job/family/home). The estimate of the total impact of the opioid crisis to society reaches over $500 billion, representing approximately 2.8% of the US gross domestic product. The aim of this proposal is to discover how opioids change neuronal circuits, and how these changes may affect behavior, and the data collected from these studies will hopefully allow us to ascertain new targets for behavioral and pharmacotherapy (medicine) treatments to alleviate OUDs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE DNA damage induces expression of non-pituitary colon GH, which, in turn, attenuates DNA repair pathways, yet accumulated epithelial DNA damage may enable an aging milieu favoring tissue degeneration, cancer, and metabolic dysfunction. We will use induced pluripotent stem-cell derived human colon organoids, normal human colon cells, and genetically altered mouse models to test the hypothesis that induction of local epithelial GH suppresses DNA damage response, reinforcing DNA damage. We propose a novel hypothesis whereby local epithelial non-pituitary GH is an adverse determinant for DNA damage accumulation and acts as an epithelial aging marker.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recently, we reported our discovery of mitochondria-rich extracellular vesicles (M-EVs), which are produced by the iPSC-derived cardiomyocytes (iCMs). We identified functional mitochondria and cluster of enriched proteins associated with mitochondrial biogenesis (PC) in the M-EVs. These M-EVs and their payload may provide an effective and novel therapeutic to restore the bioenergetic imbalance of the injured myocardium in heart failure patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tau self-assembly into fibrils that form cellular inclusions is foundational to the pathology of Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) and other tauopathies such as Cortico Basal Degeneration (CBD). However, the factors that initiate the folding and aggregation of tau are unknown. A team of cell biologist, physical chemist and a theoretical biophysicist propose to work together to determine the pathway from normal tau to pathological tau, to replicate tauopathy disease-phenotypic tau fibrils and to discover the cellular factors that initiate the pathological pathway of tau misfolding, aggregation and propagation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: BUCK INSTITUTE FOR RESEARCH ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recent identification of a series of compounds which act to induce neuronal TFEB, the master transcriptional regulator of lysosomal autophagy, lead us to the surprising discovery that our lead compound `C1' acts as a “reverse agonist” of the nuclear hormone receptor DAF-12/FXR. Although FXR is best known for its ability to act in the liver and gut to maintain lipid homeostasis, it has recently been shown to be present in brain neurons although its role in here is currently unexplored. In this current application, we propose to test the hypothesis that neuronal FXR mechanistically acts to modulate levels of TFEB-mediated autophagy and as such constitutes a novel target for the treatment of age-related neurodegenerative diseases including Alzheimer's disease (AD).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Continuous renal replacement therapy is the preferred dialysis treatment for critically ill patients with acute kidney injury, yet mortality is high. Presently, there are no accurate approaches for predicting survival or kidney recovery in these patients. We propose to deliver innovative deep learning approaches to predict these outcomes at actionable timepoints, and identify patient sub-phenotypes for model interpretation and clinical utility testing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative-Relevance to Public Health Cancer arises as a result of the accumulation of genetic alterations. We propose to develop a novel strategy of combining nanobomb-mediated RNA interference that precisely targets the genomic defects in triple negative breast cancer (TNBC) with clinically used chemotherapy drug for combating the therapeutic resistance of TNBC, and to understand the therapeutic and resistant mechanisms. This project will have a significant impact on improving cancer treatment to reduce the mortality of patients with cancer in general and TNBC in particular.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative We have discovered all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA), a metabolite of Vitamin A and master gene-switch that controls many genes that are important to heart function, declines in patients with one type of human heart failure (HF) as well as an animal model. We want to understand three things about ATRA and HF: 1. What enzymes metabolize Vitamin A to ATRA in heart muscle cells? 2. How does low ATRA alter heart function? 3. How pervasive is low ATRA across different types HF?

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Our studies will investigate the cellular mechanisms by which APP overexpression observed in trisomy of chromosome 21 (Ts21) that causes Down Syndrome (DS) leads to increased transmission of tauopathy and neurodegeneration. To study tau transmission and its impact on neuronal circuitry, we will use a novel time lapse, imaging platform, four-dimensional robotic microscopy (4DRM) to longitudinally track functional properties of individual neurons in 4D in human brain organoids, primary human brain slices, and live zebrafish. With 4DRM, we will define how APP overexpression leads to hyperexcitability of neurons, to contribute to an increased rate of transmission of tau pathology, which will lead to better strategies to block the spread of neuropathology to slow the progression of early onset dementia found in DS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ABCD Study consortium uses multimodal brain imaging, cognitive and clinical assessments, bioassays, mobile monitoring, and careful assessment of substance use, environment, psychopathological symptoms, and social functioning in 11,878 9-10 year-olds to be followed over 10 years, to determine the effects of substance use on adolescent brain and cognitive development. This ABCD Research Project Site will follow and assess participants enrolled in the study. These data will be shared with the scientific community to address a comprehensive range of questions concerning youth development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Over 40% of adults are obese in the US. Pharmaceutical options for treating obesity have been very limited and not efficacious. Leveraging comprehensive genetic resources for adiposity, psychiatric traits and addictive risk behaviors and rich phenome information across large-scale biobanks, we propose to integrate multi-layers of omics with innovative analytic methodologies to identify novel obesity drug targets that are both efficacious and safe to fill in the critical unmet need of pharmaceutical therapy of obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity is associated with a higher risk of developing pancreatic cancer and worse disease prognosis. Although elevated levels of insulin and insulin-like growth factors contribute to tumor progression and chemotherapeutic resistance, the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. The metabolic enzyme ATP- citrate lyase (ACLY) is activated in response to insulin signaling and regulates histone acetylation levels in cancer cells, and the proposed study will test the hypothesis that metabolic alterations mediate epigenetic and transcriptional changes to promote tumor progression and may represent targetable vulnerabilities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding how cells store and mobilize lipids is an urgent scientific and therapeutic goal. This project addresses the molecular and biophysical mechanisms by which the protein ABHD5 regulates the mobilization and storage of lipids in cells. Understanding how ABHD5 can be targeted by synthetic compounds could lead to new therapies for diabetes, obesity, and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project investigates cellular and molecular mechanisms of fibrolamellar hepatocellular carcinoma (FLC). The project is translational and examines if the inhibition of b-catenin in patient-derived FLC spheroid cells and animal models of FLC will repress tumor development. The project will generate a background for clinical trials with FLC patients which will be based on the inhibition of the b-catenin.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There has been great interest in advancing HDL-targeted therapies to prevent and manage atherosclerosis. Over the past several years, we have developed a novel class of HDL modulators based on amphiphilic cyclic D,L-a-peptides, which reduce dyslipidemia and prevent the development of atherosclerosis in vivo. Building on these exciting findings, this project seeks to advance such molecular entities as mechanistically novel therapeutic agents for treating atherosclerosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acetaminophen (APAP) overdose is the foremost cause of acute liver failure (ALF) in the United States and has very limited treatment options. Although, HGF receptor (MET) and EGF receptor (EGFR) are conventionally known to have similar roles in liver regeneration after partial hepatectomy, surprisingly our studies indicate that they have contrasting roles in the clinically- relevant model of APAP-induced ALF. Based on our unexpected findings, we will comprehensively investigate the uncharted roles of EGFR and MET in liver injury and the associated compensatory regeneration in APAP-induced ALF model, understand the underlying mechanisms and further, explore the clinical relevance to pave the way for novel therapeutics for ALF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Mississippi is among the leaders in health disparities in cardiovascular diseases that disproportionately affect individuals from disadvantaged and underrepresented racial and ethnic populations. At the same time, Mississippi lags in the development of a robust pipeline of biomedical researchers that can address these important issues. This grant proposes to continue a successful summer research training and mentoring program in cardiovascular research for undergraduate students from disadvantaged and underrepresented racial and ethnic populations in Mississippi.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Parenting stress is a well-documented barrier to youth engagement in community-based substance use treatment. The proposed K23 project aims to develop and evaluate a mobile health parenting stress intervention for caregivers of justice-involved youth, a population with high rates of substance use and low rates of treatment engagement. The proposed research will expand the investigator's capacities as an independent health services investigator with expertise in: 1) substance use services research; 2) participatory methods; and 3) mHealth methodology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Understanding and being able to manipulate metalloenzyme biochemistry has applications for many aspects of human health and biotechnology (e.g. the production of novel antibiotics and anticancer drugs, sustainable biofuel production, and environmental toxin remediation). With both antibiotic resistance and climate change emerging as major health concerns, the proposed studies are important and timely, and the efforts will result in insights necessary to combat these frontier challenges.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study will establish the feasibility, acceptability, and credibility of a novel, web-delivered mind-body program, "Toolkit for REsilient Life bEyond pain and Substance use-TIRELESS," aimed at adapting to pain and disability among patients with painful non traumatic upper extremity conditions who have co morbid substance use. This sub-group of patients with painful nontraumatic upper extremity conditions experience greater levels of pain and disability, opioid misuse, and medical care utilization, and poor outcomes after medical treatments. A brief, tailored mind-body program delivered to this high-risk population has the potential to decrease risky substance use, improve adaptation to pain and disability, and, in turn, reduce the utilization of orthopedic care services and costs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The underlying causes of low back pain are an enigma despite the huge socio-economic burden of this debilitating disorder, with current surgical interventions proving ineffective and highly invasive. The goal of this proposal is to establish the effects of non-viral delivery of developmental transcription factors using engineered extracellular vesicles to reprogram native diseased IVD cells from painful intervertebral discs in situ to a healthy biosynthetically active anti-nerve/vascular phenotype using clinically relevant animal models of back pain. Non- viral gene delivery with engineered extracellular vesicles is a novel concept for the treatment of discogenic back pain and there is a critical need to develop non-addictive treatments that target both the underlying cause of disease as well as pain to improve human health and quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The computational principles and neural architecture supporting complex and naturalistic navigation are unknown. In the current project I will elucidate these mechanisms by performing large-scale neurophysiology and introducing ambiguities during path integration in virtual reality; rodents will be required parse optic flow signals into self- and externally-generated components, and will be submitted to multisensory illusions altering their subjective self-location. The knowledge gained from this proposal will inform our understanding of the mechanism underlying disorders of inference, such as Autism and Schizophrenia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will investigate the neural representation of sequence monitoring, a process that is necessary for daily life. Currently, the neural underpinnings of sequence monitoring remain unknown. A systematic explication of the neural circuitry underlying structured sequence viewing could lead to new treatments for diseases and disorders where sequential behaviors are disrupted, such as obsessive-compulsive disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Trauma and/or inflammation as mechanisms cannot fully account for the different HIV transmission rates in the presence of specific genital microbes. We have recently shown that HIV glycan shield double-up as an attachment factor via a novel ‘non-electrostatic and specific’ oligomannose (oligoman)-based interaction, offering a general mechanism to account for the opposite HIV transmission phenotypes seen in the presence of lactobacillus vs sexual transmission infection bacteria, such as Neisseria gonorrhoeae. This project will determine whether this manipulatable oligoman-based interaction has: (i) helped trapped HIV onto lactobacillus to reduce HIV transmission; and (ii) allowed HIV to hijack Neisseria gonorrhoeae to gain access into the host.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is focused on elucidating the psychosocial and biological pathways through which structural racism and discrimination adversely affect chronic musculoskeletal pain and associated disability in older Black or African American adults. Chronic musculoskeletal disorders are the leading cause of pain and disability worldwide, and older Black adults bear a disproportionate burden of musculoskeletal pain. Therefore, this work has the potential to inform broadly applicable strategies for reducing health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this proposal is to complete pharmacology studies and generate the requisite preclinical data package and regulatory dossiers to support the clinical development of a novel neuroprotective peptide as a treatment for moderate to severe traumatic brain injury. Our neuroprotective peptide specifically targets injured brain and reduces the secondary injury after the primary impact. This project addresses an underserved medical area, where there is a pressing need for new therapeutic advances.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: This proposal evaluates the role of Fcγ receptors not only in CARD9-CLR signaling but also in antibody-mediated uptake and killing of Pneumocystis by macrophages. Specifically, this proposal will evaluate the combined activities of both innate (CLR-CARD9 axis) and adaptive immunity components through their common reliance on the shared Fcγ receptors and how activation of host cells through these pathways provide additive benefits crucial for proper host immunity. We will further use these observations to develop novel therapeutic approaches targeting these pathways for PCP, for those who are refractory or fail standard antibiotic therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Atherosclerosis, a chronic inflammatory arterial disease, builds plaques in the inner part of arterial wall, leading to vessel lumen narrowing and blood clotting, consequently to two life-threatening conditions, heart attack and stroke. Minority patients exhibit an increased prevalence of advanced atherosclerotic arterial disease, and they need cellular therapy with blood vessel-specialized stem cells for repair and regeneration of their diseased arterial wall. This project will employ an innovative technology to generate nanoparticle- targeted stem cells to repair the arterial wall with advanced atherosclerosis or atheroma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Over 7 million Americans currently suffer from a neurodegenerative disease (NDD). Although age is the greatest known risk factor for the onset of NDDs, we urgently need to understand the mechanisms by which treatable risk factors contribute to disease, including sleep and circadian clock disruption. In this proposal, we will investigate the likely bidirectional relationship between circadian desynchronization and NDD progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: The pathologic accumulation of misfolded α-synuclein (α-syn) in neurons leads to neurodegeneration and cognitive dysfunction and dementia in a family of disorders designated α-synucleinopathies, which includes Dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB) and Parkinson’s disease (PD) dementia (PDD). The project objectives are to understand the actions of Parthanatos Associated AIF (apoptosis-inducing factor) Nuclease (PAAN) also known as MIF in pathologic α-syn induced cognitive dysfunction and determine whether a first in class, MIF nuclease inhibitor is protective in models of pathologic α-syn induced cognitive dysfunction. In addition the role of pathologic α-syn in activating cGas and STING pathway and subsequent inflammasome activation via PAAN/MIF nuclease activity will be explored. These finding could offer innovative therapeutic approaches to treat pathologic α-syn induced cognitive dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Errors in the administration of children’s medication at home disproportionally affects multiple NIH-designated health disparity populations, including low socioeconomic status and minority populations. We are developing a novel smart phone application which will improve medication safety at home through evidence-based digital innovations that target root causes of medication dosing errors. By creating higher quality of care through expanded access to medical information and improved health literacy, we aim to lessen childhood inequities and the impact they have in adulthood.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: The brain is very vulnerable to metabolic problems and synapses, the machinery that mediates the conversion of electrical information into chemical information, are very sensitive to metabolic imbalances. Since neurodegenerative diseases results in improper function of synapses, we hypothesize that these disease states might have at their origin an imbalance between fuel availability and fuel use at the level of individual synapses. The fuel here that matters is a molecule called ATP and our work aims to understand how it is produced at synapses, who consumes it and how in diseases like Parkinson’s and Alzheimer’s this changes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Ankle contracture, or loss of full ankle joint motion, commonly occurs alongside progression of muscle degeneration and weakness in ambulatory children with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). A lack of understanding of the pathophysiology of contracture development has limited the impact of rehabilitation interventions used to prevent contractures and maximize functional ability in DMD. This study will evaluate the potential mechanisms leading to loss of ankle range of motion and the muscle and tendon tissue adaptations associated with ankle contractures in ambulatory children with DMD, which will give rehabilitation professionals the ability to make more evidence-based decisions and provide more targeted interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune, demyelinating, and degenerative disease characterized by lesions in the central nervous system that cause debilitating neurologic dysfunction. This proposed research will investigate a newly described mechanism by which neurons and oligodendrocytes within the central nervous system degenerate in the context of multiple sclerosis. Therefore, this work could establish new disease-modifying therapeutic advancements that halt the disease’s pathology without relying on immunosuppressants that are often temporarily beneficial, nonspecific, and ineffective for patients with progressive multiple sclerosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Individuals with profound anemia, particularly sickle cell anemia (SCA), have a high risk of developing strokes and silent cerebral infarcts; this risk begins in early childhood, with more than 50% affected by 30 years of age. Better understanding stroke mechanisms in anemia should improve stroke risk identification, and lead to better treatments to prevent stroke. This study uses multiple hemodynamic and metabolic brain imaging techniques to understand differences in brain blood flow and oxygen use before versus after anemia treatments, as well as how brain blood flow and oxygen utilization differ in anemic individuals with versus without strokes.

PHR: 1 PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT 2 Maternal mortality rates are three times higher among non-Hispanic Black than White women. SDoH are 3 social, economic, and environmental conditions that have been found to mediate between racial and ethnic 4 health disparities in maternal mortality, yet no standard of care exists for how and when to screen for health- 5 related social needs in pregnancy, let alone address them. In this SBIR, BetterHope LLC (dba Poisera) will 6 develop chatbot technology to identify and address SDoH for half a million Black pregnant women annually to 7 ultimately reduce the inequitable rates of maternal morbidity and mortality. 8

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PEDSnet Scholars: A National Pediatric Learning Health System Embedded Scientist Training and Research Program NARRATIVE Creating integrated learning health systems (LHSs) that improve child health will require a new generation of pediatric scientists with diverse backgrounds who will be embedded in healthcare organizations’ clinical and research operations. We propose to address this need by creating a Pediatric LHS Embedded Scientist Training and Research Center. The Center will be integrated within PEDSnet, a PCORnet Clinical Research Network and a national pediatric LHS with 11 institutional members that provide care for 10% of the nation’s children.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: OVERALL The Learning Health systems training to improve Disability and chronic condition care (LeaHD) center will train embedded scientists to conduct PCOR/CER and dissemination and implementation research that will inform improvements in health system operations and quality of care. LeaHD will train a cadre of learning health systems (LHS) scientists who will be poised to transform the delivery, quality, and outcomes of care for persons with disability and chronic conditions by focusing on rehabilitation and long term services and supports (LTSS). LeaHD will build upon a well-established infrastructure and collaborative relationships between Brown University, University of Pittsburgh, and Boston University, extensive faculty expertise, and established and emerging partnerships with a diverse group of nine health system partners.

PHR: The University of Pittsburgh TraCe MPS Center’s (Pitt-TraCe) qualified, patient-derived, structured, biomimetic liver Microphysiology Systems (MPS) platform will deliver qualified DDTs that will dramatically improve the efficiency and accuracy in liver safety and efficacy for drug development decisions, especially for complex heterogeneous diseases in precision medicine. These commercially available, qualified DDTs will benefit the drug development process for the pharmaceutical industry and FDA regulatory oversight. In addition, the Automated Biomimetic Analytic MPS (ABAMPS) platform employing commercially available materials from can be harnessed to qualify new organ structured, biomimetic MPS in the future.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our LHS STAR NJ program will train future scientists and health professionals in the best ways to evaluate and improve the quality, outcomes, and patient-centeredness of care through educational classes, mentoring, and hands on learning. It makes available to a broad community all of the research knowledge and resources needed to do projects that will improve health and health equity. Our program combines the teaching and research knowhow of Rutgers Biomedical and Health Sciences (7 health professions schools) partnered with a 6 diverse health system partners, insurers, and government agencies.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Learning Health System Scientist Training And Research in New Jersey (LHS STAR NJ)

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Overall Project Narrative The overarching goal of the Massachusetts Institute for Equity-Focused Learning Health System Science (MIELHSS) is to train embedded health system scientists and accelerate the conduct of equity-focused PCOR/CER to improve health system operations, quality, and health outcomes. Our group includes several large academic health systems, FQHCs, community centers, safety net hospitals, PCORnet sites, and the VA; together we care for diverse populations and share a common goal to advance equity-focused learning health system science. Our proposed infrastructure will: 1) create a stimulating environment to develop embedded LHS scientists from diverse backgrounds, 2) build a robust shared data structure that will support and accelerate equity-focused research, and 3) accelerate the collaborative culture change that will be needed to drive meaningful impact in LHS and health equity.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Massachusetts Institute for Equity-Focused Learning Health System Science (MIELHSS)

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Administrative Core Narrative The Administrative Core of the Massachusetts Institute for Equity-focused Learning Health System Science (MIELHSS) coordinates and manages all Institute activities across its Research Education and Research Data Cores. The role of the Administrative Core is to: 1) Provide leadership, direction, and oversight of MIELHSS; 2) Foster internal and external communications and engagement across health systems, community and stakeholder partners, scholars, mentors, projects, and cores to create a broad and sustained culture of integrated E-LHS science; and 3) Advance E-LHS research methods through a methods incubator. We will measure success using metrics such as grant submissions and publications while also by measuring health system engagement in MIELHSS activities and sustained implementation and widespread adoption of equity-focused interventions and health system improvements.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: MIELHSS - Admin Core

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Education Core Narrative The Education Core works with the Administrative and Data Cores, and Heath system and community partners to train embedded health system scientists and accelerate the conduct of equity-focused PCOR/CER to improve health system operations, quality, and health outcomes. Our educational infrastructure will: 1) create a stimulating environment to develop embedded LHS scientists from diverse backgrounds, 2) provide a novel intensive program of embedded research training featuring Human-Centered Design, and 3) provide meaningful experiential mentored learning in diverse settings.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: MIELHSS - Research Education Core

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Research Data Core Narrative The Research Data Core (RDC) for the Massachusetts Institute for Equity-focused Learning Health System Science (MIELHSS) aims to support ongoing equity-focused research for and beyond the scholars by developing common data standards, shared practices, and an infrastructure for conducting distributed data analysis and data sharing across the MIELHSS organizations. We provide ongoing mentorship of MIELHSS scholars, assisting scholars in accessing and interpreting PCORnet, Medicare, Medicaid, and other research datasets, and we work in concert with the Administrative Core on dissemination strategies.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: MIELHSS - Data Core

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Disparities in healthcare quality and outcomes persist and a systematic approach is needed to reorient and restructure healthcare systems to address this urgent problem. The Columbia-Cornell-Einstein EQUIP+ Center for Learning Health System (LHS) Science will provide a novel training and research program that leverages cross-institutional collaborations to develop a diverse cadre of embedded LHS Scientists who are equipped to improve healthcare delivery and outcomes. EQUIP+ Center LHS Scientists will generate and disseminate evidence through this dynamic infrastructure to advance the equity, quality, and safety of healthcare for all.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research project aims to understand the molecular mechanisms leading to the demise of neurons in Alzheimer's disease (AD) brains and identify potential therapeutic targets and biomarkers. By studying select AD pathology-associated proteins and their impact on disease progression, non-amyloid pathways mediated by these proteins, and the biochemical mechanisms by which they regulate assembly of Aβ filaments, this project seeks to inform the development of more effective experimental models and therapeutic and imaging agents for AD. The ultimate goal is to enhance public health by improving our fundamental knowledge of AD pathogenesis and finding new ways to lengthen life, reduce illness, and minimize disability caused by this devastating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over 38 million people worldwide suffer from atrial fibrillation, but access to heart rhythm drugs is restricted by the required three-day hospitalization to start these oral medications due to rare, dangerous rhythm side effects. The objective of this SBIR is to expand access to these life-saving medications, which are currently underprescribed to minority and rural populations due to the required hospitalization. The proposed research will advance technology created by SafeBeat Rx to allow atrial fibrillation patients to start medications safely at home via automated mobile heart rhythm analysis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Asthma is a disease of the airways that is growing in prevalence and represents a major public health burden. In the majority of people with asthma, IgE antibodies play a role in triggering allergic immune responses in the lung that contribute to disease pathogenesis. In this project, we will study how IgE responses to aeroallergens are initially generated, resulting in allergic sensitization.

PHR: Overall Project Narrative: Southwest Safety Net Embedded Scientist Training and Research (SSNE-STaR) Center Arizona State University College of Health Solutions (ASU CHS) and Valleywise Health (VH) System will create the Southwest Safety Net Embedded Scientist Training and Research (SSNE-STaR) Center. Our goal is to help improve the health equity of historically disadvantaged populations, with a strong commitment to addressing the needs of Native American, Hispanic, homeless, and other underserved populations. We will support the scientific training and professional development of Scholars embedded across Arizona Safety Net Organizations (SNOs) to conduct comparative effectiveness and patient-centered outcome research (CER/PCOR) and gain proficiency in rapid-cycle implementation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although hundreds of genes have been associated with coronary artery disease (CAD) and insulin resistance related metabolic traits, the lack of mechanisms linking CAD to insulin resistance has hampered development of new therapies. This study will determine the role of the gene PRDM16 (PR domain containing 16), which is at the intersection of both CAD and insulin resistance, on smooth muscle cell function and atherosclerosis using novel conditional knockout mouse models in conjunction with cutting edge genomic sequencing approaches. By determining the role of PRDM16 in smooth muscle cell function and atherosclerosis, this work will not only determine the mechanistic connection between PRDM16 and CAD but will also identify novel mechanistic connections between CAD and insulin resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Fibroblasts are cells that maintain the structural framework of most tissues, and many studies show that they can also promote and suppress tissue inflammation. This project will study how fibroblasts in rheumatoid arthritis develop the ability to suppress joint inflammation and enable joint healing when they are activated by specific signals. Our findings could aid in devising new therapies for rheumatoid arthritis and many other inflammatory diseases involving fibroblasts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Ninety percent of cancer related deaths are due to metastatic dissemination to distal organs, thus it is of great interest to study molecular mechanisms that contribute to metastases. Of interest, mitochondria have emerged as important organelles in tumorigenesis and metastasis. This project seeks to gain a mechanistic understanding of a novel mitochondrial signaling pathway that positively influences tumor cell invasion and metastasis, which would serve as the basis for new therapeutics targeting metastatic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is the improvement of cancer therapy by employing nanoparticles as image contrast and radiation therapy amplifying agents. The nanoparticles are visible in magnetic resonance imaging and provide a boost of extra energy to their immediate surroundings during therapeutic irradiation. The preferential killing of cancer cells in the tumor will lead greater tumor shrinkage and longer overall survival relative to radiation treatment alone.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Approximately two-thirds of patients diagnosed with cancer in the United States will be cured of their disease using a combination of surgery, radiation and chemotherapy, but progress towards enhanced survival in adults with advanced and metastatic disease has been painfully slow, even in the era of targeted therapies, and new, more effective therapies are desperately needed. TYRO3 is a member of the TAM-family of receptor tyrosine kinases that is aberrantly expressed, promotes tumor cell survival and/or proliferation, and has been associated with poor prognosis in numerous human cancers, including melanoma, colorectal carcinomas, and lymphoma. Our preliminary data also suggest that agents targeting TYRO3 may be particularly useful for immuno-oncology applications, therefore, the studies described here aim to develop potent and selective TYRO3 inhibitors suitable for clinical application and as such, may have a direct impact on outcomes and/or quality of life for patients with advanced cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project investigates alpha-synuclein fibril structures and how various factors contribute to fibril stability and aggregation, leading to diseased fibril states that are centrally implicated within several neurodegenerative diseases (Parkinson disease, Lewy body dementia, multiple system atrophy) affecting millions of people each year. Fibril structures will support efforts in the broader research community to develop diagnostic tools and eventual therapies for these neurodegenerative diseases. This proposed study aims to determine the structure of in vivo fibrils amplified from patient tissue, to measure the molecular dynamics and quaternary structures, and to detect the site-specific binding of imaging ligands with atomistic detail.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The azetidine-containing metabolites azetidomonamide A, azetidopyridone, and diazetidomonapyridone have attracted recent interest due to their significance in biofilm and pigment production of the pathogenic bacterium Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Biological studies to understand the metabolites’ role in these bacterial quorum- sensing pathways have been hindered because the molecules are difficult to synthesize in significant quantities; this proposal seeks to establish their first chemical total syntheses. This project is relevant to the NIH’s mission because 1) in the short-term, it will expand current fundamental understanding in the synthesis of bioactive natural products, and 2) in the long-term, findings derived from biological studies of these metabolites could potentially lead to new anti-virulence treatments for those infected with P. aeruginosa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative c-Myc overexpressing large B-cell lymphoma (LBCL) have a significantly worse prognosis compared to the c- Myc-negative counterpart. Based on our preliminary data, we hypothesize that TBL1 serves as a critical modulator of c-Myc turnover and represents a novel and attractive candidate for targeted therapy for patients with c-Myc overexpressing LBCL. At completion of this project, we will have a better understanding of the TBL1-modulated mechanism through which c-Myc turnover is regulated, will have developed a novel therapeutic strategy (tegavivint) to treat this incurable disease, and will have begun to characterize resistance mechanisms to tegavivint.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Modern biological methods can measure the expression of every gene at once, and scientists often use them ask how levels of different genes are changed in response to mutations, diseases, or other perturbations. Existing methods zoom in on individual genes with large expression changes, potentially missing small shifts across many or even all genes. We propose a new method to capture the overall, transcriptome-wide impact of a perturbation on gene expression, which has applicability to understanding both basic biology and diverse disease states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Enteric synucleinopathy is a major cause of gastrointestinal dysfunction and is believed to be the precursor of CNS synucleinopathies like Parkinson’s Disease (PD) and PD-Dementia. The immune system has been increasingly implicated in various stages of synucleinopathies and represents a promising therapeutic target in general. This study will investigate the role of gut-resident immune cells in enteric synucleinopathy to identify molecular mechanisms underpinning neuro-immune interactions that may influence disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Childhood cancer survivors treated with anthracycline chemotherapy or chest-directed radiation are at risk for cardiomyopathy. This study aims to validate advanced artificial intelligence methods to accurately identify survivors at high risk for cardiomyopathy using low-cost, accessible electrocardiography data and to evaluate the feasibility of using smartwatches for this purpose. Such artificial intelligence tools may facilitate early detection of high risk survivors who may benefit from advanced cardiac imaging and interventions to preserve cardiac function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE NCI-sponsored clinical trials are essential to improve the prevention, detection, and treatment of cancer. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Secretory protein trafficking enables newly synthesized proteins to be transported to the cell surface. Faulty trafficking is implicated in developmental defects in brain development; however, how defective trafficking causes abnormal brain development is unknown. This work aims to elucidate how inefficient protein trafficking leads to brain birth defects and abnormal neuronal differentiation using rare disease patient-derived cell models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance: The neurotensin receptor subtype 1 (NTSR1) is expressed in a large segment of colorectal cancers. By incorporating irreversible inhibitors into NTSR1-targeted agents, we seek to develop a targeted radionuclide therapeutic that can form high-molecular-weight intracellular adducts. By this approach, our developed therapeutic agents will demonstrate significantly higher radiation dose delivery and therapeutic efficacy for colorectal cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: LOUISIANA STATE UNIV A&M COL BATON ROUGE
PHR: Narrative: The project involves designing a grafted peptide molecule from a plant-based peptide, which can be used to modulate protein-protein interactions of EGFR proteins that are overexpressed or mutated in lung cancer. The research outcomes from this project will help in developing therapeutic grafted peptides that could have an impact on lung cancer that becomes resistant to treatment. These grafted peptides will form the basis of a new therapeutic approach to NSCLC that could improve the survival rate of lung cancer patients.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children are often prescribed opioid analgesic medications to use at home following surgical procedures. This study evaluates the complex interaction between biological, psychological, and social influences which may drive opioid use in children following surgery. With a specific focus on parents as the gatekeeper for children’s medication use, data gathered will help inform the development of preoperative interventions and predictive models to optimize opioid use for pediatric postsurgical pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma (ICC) is a highly lethal form of liver cancer due to late diagnosis and limited therapeutic options. Through unbiased high-throughput drug screens we have identified a striking therapeutic vulnerability of ICC tumors harboring mutations in the isocitrate dehydrogenase (IDH), which make up the most common genetic subset. Using this discovery, this proposal aims to elucidate the specific molecular pathways driving the growth and survival of these tumors in order to better understand their unique biology and develop more effective therapeutic options for this disease.

PHR: Project Narrative This training program for 8 PhD students and 4 postdoctoral fellows in Molecular and Cellular Basis of Infectious Diseases (MCBID) is highly relevant to national interests in the areas of emerging infectious diseases. Training is focused on the molecular aspects of pathogen biology, disease pathogenesis, vectors of pathogen transmission and disease ecology. Overall emphasis is on rigorous scientific methods and practice with broad interdisciplinary perspectives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our proposal investigates molecular mechanisms through which cells adhere to and migrate in/on hyaluronic acid (HA)-based extracellular matrices, with a focus on the membrane receptor CD44. In addition to developing fundamental new insight into HA/CD44-based adhesion, we will apply a variety of model systems to investigate how aberrant HA/CD44 adhesion contributes to the progression of malignant brain tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Narrative The single molecule sensitivity of solid-state nanopores make them ideal candidates for the detection of low abundance protein biomarkers in portable device formats. To realize this potential requires techniques for the concentration of protein biomarkers and lossless transfer to nanopores for single molecule counting. This project will combine advances in nanopore sensor design with precision microﬂuidics and on-chip biomarker pre-concentration to achieve low- abundance biomarker detection in a compact, purely electrical, device. The project will validate our developments through comparisons to gold standard quantiﬁcation of a cytokine panel in urine and a traumatic brain injury panel in blood.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JOHN D DINGELL VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Sensory hair cell synapses are critical for acoustic signal conduction from sensory hair cells to auditory neurons, but knowledge of hair cell synapse regeneration is very limited. This proposal will use both in vitro and in vivo animal models to investigate the molecular mechanisms critical for stem cell-derived neurons to reinnervate sensory hair cells. Completion of this project will significantly advance knowledge of hair cell synapse regeneration, which will potentially open new avenues to develop stem cell-based hair cell reinnervation approaches for Veteran and civilian hearing loss patients.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: The VA has had considerable success in reducing the number of homeless Veterans through permanent supportive housing programs. Permanent housing is necessary, however, but not sufficient for successful social integration. Poor social integration is associated with a variety of adverse mental and physical health outcomes. Notably, Black Veterans are overrepresented among homeless Veterans yet remain understudied in psychological science. A better understanding of potential racial differences in risk and protective mechanisms of social integration is crucial for the development of culturally responsive rehabilitative interventions for recently housed Veterans. The proposed study aims to examine the contributions of stress, inflammation, and resilience to social integration in recently housed Black and White Veterans. Knowledge gained can inform innovative race-conscious treatments that mitigate the effects of stress and enhance resilience to improve social integration in recently housed Veterans.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: This work will benefit both Veterans and civilians who have osteoarthritis, by developing a novel approach to reduce harmful inflammation in the joint after an injury, and prevent the onset of post-traumatic osteoarthritis and associated disability. The number of patients in the US estimated to have symptomatic osteoarthritis approaches 27 million. Incidence rate is 26% higher in active duty service members 20-24 years old, and >100% higher for those >40 years old, than the general population. This is largely due to increased incidence of acute and chronic joint injury in the military. This project will identify a novel method of treatment to inhibit inflammation that contributes to arthritis development and joint dysfunction after joint injury. Expanding medical approaches for OA and joint injuries will improve quality of life, enhance rehabilitative efforts, and diminish the need for joint replacement in Veterans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative SARS COV2 infection leads to significant morbidity and mortality. The major point of entry for the viral infection is the mouth and nose but little is known about how the immune cells in these areas interact with and responds to SARS COV. Improving understanding of which cells are affected and how the virus triggers inflammatory response in them is critical for SARS COV2 management and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The limited success of our current approaches to improve long-term physical activity adherence in adults with overweight and obesity is a substantial barrier to effectively address the current obesity epidemic and prevention of cardiovascular disease. This mentored K01 application addresses the significant public health issue of obesity by expanding and pilot testing a theory-based physical activity program designed to enhance motivation in adults with overweight or obesity enrolled in a lifestyle weight management program. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will improve long-term physical activity adherence, which will enhance health and reduce chronic disease risk, for the large number of U.S. adults who struggle with obesity and its adverse health consequences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Influenza related morbidity and mortality continues to steadily increase each year, and the persons most at risk include those with cardiovascular disease. Vaccination reduces the incidence of cardiovascular events at the population level, but the degree of immunoprotection and cardioprotection achieved at the individual level is highly variable. We will investigate the extent to which upstream immune-inflammatory mediators account for individual differences in response to therapy and propensity for developing cardiovascular events.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative The outcomes of minority patients with advanced cancer remains poor despite many attempts at improving equity. This project will evaluate the role of implicit bias in contributing to some of these disparate outcomes including patient-centered communication, pain, psychological distress, satisfaction with communication and decisional conflict. We will audio record communication encounters of 60 oncologists and their 360 patients with advanced cancer in New York City and in Durham, NC to evaluate differences in these critically important outcomes.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JAMES J PETERS VA  MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Electrical stimulation of the spinal cord aims to take advantage of spared neural circuitry to promote functional recovery following spinal cord injury (SCI). This can be done non-invasively through transcutaneous spinal cord stimulation (TSCS). Small, proof-of-principle studies have shown that TSCS can be targeted to restore blood pressure to more normal and stable levels in hypotensive individuals with chronic, motor-complete SCI. Improved blood pressure control with TSCS is attributed to the restoration of intrinsic autonomic cardiovascular regulation. If true, improvement in other physiological systems that are regulated by the autonomic nervous system should be evident with targeted TSCS. We will identify TSCS parameters that normalize blood pressure in hypotensive individuals with chronic SCI and determine if these TSCS settings improve exercise endurance, recovery from exercise, regulation of core body temperature, and perception of thermal comfort.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: African American women with triple negative breast cancer have much worse clinical outcome, in terms of early relapse, aggressive metastasis and 5-year survival rate of 14% compared to 36% for other races. We have discovered race-specific single nucleotide polymorphism in TRIM37 that strongly correlates with high TRIM37 expression in African American women, and aggressive metastatic phenotype. This project will demonstrate that TRIM37 is a genetic variant associated with high risk of metastatic TNBC in African American women and generate proof-of-concept data to treat metastatic TNBC using TRIM37-specific antisense oligonucleotide and investigational clinical anti-FOLR1 antibody-guided nanoparticles.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Radiation-resistant prostate cancer (RR-PCa) is highly unpredictable which frequently results in cancer recurrence in many patients. This project aims to 1) establish the underlying mechanism(s) of mitochondrial biogenesis that contribute to RR-PCa cell survival and metabolism and 2) determine if targeting inherent mitochondria and radiation-acquired mitochondria, can overcome RR-PCa. The successful completion of this project will establish a new and significant therapeutic platform for making radiation therapy more effective.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: Project Narrative High-grade gliomas of the cerebral cortex are intractable brain tumors with a 5-year survival of less than 20%. Recurrent Gly34Arg/Val substitutions in Histone H3.3 (H3.3 G34R/V) occur in more than 15% of cerebral cortex high-grade gliomas found in adolescents and young adults. This proposal aims to determine the impact of H3.3 G34R/V mutations on transcriptional regulatory patterns contributing to tumorigenesis and identify critical transcription factor dependencies by leveraging a novel collection of primary tumors, patient-derived orthotopic xenografts, and a range of patient-derived cell lines modeling wild-type, H3.3 G34R/V mutant, and CRISPR- corrected H3.3 G34R/V backgrounds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative  Perturbing early development events can have profound consequences for the structural and functional integrity of the brain. In the olfactory system innovative strategies developed in the past several decades provided significant new insights into odor processing in the olfactory epithelium and olfactory bulb. In the current proposal we seek to develop a similar understanding of odor processing at the 3rd tier of the olfactory system, piriform cortex, by implementing novel molecular/genetic tools to understand how choreographed developmental events establish the foundations of cortical odor coding.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE South Asians (individuals from India, Pakistan and Bangladesh) have significantly more cardiovascular disease than other U.S. race/ethnic groups. However, Pakistanis and Bangladeshis may have even higher disease burden compared to Asian Indians. We propose to add Pakistanis and Bangladeshis to our ongoing study of South Asians that includes mostly Asian Indians to understand the complex drivers of cardiovascular health disparities in these three diverse and growing immigrant groups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Radioiodine is commonly used to treat patients with thyroid cancer, but it is often ineffective when the disease progresses or is more advanced. Blocking the abnormal proteins that cause the most common forms of the disease with specific drugs can restore the ability of thyroid cancer cells to trap radioiodine. This study tests new approaches to prolong the time that the radioiodine remains within the cancer cell so that a greater radiation dose can be delivered, and develops novel therapeutic antibodies to increase the immune response against these thyroid cancers.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Relevance to Public Health Sleep disruption during the transition to college can give rise to many health problems that prevent students from successfully navigating a path to a postsecondary degree. Fortunately, sleep is a modifiable behavior. Testing the effectiveness of interventions to improve the sleep of a broad population of students could reveal effective strategies for colleges to pursue in order to improve the sleep quality of their students.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: The overall goal of the proposed UCSF Environmental Research and Translation for Health Center (EaRTH Center) is to accelerate the pace of recognizing and preventing environmental exposures that affect reproduction and development, to improve health across the lifespan. We will offer focused resources to provide expertise and state-of-the-art technologies to create and support new research directions in environmental health at UCSF that are not currently possible. Our research will be tightly integrated with our community engagement, which will embed environmental health within the health care community. Our integrated Center will lead to new scientific understandings in environmental health, which will shift the fundamental understanding of the role of environment in disease, leading to solutions to preventing harmful exposures and improving health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pediatric leukemia patients bearing Mixed-lineage leukemia (MLL) gene translocations are associated with dismal prognosis and poor response to standard treatments. This proposal aims to develop novel ENL small- molecule degraders as in vivo chemical probes to target ENL, a promising drug target we recently identified, and test our therapeutic hypothesis that pharmacological degradation of ENL will provide a novel and effective strategy for treating MLL-rearranged leukemias. The proposed research is directly relevant to public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The molecular regulators of valvular delamination – a critical morphogenetic step of valvulogenesis whose dysfunction underlies a rare tricuspid valve malformation, Ebstein’s Anomaly – remain largely unknown. I will apply an innovative multi-omic approach to identify the intercellular interactions regulating this morphogenetic process and define the gene regulatory networks that drive valvular interstitial cell fate determination. This study will deepen our understanding of valvulogenesis and inform future efforts toward the development of novel regenerative medicine-based therapeutics for congenital and acquired valvulopathies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Apraxia is a common, disabling, but poorly understood impairment observed in several neurological disorders, particularly following a left hemisphere stroke, that selectively affects the ability to perform daily activities such as imitation and tool-use (i.e., praxis). This project aims to identify how two distinct processing mechanisms, supported by different brain regions, both contribute to imitation and tool-use behaviors. This serves as an important step toward developing tailored neurorehabilitation programs that can identify and take advantage of those processes and brain regions that remain intact in patients after stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because severe lung disease (LD) is an emerging complication of systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis (SJIA) and macrophage activation syndrome (MAS) has rapidly become the leading cause of death for children with this disorder. The proposed aims will mechanistically define the role of IFNγ as well as IL-1 blockade in an experimental model of lung disease in MAS as well as children with SJIA-LD, informing clinical care and leading to rapid translation of new therapeutic avenues. The project is relevant to NIH’s mission through seeking fundamental knowledge about the nature of systemic cytokine storms, and applying that knowledge to influence established treatment paradigms in SJIA, particularly with regards to the continued use of biologic therapy and risk of SJIA-LD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE African Americans living in the inner city disproportionately experience multidimensional adversity, defined as having three or more social adversities such as housing instability, food insecurity, transportation needs, utility needs, interpersonal safety, and financial strain, which impacts the complex self-management of type 2 diabetes and chronic kidney disease, also known as diabetic kidney disease. The goal of this K23 proposal is to use a convergent parallel mixed methods study design, which uniquely integrates the patients’ lived experiences, to inform the development of a culturally tailored intervention that addresses multidimensional adversity to improve clinical outcomes, quality of life, and self-care behaviors in African American adults with diabetic kidney disease living in the inner-city. Successful completion of this proposal will provide new evidence on potential targets and components of an intervention that addresses multidimensional adversity in general and particularly among African American adults with diabetic kidney disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are marked disparities in type 2 diabetes prevalence among socioeconomically disadvantaged and socially vulnerable populations. Tackling disparities in diabetes incidence requires innovative strategies that address both clinical parameters and underlying social and environmental determinants of health. Incorporating social determinants of health data into risk prediction models to identify those at high risk utilizing data already available in the electronic medical record is a promising avenue to prioritize and tailor local diabetes prevention initiatives to socioeconomically disadvantaged, socially vulnerable individuals, with potential to improve diabetes outcomes and health equity at the population level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  High blood pressure affects one-third of US adults, yet up to 20% of patients being treated for high blood pressure do not respond to any drugs. Antlia Biosciences is developing a long-acting analog of the human hormone brain natriuretic peptide, hBNP, to significantly lower blood pressure in this patient population via a 1x monthly (or longer) subcutaneous (SC) injection. If successful, this work will lead to clinical testing and ultimately commercialization of a drug for resistant hypertension and other chronic cardiovascular indications that patients can dose 1x monthly SC, with follow-up formulations that would be dosed at up to 3-month intervals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE  Non-healing wounds in diabetic patients represent a significant clinical problem and effective treatments are lacking; only one therapy is currently approved by the FDA, but exhibits questionable efficacy and is less effective than our product, CTX-001. CTX-001 has been formulated as an injectable gel to target two critical events that are dysregulated in diabetic wounds: chronic inflammation and oxidative stress. Based on strong preliminary data and our pre-IND meeting with the FDA, the ultimate goal of this Direct to Phase II proposal by Ceria is to complete cGMP-grade manufacturing and characterization of CTX-001 drug product, confirm efficacy in two relevant models of diabetic mice and pigs, and perform GLP-compliant toxicity studies to fulfill IND requirements.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: The Phase I objective is to design, develop, and demonstrate feasibility of srvc-EHSR ("Sysrev version control - environmental and health systematic reviews"), a modular, cloud-based, remote-installation-capable, platform which allows researchers to build customizable literature review workflows for environmental and health- related risk assessments. While several established platforms for systematic literature review exist, they lack interoperability, are not fit-for-purpose for risk assessment, and their complex codebase makes it too unwieldy to integrate new features to adapt systematic review methodologies for specific use-cases. Therefore, srvc- EHSR will increase the efficiency of literature reviews, make literature reviews more applicable to risk assessments, produce standardized data for research consumption, inform new and more powerful in silico models, decrease the scientific community's reliance on animal testing, and promote safe chemical use in consumer and industrial products and formulations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Marfan aortic root aneurysm leads to early dissection or rupture and reduced life expectancy, thus constituting a major health crisis. While prophylactic invasive aortic root surgical replacement can be performed, drug development has been absent since Marfan aneurysm pathophysiology remains unsolved. Our research aims to study molecular and cellular pathways leading to aneurysm formation so that mechanistic-based drug therapies can be discovered.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Vascular inflammation plays a central role in a variety of cardiopulmonary diseases and organ injuries involving the brain, nerves, kidney, gut and placenta. Tremendous gaps of knowledge exist with regard to the cellular and molecular basis of inflammatory injury and its related organ-based pathophysiology, contributing to the hampered development of effective diagnostics and therapeutics. This program recruits a collaborative team of nationally recognized experts in inflammation research who will provide comprehensive training of our next generation of scientists in understanding and solving the complex problems beyond the scope of individual laboratories.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Immune checkpoint blockade (ICB) has become an important therapeutic modality across a wide range of cancers, including breast cancer, that typically target inhibitory networks that cancerous cells use to negatively regulate a patient’s immune response. Here we will investigate an inhibitory network in the tumor microenvironment involving constitutively elevated phosphatidylserine (PS), engagement of Mertk receptors on infiltrating macrophages, and subversion of host anti-tumor immunity. We attempt to demonstrate that the PS- >Mertk->PD-L1 axis presents a vulnerability in cancer that can be mechanistically evaluated and therapeutically exploited.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The purpose of NE-CAT is to provide the biomedical community with access to state-of-the- art facilities for macromolecular crystallography. NE-CAT will enhance our ability to visualize the three-dimensional structures of biological macromolecules. These structures allow us to better understand basic biological systems, often resulting in the identification of new pharmaceutical targets and aiding in the development of new pharmaceutical agents. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Public Health Relevance/Project Narrative Understanding how blood cells are produced is fundamentally important to human health. We applied genetic studies in humans to identify a new cellular enzyme associated with increased platelet counts, and now propose to further characterize how metabolic function(s) involving the enzyme and its cellular pathway components affect human platelet production and erythrocyte development. This direction of research highlights its importance for blood cell development, most prominent in situations of aging or stress. During the grant period, we propose to complete more detailed biochemical and genetic studies to further study its mechanism of action. Animal models will be used for sophisticated mechanistic studies; comprehensive studies in mice will also provide novel insights into the mechanism(s) of stress hematopoiesis, relevant to human inflammatory conditions and/or patients receiving chemotherapy. Initial goals of characterizing novel chemical inhibitors based on our sophisticated structural models, are predicted to provide important pre-clinical data supporting more future drug development aimed at increasing human platelet counts. All the work proposed in this application builds on studies in humans with significant impact on translational studies designed to increase our understanding of metabolic regulation of blood cell development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Xanthine oxidase (XO) activity is significantly increased in a number of vascular diseases including hypertension, sepsis, and sickle cell disease as well as a substantive contributor to poor outcomes allied to cardiovascular surgery and transplantation. Associated with an elevation in XO activity is circulating heme. This grant will test if XO has protective, rather than a deleterious, role in vascular protection through its ability to degrade heme from XO-derived reactive oxygen species. Completion of this study will fill a major gap in our understanding XO’s ability to regulate intravascular heme and may lead to therapeutic strategies to improve cardiovascular health.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Sleep disorders are highly prevalent in veterans. A 6-fold increase in the diagnosis of sleep disorders was reported at the VA in recent years. Insomnia is associated with increased risk for suicide in veterans, an area of particular interest for VA. Furthermore, other severe neuropsychiatric disorders affecting veterans, such as schizophrenia or dementia, are associated with abnormalities of cortical electrical activity during wakefulness or specific sleep stages. Current attempts to develop treatments are hampered by a poor understanding of the brain circuitry controlling sleep, wakefulness and cortical activity. This research program in mice uses a novel strategy based on developmental biology to identify and characterize the neurons which control brain arousal and sleep in the basal forebrain, a brain area which degenerates in dementia. State-of-the-art genetic techniques will be used to manipulate the activity of these neurons, an essential first step towards correcting abnormalities of sleep-wake behavior and cortical activity in disorders affecting veterans.
