IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed studies are relevant to public health because they investigate the mechanisms underlying the biology of the lens, the development of age-related cortical cataracts, and the function of a critical proteins in lens fiber cell biology. Additionally the gene encoding the protein that is the focus of this study (Arvcf) is missing in the chromosomal disorder Velo-cardio-facial/DiGeorge Syndrome. Because this congenital disease includes multiple ocular and lens abnormalities of unknown cause, this study has the potential to elucidate at least part of its etiology. This proposal seeks to understand the function of Arvcf in the lens, how the generation and formation of lens fiber cell morphology contributes to and maintains lens function, and to determine how cellular processes may go awry to disrupt the structure and transparency of the lens, which is a leading cause of blindness world-wide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative. Proposed research will contribute to fundamental knowledge of how T-cell co-receptors regulate gene expression and T cell function through their influence on RNA maturation. Such knowledge will provide novel opportunities for targeting T-cell co-receptor downstream pathways in a manner that alters T cell responses. Therapeutic strategies to modulate T cell co-receptor downstream pathways have the potential to synergize with therapies targeting T cell co-receptors currently being used to treat cancer and autoimmune diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative With the increasing public use of complementary and integrative health (CIH) modalities and disciplines, rigorous research is essential so that CIH therapies can be accurately evaluated, and members of the public adequately informed. To help meet the need to rigorously evaluate promising CIH treatments for treating disease and improving health, CIH clinicians need training in clinical and translational research methods, and conventionally trained researchers need grounding in CIH therapies and philosophies. The T90/R90 BRIDG program partnership between the University of Washington and the National University of Natural Medicine is preparing the next generation of clinical investigators to design and carry out competitive, rigorous programs of CIH research that are innovative, collaborative, and multi-disciplinary, thereby generating new knowledge and contributing to improving health care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The function of a large number of genes termed long non-coding RNA (lncRNA) is poorly understood. We identified a cardiac specific circadian lncRNA, which affects cardiac remodeling post myocardial infarction by regulating alternative splicing. Understanding the molecular mechanism of this lncRNA will uncover novel gene regulatory pathways in the heart.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The discovery of BRAFV600E oncogene in a wide range of human cancers, including >50% of melanomas, has provided opportunities for the development of BRAF and MAPK-targeted cancer therapies, but their benefit has been limited due to tumor-to-tumor and cell-to-cell heterogeneity in the state of BRAF/MAPK dependency. Heterogeneity is regulated by a mixture of genetic, epigenetic, and signaling mechanisms, whose interplay with one another determines the dynamic state of MAPK dependency in tumor cell populations. This study creates a platform to characterize the role of epigenetic factors associated with tumor differentiation state and tissue lineage, with the goal of developing predictive tools to modulate the epigenetic state of BRAF/MAPK dependency in tumor cells and ultimately improving the clinical benefit of MAPK-targeted therapies in patients with BRAF-mutated cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lung transplantation is a life-saving procedure for thousands of people annually, but survival is severely diminished by invasive fungal infections. Aspergillus fumigatus is a common mold that affects one-in-three lung transplant recipients. This proposal seeks to better understand the host-pathogen relationship in lung transplantation, in order to develop new therapeutic approaches for this common infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Although significant progress has been made in understanding the regulation of fetal hemoglobin (HbF) in the treatment of sickle cell disease, very few of these findings have been developed into approved medications that effectively increase HbF levels. I have recently identified a novel regulator of HbF, the protein phosphatase PP6C; this project proposes to study signaling pathways important for PP6C-mediated HbF regulation in healthy individuals and in those with sickle cell disease. Results from this study will uncover new therapeutic approaches for the treatment of sickle cell disease and other hemoglobinopathies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Social contact plays a critical role in brain health and disease, and loneliness is tightly linked with depression, psychosis, suicidal behavior, and many autonomic, immune, and metabolic disorders. It remains unclear how the brain regulates 'social homeostasis' to maintain the internal stability and balance of diverse social, emotional, and physical needs. This project will use a new conceptual model and state-of-the-art technology to establish social homeostasis as a biological neural control system, like those well established for other physiological conditions (e.g. hunger, thirst, sleep), which will provide insights for social processing that is disrupted among many disease states including autism spectrum disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Tongue cancer and its treatment affect tongue structure and function, yet little is known about how the changes in tongue structure due to varying degrees of resection and reconstruction affect the formation of functional units of tongue motion during speech. We propose to use novel integrated platform tools to identify functional units seamlessly with unprecedented resolution and precision. Upon success of this proposal, our integrated framework has the potential to aid in an increased understanding of speech motor control strategies in healthy controls and the patient group, thereby benefiting patients through improved diagnosis, treatment, and rehabilitative strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Even with substantial public health advances in early identification of hearing loss and access to intervention for children who are deaf/hard-of-hearing (DHH), marked improvements in interventions to support continued language development have ceased. This study will test the effectiveness of a technology-assisted language intervention using augmentative and alternative communication software as a tool to enhance language development in children who are DHH. Expected outcomes of this study will very likely transform care delivery strategies for speech-language therapy for children who are DHH. An efficacious language intervention platform, such as the one proposed in this application, could be adapted for use among other language disordered populations providing a tremendous potential public health impact.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Safety assessment of electronic health records focuses on adult populations, even though challenges with health information technology contribute to a large portion of errors in pediatric populations, specifically medication errors in pediatric weight-based dosing. Our proposal will engage subject matter experts in pediatrics, medication safety, and informatics to optimize a tool to assess pediatric medication safety, test this tool across at least 20 hospitals, and measure the impact of changes made as a result of the assessment system on medication safety. The assessment tool can be applied across diverse healthcare settings as a robust, low-cost method of assessing and optimizing pediatric medication safety.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: A Systems Engineering Approach to Optimize Pediatric Medication Safety

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Non-polio human enteroviruses (NPEVs) represent an existing and emerging threat to public health, especially to infants and children. With more than 100 NPEVs known and the high rate of mutation and recombination of these viruses, the risk for evolution of virulent strains is high. Because we cannot predict the serotype of any newly emerging strain, addressing this problem effectively will require pan-enterovirus solutions. The central objective of this application is to establish unifying models for the biological functions of the enterovirus 2C protein that will provide a framework to establish 2C as a pan-enterovirus therapeutic target.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is a neurobiological condition with increasing prevalence for which early diagnosis is crucial but unfortunately often late or missed entirely, in large part due to lack of trained clinicians. This project will create health information technology (HIT) that uses natural language processing and machine learning algorithms with electronic health records to support non-expert clinicians in identifying children at risk for ASD. The HIT will be evaluated with non-expert clinicians for the minimum and optimal requirements to help clinicians make confident and high quality decisions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Hypertension is a public health epidemic, and in >30% of people with hypertension, blood pressure does not adequately fall during the night compared to daytime values (i.e., non-dipping). This non-dipping hypertension dramatically increases the risk for cardiovascular disease and increases the likelihood of early death, yet the mechanisms underlying this phenomenon are unclear. Through a mechanistic clinical trial, we will determine the individual contributions of sleep and the circadian system to non-dipping blood pressure to further behavioral and circadian time-based treatment of this syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inflammatory bowel disease represents a collection of medically incurable illnesses that cause severe and chronic damage to the lining of the bowel. Although all available therapies for IBD target the overactive immune system, promotion of healing of the damaged bowel through regenerative medicine represents a promising complementary strategy. Here, we elucidate important aspects of a noncanonical colonic wound healing response that originates from the neighboring skin-like anal transition zone and which could yield therapeutic insights.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Bestrophins are a family of ion channels with critical (patho)physiological roles in the eye, as mutations of bestrophin-1 (Best1) cause retinal degenerative disorders, while bestrophin-2 (Best2) regulates intra-ocular pressure. This project is aimed to identify interacting protein partners of bestrophins and elucidate the structural and functional consequences of these interactions. The findings from this work will provide important knowledge on ocular physiology, and establish a versatile platform for investigating other ion channels of interest and their interacting partners.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this innovative proposal is to bring together a policy-level strategy and adaptive implementation to develop and validate practical, effective and scalable strategies to achieve clinical practice change. Specifically, this project will have an important clinical impact by improving adherence to preoperative patient optimization across a statewide health system and will inform novel implementation strategies that could be scaled to other important clinical practice gaps. Optimally combining practice change strategies will allow for a tailored and cost-effective approach to improve the quality and cost of care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative This project seeks to develop a microengineered tissue model of the human vocal fold using pluripotent/ multipotent stem cells, custom-designed synthetic matrices and a multicompartment microfluidic device with integrated strain sensors. Using the microfluidic vocal fold tissue model, we will investigate how damage to the epithelium initiates fibrosis and how the fibrotic microenvironment sustains scarring. The chip-based vocal fold scar model will be utilized to evaluate the therapeutic efficacy of antifibrotic remedies.

PHR: Lung microvascular endothelial dysfunction is a hallmark of acute lung injury and sepsis. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Observational clinical data suggest that the injectable contraceptive depo-medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA- IM) increases HIV-1 acquisition risk by 32-40% compared to another injectable contraceptive norethisterone enanthate (NET-EN). Our proposed study comparing immune biomarkers and peak serum progestin and endogenous hormone levels relevant to HIV-1 infection in archived samples from a clinical trial of women randomized to DMPA-IM and NET-EN, and comparable in vitro mechanism studies, will provide high quality evidence of plausible mechanisms as to whether these two injectable contraceptives are likely to have different effects on HIV-1 risk. Insights from this study will be relevant to clinical practice and public health, particularly in South Africa, regarding choice of injectable contraception in areas at high risk for HIV-1 acquisition, where DMPA-IM and NET-EN are used without discrimination, and may also impact on international guidelines to either reassure interchangeable use or suggest preferential use of one of these injectable contraceptives over the other in populations at high risk of HIV-1 infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Chronic hypertension and aortic stenosis increase the contractile demands on the heart resulting in progression to heart failure. The precise mechanisms by which chronic elevated cardiac stress leads to heart failure are not known, and therefore, there are no effective treatments for patients with this condition. We have identified a cardiac regulatory protein (MyBPC) that modulates the cardiac contractile response to chronic stress. Thus, in this proposal we will investigate how manipulating MyBPC function can improve cardiac function in hypertension to prevent progression to heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Heart and/or skeletal muscle defects in newborn infants remain the most prevalent form of human birth defects, yet the exact genes and genetic processes that can either positively or negatively affect muscle development remain unknown. Studies on Akirin, a nuclear protein that is found in both fruit flies and humans, have indicated that Akirin works with a novel class of regulators to facilitate heart and skeletal muscle development By studying the role of Akirin during this process in fruit fly embryos, we will learn how this protein likely functions in vertebrates, such as mammals, during heart formation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recent genetic studies have identified a large compendium of genes associated with protein-truncating mutations in autism spectrum disorder (ASD), and these studies have demonstrated overwhelming support for chromatin modification and synaptic function as key pathways involved in ASD pathogenesis. Here, we seek to understand how these pathways converge on synaptic changes that contribute to neurodevelopmental deficits and will use a massively parallel CRISPR-engineering approach to disrupt 48 genes against the same genetic background and characterize the gene expression and functional changes that occur in human induced pluripotent stem cell derived neurons. These studies identify new mechanisms by which genes contribute to ASD and provide an invaluable resource of isogenic stem cell models of ASD to the broader research community.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Program Narrative Unlike a randomized control trial, our design seeks to draw causal inferences about the impact of varying the sequence of three TBC enhancements: small-group diabetes self- management training (DSMT), technology-supported remote glucose monitoring (RGM), and high-touch, individualized community health worker (CHW) support. Having better knowledge of how enhancements operate and their individual and combined impact on diabetes outcomes for people with a greater risk for poor diabetes control, is vital in ensuring limited resources are applied in ways that enhance efficiency, reduce costs, and improve patient outcomes and patient/provider experience. Second, the proposed study will examine the appropriateness, utilization and impact of novel technology to facilitate diabetes management and care in a safety-net hospital setting. Third, we aim to assess the potential for a high-touch, individualized CHW enhancement to improve uptake and adherence to DSMT and RGM among patients who do not improve within six months. This CHW innovation leverages persons particularly close to the population served who have the potential to strengthen intervention packages cost-effectively.

PROJECT_TITLE: Sinai diabetes center

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative In this project, we will investigate how cardiac-specific TCF7L2 isoforms interact with β-catenin to mediate cardiac gene expression in failing human hearts with coronary artery disease and idiopathic dilated cardiomyopathy. Using genetic targeting, we will determine if TCF7L2 is required for cardiac remodeling and dysfunction induced by pressure overload and if TCF7L2 temporal induction in adult mouse hearts is sufficient to cause cardiac remodeling and dysfunction. More importantly, we will evaluate if pharmacologic intervention to interfere TCF7L2 interaction with β-catenin can prevent heart failure after pressure overload or TCF7L2 induction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative General strategies to impose stereocontrol over radical-mediated transformations have long eluded synthetic chemists. By repurposing and engineering naturally occurring metalloenzymes for new-to-nature metalloredox processes, we will develop biocatalytic radical reactions that occur with excellent stereochemical fidelity. Ultimately, this evolvable metalloenzyme platform will allow for the rapid assembly of clinically significant therapeutics of general societal importance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hookworm infection is a parasitic disease that causes significant morbidity in tropical and subtropical regions worldwide. The World Health Organization (WHO) has called for the development of new, low-cost tools for hookworm surveillance, to replace currently used methods which are laborious and low in sensitivity. In this project, we propose to develop a test for human antibodies to hookworm that will meet the requirements set forth by the WHO. In Phase II we will refine this assay to improve sensitivity and specificity, manufacture the product, and scale-up production.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: In the United States, about 20,0000 children experience cardiac arrests per year, the majority of whom present to under-resourced and under-trained community hospitals that are unable to provide the high-quality cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) recommended by the Pediatric Advanced Life Support guidelines. Efficient, affordable, and high-quality CPR feedback provided in real-time by augmented reality CPR (AR- CPR), to various providers, could save lives and bridge gaps in who gets high quality care. We will refine AR- CPRs software and hardware, enhance its usability and functionality, and lay the groundwork for improvements in AR-CPRs to be incorporated into future clinical care. 1
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: AR-CPR: Refinement and Large-Scale Simulation-Based Testing of a Novel Augmented Reality Point of Care Chest Compression Feedback System.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative A core brain area responsible for memory is the hippocampus, which is impaired in a number of cognitive diseases, including Alzheimer’s. This work contributes to fundamental knowledge about the form of hippocampal representations, and their function in memory-guided cognitive behaviors. In order to address the question of how limits to hippocampal function might affect specific aspects of behavior, we compare memory-guided foraging behavior across animals with different hippocampus sizes, both in simulation and in natural environments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chemoproteomics provides an additional and important functional dimension to conventional genomic, transcriptomic, and proteomic data sets; accordingly, activity-based profiling has been successfully applied to a variety of oncologic, metabolic, and infectious diseases to better understand enzyme function under normal and diseased states. However, activity-based profiling has never been thoroughly applied to gain insight into basic ocular enzyme biology or leveraged to provide real-time activity of select enzymes in vivo. Our proposed studies will address both of these aspects, potentially laying the groundwork for more conventional use of activity-based profiling in vision research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with lung disease who have better self-management abilities or emotional health have an improved quality of life following lung transplant surgery. Health and wellness coaching is known to improve patients’ self- management abilities and emotional health in certain diseases, such as chronic obstructive lung disease (a.k.a. emphysema). In this application, we will investigate whether a weekly health and wellness coaching intervention by telephone improves pre-transplant self-management abilities and emotional health in patients on the lung transplant waiting list and whether it also improves patients’ quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because spinal cord injury causes permanent disability and worsened quality of life. Targeting harmful neuroinflammation after spinal cord injury could lead to discovery of new therapies that improve tissue repair and functional recovery. This preclinical project aims to reveal the untapped therapeutic potential of the circadian-neuroimmune axis after spinal cord injury, and is therefore relevant to NIH’s mission to seek fundamental knowledge that improves health and reduces disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Racial and ethnic minorities experienced stark health inequities during the COVID-19 pandemic. This study seeks to explain previously unexplored causes of COVID-19 disparities through an evaluation of the inter- related effects of nursing resources and by identifying those hospitals, that despite the odds, achieved equitable outcomes for racial and ethnic minorities during the pandemic. Findings from this study will leverage “lessons learned” from COVID-19 to inform interventions that ensure the allocation of appropriate clinical care resources to patients from diverse backgrounds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The COVID-19 pandemic has dramatically altered healthcare delivery, rapidly shifting the primary modality of ambulatory care delivery to telemedicine-based virtual encounters that are persisting at high levels. Our project will generate evidence on the implications of this transition for how clinicians use the electronic health record to support care documentation and clinical decision-making. Resulting findings will be used to develop and prioritize design guidelines and translate them into pragmatic strategies to improve EHR support for telemedicine encounters.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Malaria is one of the major global health problem afflicting about 219 million people and killing 435,000 individuals annually. Because of the emergence of drug resistance parasites, current therapies for malaria are rapidly loosing their efficacy. The proposed research seeks to identify antimalarial lead compounds from fungal extracts effective against multidrug resistant malaria, thus contributing to the global malaria elimination campaign.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The infectious bacterial disease tuberculosis poses a significant global threat to human health, since it is the leading cause of death due to infectious disease in South Africa, with over 9,000 reported cases in the USA in 2017. Here, nanoparticles, which mimic the bacteria in appearance, will be investigated to modulate the antibacterial response of the host immune cells, and thus achieve eradication of the bacteria. Knowledge gained could contribute to improved tuberculosis control strategies, specifically more effective drug treatment regimens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cellular events that alter vessel architecture, drive extracellular matrix degradation, and promote vascular calcification cause atherosclerotic plaque destabilization, ultimately increasing the risk for acute cardiovascular events. Our research identifies that impaired putrescine synthesis in vascular smooth muscle cells (vSMCs) enhance these features of plaque instability. Understanding the mechanisms that impair putrescine biosynthesis in vSMCs during atherosclerosis may provide novel therapeutic strategies to stabilize rupture- prone atheromas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: The prefrontal cortex (PFC) of the brain controls decision making and impulsive behavior, and changes in the PFC are thought to underlie compulsive drug-taking and relapse in drug and alcohol abusers. A detailed understanding of what alcohol does in the PFC will help us to understand how the existing drugs work, and identify new targets in the brain so we can develop better drugs to treat alcohol use disorders more effectively. We will study the effects of alcohol in the PFC area of the mouse brain after the equivalent of between one and six drinks, using new methods for recording from brain cells, imaging the cells with infra-red light, using a specially equipped microscope and camera.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Pediatric sleep problems are a major public health concern and sleep in children with autism spectrum disorders (ASD) is a very high priority for research (see IACC Strategic Plan, Objective 2). Our application, “Sleep, Brain Development, and Behavioral Correlates in a Longitudinal Cohort of Children at Risk for ASD,” will leverage a recently funded longitudinal follow-up of 300 7-10 year-old children at high familial risk for ASD (HR; with ASD n~100; without ASD ~200) and 100 low familial risk for ASD (LR) who have had multiple MRI and behavior assessments since infancy through the NIH Autism Center of Excellence Infant Brain Imaging Study (IBIS). Across these three groups (HR-ASD, HR-NonASD, and LR) our aims are to 1) characterize sleep problems in the home using actigraphy, validated by sleep diary, and parent report, (2) examine longitudinal brain trajectories (from infancy) associated with sleep problems in school-age, and (3) examine the relationship of longitudinal behavior trajectories and concurrent behavior to sleep problems in school-age to increase understanding of the neurobiology, developmental characteristics, and co-morbid conditions associated with sleep problems, with implications for developing novel sleep interventions and improving outcomes in this vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Obesity is now considered a worldwide epidemic and a risk factor for insulin resistance, diabetes, cardiovascular diseases, liver disease and immunological/infectious diseases such as COVID-19. Our recent findings in humans and mice identified the G-protein-coupled receptor 75 (GPR75) and its ligand, the lipid mediator 20-HETE as significant contributors to obesity and its associated cardiovascular and metabolic complications. Understanding the mechanisms by which activation of GPR75 leads to exacerbation of diet-driven adiposity, insulin resistance and vascular dysfunction will lead to novel therapeutics to treat obesity and its associated complications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Psychiatric disorders pose challenges to neurobiological analysis as they are complex, routinely co-occur, and are operationalized using behavioral symptoms. We propose to examine the neurobiological basis of reaction time variability in the Adolescent Brain Cognitive Development (ABCD) study in order to explore heterogeneity in Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD). This work may help us better understand how to identify and treat individuals with ADHD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While the advent of antiretroviral therapy (ART) has significantly decreased the morbidity and mortality associated with HIV infection, a cure is not achieved, and ART must therefore be taken on a lifelong basis. In this project, we pursue the hypothesis that circulating cell-free DNA in plasma that can be conveniently and non-invasively measured will enable us to predict if and when HIV will rebound when an individual stops taking ART. In addition, we pursue the hypothesis that cell-free DNA that circulates throughout the human body may transmit key signals that activate antiviral immunity and prevent HIV recrudescence when ART is stopped.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The main goals of the U-RISE program at Cal State Fullerton are to recruit and provide biomedical research training to undergraduates from under-represented or disadvantaged backgrounds; nurture their academic and research skills; and place graduating U-RISE scholars in various PhD or MD-PhD programs. The program will track all participants and will disseminate its achievements through various media platforms. Overall, the program endeavors to increase the diversity of highly-trained biomedical researchers and produce scientists who will serve their community and the public, as well as work diligently on health-related issues faced by our nation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Routine mammography screening for early cancer detection has significantly reduced breast cancer mortality, but also subjects women to several potential harms, including incorrect results and unnecessary recall with po- tentially invasive procedures. The goal of this project is to increase accuracy of breast cancer detection and risk estimation through the development of new deep learning models that consider a patient’s mammogram screening history. This work would improve breast cancer detection, inform individualized screening protocols, and guide development and monitoring of tissue-modifying preventive cancer treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute leukemia (AL), a cancer of the blood, has variable prognosis, treatment response and survival depending on the specific subtype, which is characterized by genetic alterations, but current standard-of-care testing takes 2 to 4 weeks to fully characterize and subtype an AL and requires highly skilled staff as well as multiple expensive instruments and reagents. We have developed an ultrarapid (same day sample to reporting) assay using real-time long read DNA sequencing to achieve faster and more cost-effective detection of AL mutations/fusions and build upon our current computational methods and software tools to support reproducible data analysis and enable interactive interpretations for biomedical users. We propose to first expand this assay to add additional targets for AL prognostication and therapy guidance, then to validate an optimized CSRL assay and bioinformatics workflow, and finally to run a pilot trial to show feasibility of clinical implementation.

PHR: Narrative  We hypothesize that increasing AbcA1 and Ldlr while reducing ApoE with small molecules, will diminish and clear amyloid plaques from affected brains in Alzheimer’s disease. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal aims to develop a biodegradable and implantable piezoelectric platform that can provide wireless, local, and on-demand mechano-electrical stimulation of pudendal nerve upon applied mechanical forces for postoperative stress urinary incontinence treatment. This unconventional approach will challenge the standard paradigm by modulating injured neurons and endogenous cells via local mechano-electrical cues created by rehabilitative exercise movements. In the long run, this piezoelectric platform technology has the potential to be synergistically combined with Kegel exercise to promote pudendal nerve regeneration and provide a positive impact on economic and societal needs of patients with stress urinary incontinence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Neurodegenerative diseases are characterized by the presence of protein aggregates that result in dementias and movement disorders. Purification of amyloid filaments from the protein aggregates for structural studies has been challenging. An affinity purification method will be developed in this project to improve amyloid isolation and cryoEM structural studies for better understanding of the diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Nearly half of the adult U.S. population suffer from hypertension, a major risk factor leading to heart disease, stroke, and kidney failure. Combined intake of fructose and salt equivalent to three 12-oz cans of sugared soft drinks and ~6 gm of sodium raises blood pressure, induces prediabetes, and increases stiffness of the arteries, all strong predictors of cardiovascular morbidity and mortality. Our proposal investigates drug therapies that improve blood pressure, insulin sensitivity, and arterial stiffness in a preclinical model and provides insights into underlying causes leading to novel approaches at an early stage of these disorders and prevent frank disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: Project Narrative The major histocompatibility complex (MHC) is critical for effective immune responses, but is deregulated in common malignancies, such as duodenal and colorectal cancer. Using cell culture, animal, and patient organoid approaches, this project repurposes standard-of-care clinical agents and a novel epigenetic drug candidate in the context of an evolving new paradigm for immune- based cancer interception in the gut. Increasing MHC expression according to the central hypothesis will enhance immune surveillance and foster clearing of precancerous lesions, at doses likely to be well-tolerated when translated to at-risk human subjects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Excessive drinking is a significant public health problem that may be powerfully driven by what people learn and remember about their experiences with alcohol. The proposed research uses functional neuroimaging and neuroendocrine assays to investigate the cognitive and neurobiological mechanisms by which binge/heavy drinkers form different types of memories about alcohol-related cues. We will explore how the engagement of multiple neural memory systems is modulated by glucocorticoids and drinking history, and determine whether these processes predict real-world drinking behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Resident-to-resident aggression (RRA) is a prevalent issue in long-term care with severe health consequences to residents, many of whom suffer from Alzheimer's Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD) and are minority racial/ethnic backgrounds. We propose to comprehensively examine the role of race and ethnicity in RRA using already existing prospective prevalence data, in addition to collecting nursing home stakeholder input to improve understanding of the role of race/ethnicity in RRA to inform a novel staff education RRA intervention development. This proposal thus has the potential to reduce race/ethnicity-related RRA, strengthen workforce training by improving provider competency for resolving race and ethnicity-related aggression among residents, and benefit residents with ADRD from diverse racial/ethnic backgrounds who are at higher risk of RRA involvement due cognitive impairment related behavioral symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will use novel analysis techniques to investigate biological processes in the brain that are related to disease progression in patients with the non-fluent/agrammatic variant of primary progressive aphasia. We will measure brain neuroinflammation using neuroimaging, as well as biomarkers of neuroinflammation and neurodegeneration from blood samples, and determine how these biological processes relate to clinical disease progression and structural and functional abnormalities in the brain. The study will improve our understanding of disease progression in these patients, provide new biomarkers of disease, and lead to better targeted future treatments.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Recent evidence suggests that the same event can engage different brain circuits at different ages with transitions between these circuits considered periods of vulnerability that can initiate a pathway to pathology. Yet, we have little understandin of how a child can switch between these circuits or why access to an early life circuit is lost. To address this gap, we propose to use a model system where two different circuits are evoked by the same event at two different ages, and a brief developmental period when both circuits co-exist and maternal presence controls which circuit is used.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE Genetic exchange between homologous chromosomes is essential to ensure that they segregate accurately in meiosis, the specialized cell division that gives rise to eggs and sperm. Errors in recombination can lead to an incorrect number of chromosomes, which is the most common cause of birth defects and miscarriage. However, the same type of exchange in other cells can lead to cancer. This proposal seeks to understand how exchange is promoted in cells undergoing meiosis but avoided in other tissues, in terms of both regulation and molecular mechanisms of recombination processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Treatment options for Glioblastoma (GBM) – a deadly disease with median survival of ~15 months – have changed little over the past 50 years, but preclinical data suggest a ketogenic diet (KD) may have anti-GBM effects. Given many GBM patients attempt to adopt some version of KD despite the lack of high-quality data supporting its use, we recently completed a phase 1 KD trial for newly diagnosed GBM, wherein we achieved the primary aim of safety and feasibility and found an impressive median Overall Survival (OS) of 29.1 months, which is a 99% improvement vs. historic control from the phase 3 trial that established the current standard-of- care. We are now poised to conduct, for the first time, a well-powered multicenter randomized controlled phase 2 trial testing the efficacy of a KD plus standard-of-care vs. standard-of-care to improve OS in newly diagnosed GBM patients, along with correlative studies to uncover the potential mechanisms by which a KD may delay GBM progression and improve quality-of-life, providing key data which can inform clinical care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Increasing antibiotic resistance is a major problem that threatens to end the clinical usefulness of many antibiotics and fundamentally alter our ability to treat bacterial infections. This proposal will extend our studies of enzymes that chemically modify specific RNA molecules to alter antibiotic activity and will also establish a new paradigm for understanding how these modifications impact antibiotic-target interactions. Detailed understanding of mechanisms of resistance and antibiotic-target interactions are necessary prerequisites for the development of new strategies to extend the clinical life of current antibiotics or to create novel designer drugs to combat resistant bacteria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Dementia due to Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) disproportionately impacts racial/ethnic minorities and the socioeconomically disadvantaged; groups more often exposed to neighborhood disadvantage. Prior research supports that neighborhood disadvantage is modifiable and interacts with biological processes to produce disease, yet little is known of its impact on ADRD. This project leverages data within 22 Alzheimer’s Disease Research Centers across the US to conduct the largest study of its kind on social determinants of health in the context of AD and to develop a novel collaborative infrastructure of contextual exposure for future social-biological phenotypic evaluation-- a potential pathway to new therapeutics directly responsive to the NIA mission.

PHR: The goal of this research is to improve the delivery of neuroprotective antibodies to the brain by generating bifunctional antibodies that target both a protein at the blood brain barrier and a target within the brain. This research will involve optimizing bifunctional antibodies to achieve high and sustained antibody levels in the brain, and then using them to prevent Alzheimer's disease-like pathology in animal models. The bifunctional antibodies and insights gained in this work are expected to accelerate the development of therapeutics for treating Alzheimer's disease and other neurodegenerative disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research is relevant to public health because it will uncover new neurobiological influences on how people regain motor and sensory function after a stroke. Specifically, this study will examine the role of global brain health measures, which represent deterioration of systems across the whole brain, in stroke recovery by analyzing both: (a) a large existing database of neuroimaging and behavioral data on stroke patients and (b) new data that will be collected in the first 3 months following stroke, when the majority of stroke recovery is thought to occur. The project is relevant to the NIH’s mission because it will create important new knowledge on the relationships of global brain health to post-stroke brain injury, brain repair, and sensorimotor recovery, which can be used to identify novel therapeutic targets to improve stroke recovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) has become a leading cause of liver-related morbidity and mortality. We recently discovered that macrophage TREM2, whose expression is positively and tightly associated with NASH progression, protects mice from NASH. In this study, we will comprehensively investigate how TREM2 expression is regulated during NASH progression, what TREM2 does in macrophages to prevent NASH development, and whether blocking TREM2 cleavage can inhibit NASH.

ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the current grant proposal, we will study how endogenous opioids (called endomorphins) and clinically employed opiates (such as fentanyl, remifentanil) regulate the entry of Na+ ions through acid sensing ion channels (ASIC) in rat sensory neurons. We will also investigate the ability of endomorphins to enhance blood pressure increases mediated by lactic acid and contracting muscle. We will employ rats with “freely perfused” femoral arteries and those that have had their femoral artery “ligated”—a model of peripheral artery disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Neuronal miscommunication, neuronal death, and abnormal depositions of proteins forming amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles are the basic pathological hallmarks of Alzheimer's disease (AD), the most common form of dementia currently affecting more than six million Americans. The amyloid precursor protein (APP) is the precursor of the beta amyloid peptide (Aβ), the basic component of the amyloid plaques, but it is also involved in the regulation of neuronal communication and neuronal death. The proposed research program will enable us to investigate the molecular architecture of APP and related proteins using advanced structural biology techniques, and open the way towards understanding how the molecular architecture of the protein enables its physiological functions and how it may permit dysregulation of these functions in AD.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The transfer of microbes from mother to infant at birth is widely recognized as a critical life event that impacts life-long health for the infant. At present, factors that promote an optimal transfer of microbes to the infant are not well-defined, and medical interventions that perturb microbial transfer, such as maternal antibiotics, put the infant at increased risk of adverse health outcomes. This proposal will investigate the influence of human breastmilk components produced during pregnancy in shaping the mother’s vaginal microbes and vaginal immune responses to promote transfer of beneficial microbes to the infant.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative Brain tumor is the leading cause of death by cancer in the pediatric population; thus there is a great need for novel therapies. Radiation is an important part of therapy for many high-grade tumors including medulloblastoma, the most common malignant pediatric brain tumor, but it is rarely curative and comes with significant side effects. This project aims to identify reversible causes of immune suppression in medulloblastomas treated with radiation so that we can leverage the benefits of immunotherapy to achieve long-term remission for patients with treatment-resistant tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Project Narrative These experiments will address a significant gap in what we know about the causal link between hearing loss and Alzheimer’s disease by using mouse models with specific brain pathologies. Most studies on the effects of age, sex, and noise using these models test them with physiological and reflexive techniques, which do not accurately reflect how sounds are perceived in an awake, behaving state akin to people out and about in the world. This study aims to characterize the relationship between behavioral and physiological measures of hearing in quiet and noisy environments to learn more about the relationship between hearing loss and Alzheimer’s Disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Nearly every minute, someone in the United States sustains a burn injury serious enough to require treatment (~500,000 a year). Burn dressing removal is reportedly the time of most pain (after the burn itself) and opioids are the main treatment for such pain. This proposal describes the synthesis, characterization, and evaluation (in vitro, in vivo, and preclinical) of the first supramolecular hybrid hydrogel burn dressing that is on-demand dissoluble -for easy trauma-free removal from burn wound-, antimicrobial, and self-healable.

ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Public Health Relevance: The microbes living on/in the human body, known as “the human microbiota”, metabolize various dietary nutrients, impact host metabolism, and are essential for human health. This proposal aims to investigate the molecular mechanisms behind microbiota-Type 2 diabetes (T2D) association and provides mechanistic insights of some microbial pathways involved in mediating host amino acid and glucose homeostasis. It will also pave the way for a systematic regulation of these health- related microbial pathways in the human gut using synthetic biology and microbial genetics to treat age-related disease like T2D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Due to relentlessly evolving drug resistance, a continual pipeline of new drug discovery is required to combat mortality caused by the malaria parasite. We have identified three new chemical series based on phenotypic screening and will conduct a medicinal chemistry and target identification program to determine if they have the potential to be developed for the treatment of malaria. Our multidisciplinary team has extensive experience working together and a successful track record in identifying drug candidates.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This Research Training in Endocrinology and Metabolism will provide outstanding young physician- scientists and PhD scientists with the resources, skills, knowledge and mentorship they need to launch careers in metabolic research. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to understand how increased gut permeability and translocation of fungal products from the gut impacts lung function, respiratory symptoms, and disease progression in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). This project will also explore if the fungal cell wall product, 1,3 beta-d-glucan, has direct pathogenic effects on the lung and can be targeted as a novel therapy for COPD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to the public health because it focuses on developing clinically validated predictive markers for response in chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), which will result in personalized therapies for people with CLL and prospectively identify high-risk patients. These data will identify therapeutic vulnerabilities leading to novel therapeutic approaches that improve patient outcomes. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NCI’s mission that pertains to advancing scientific knowledge and helping people live longer, healthier lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Quantitative measures of hormone levels are critical to the diagnosis, management, and treatment of endocrine disorders, and are central to fertility planning and assisted reproductive technologies. We proposed to develop a novel class of inexpensive, real-time, sensors based on the discovery and functionalization of microbial hormone sensing proteins. We will demonstrate the utility of our novel sensors by developing a point- of-care microfluidic device for real-time hormone measurements from urine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Venezuelan equine encephalitis virus (VEEV) is an emerging, biodefense-relevant pathogen that causes severe morbidity and mortality in humans and animals. There is no approved human VEEV vaccine. Development of VEEV vaccine is in line with the mission of the NIH as outlined in the 2007 NIAID Strategic Plan for Biodefense Research. Live-attenuated vaccines provide successful vaccination with a single dose, which is required for rapid outbreak containment. In this Phase 1 clinical trial proposal we investigate safety and immunogenicity of rationally designed, novel live-attenuated vaccine V4020 with rearranged genome for increased safety.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Whereas evidence is accumulating that exposure of pregnant women to toxic substances may initiate hereditary diseases that run in the family with or without involving DNA mutations, our knowledge about how various types of toxicants can introduce persistent damages into the genetic materials of human germ cell precursors responsible for production of sperm or eggs has been limited due to the lack of convenient experimental model of such precursor cells. Taking advantage of our recent accomplishment that enables perpetual expansion of human germ cell precursors in the laboratory as cell culture, we propose a research project aiming at examining persistent damages in the genetic materials of germ cell precursors caused by exposures to toxic chemicals. Outcomes of our research will immediately teach not only academic research laboratories but also the hospital clinicians, the industry, or the governmental agencies regulating chemical safety about the risk and mechanisms of heritable damages caused by exposure to environmental chemicals or therapeutic drugs, including chemotherapy agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative RNAs play essential roles in nearly every aspect of HIV-1 replication, yet currently available therapeutics only target the proteins of the virus. The Center for Structural Biology of HIV-1 RNA (CRNA) brings together an interdisciplinary team of biomedical specialists to tackle technical challenges and discover structural, dynamic, and biologic properties of HIV-1 RNAs to guide new therapeutic approaches to HIV-1 disease prevention, treatment, and cure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tamoxifen has been an effective treatment for estrogen receptor positive breast cancer for several decades. Unfortunately, tamoxifen acts in an opposite manner in the uterus and increases the risk of endometrial cancer. The goal of this project is to determine why tamoxifen promotes endometrial cell growth with the hope of discovering fundamental differences between breast cancer and endometrial cancer and identifying potential treatment targets for endometrial cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Privo’s Nanotechnology-Engineered Hydrogel, PRV211 is applied as an intraoperative therapy for oral  cancer patients. Following tumor resection, PRV211 is applied directly within the tumor bed to kill  remaining cancerous cells and prevent micrometastasis or recurrence. PRV211’s safety and efficacy has  been proven through multiple sets of animal studies. The team is strongly motivated to pursue effective  prevention of tumor recurrence, with negligible side effects, and planning for a clinical study to evaluate  the impact of PRV211 on the recurrence rate and overall survival in OSCC patients. This treatment has the  potential for improving the progression free survival rates with a great impact on patients’ lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rhabdomyosarcoma (RMS) is the most common childhood sarcoma, yet little is known about how chromatin regulators control tumor-propagating cells and tumor relapse after treatment. Here, we will dissect the role of polycomb complex 2 and its catalytic subunit EZH2 in regulating RMS cell state transitions by employing single-cell multiomics sequencing, functional assays, and novel preclinical zebrafish and mouse models. This study will broaden our understanding of how chromatin regulators control tumor cell state transitions and will contribute to developing novel therapies for rhabdomyosarcoma patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative For years it has been hypothesized that psychiatric disorders are the result of abnormal trajectories of childhood brain development, though there is little direct evidence to support that hypothesis. The UNC Early Brain Development Study is a longitudinal study that has followed children with imaging and developmental assessments from birth to age 10 years. We will study brain structure and function in these children at 12, 14, and 16 years with MRI to see if we can identify childhood predictors of behavior in adolescence that is considered at risk for psychiatric illness, which will ultimately help target periods of childhood development for early intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many forms of human disease result from mis-regulation of the pre-mRNA splicing reaction, and this is particularly evident in the nervous system, where amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), Spinal Muscular Atrophy, Myotonic Dystrophy, and Frontal Temporal Dementia are all disorders of splicing regulation. In this project, we study the mechanisms of splicing regulation by the PTBP and Rbfox protein families, which have been implicated in disorders of cortical development, and in epileptic and autism spectrum disorders, respectively. Despite its broad involvement in neurologic disease, how the cells control splicing is not understood, and this understanding will be essential to the development of splicing targeted therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: The proposed project has significant public health relevance; nearly 30 million Americans will have an eating disorder in their lifetime. These disorders are increasingly recognized to have a biological basis, however neural mechanisms and factors that render individuals responsive vs resistant to treatment, recovery, and remission are poorly understood. This project will characterize behavioral factors and brain mechanisms underlying food choice, associated eating-associated anxiety, and striking clinical features of anorexia nervosa and determine their relationship to treatment responsivity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: This research investigates how animals integrate different visual cues to detect and respond to their own self-motion. Humans rely on similar visual cues to stabilize gaze when the head or body moves, processing that is disrupted by a variety of neurological diseases. The proposed project will contribute to understanding the suite of algorithms, neural computations, and visual cues that are associated with visual stabilizing behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative: Understanding how a history of chronic alcohol exposure during adolescence influences viral host defense mechanisms has direct implications for individuals exposed to SARS-CoV-2 and other viral infections. Importantly, sex differences in vulnerability to COVID-19 adverse outcomes are profound, and require well- established animal models for the development of future therapeutics. This project presents a compelling model system to identify the neuroimmune mechanisms underlying early developmental alcohol exposure effects on virally-mediated host defense mechanisms and potential mechanisms of drug-resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Project Narrative: Replacement therapy using recombinant Factor VIII is the first line of therapy for Hemophilia A, a bleeding disorder and this life-saving therapy is complicated by the development of anti-Factor VIII antibodies, referred as inhibitors and this increase bleeding related morbidity and mortality. Once such responses are established, cost prohibitive therapies are attempted (about $700,000 per patient/per year) with limited success and the proposed research is relevant to NIH’s mission of seeking fundamental knowledge to enhance human health and relevant to public health because the proposal addresses an unmet medical need and is focused on developing novel clinical approaches to reduce and reverse such unwanted immune responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Periodontitis, a disease affecting a large proportion of the population, is associated with a dysbiotic microbial community in which Porphyromonas gingivalis is a major player. As current therapeutic options for periodontitis are only partially successful, therapeutic agents that can specifically target P. gingivalis are attractive and advantageous alternative over conventional antibiotics. Our proposed research will provide a molecular basis for the rational design of agents that can interfere with the initiation and formation of P. gingivalis-associated pathogenic communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This proposal finalizes the design of a portable ankle robot as a therapeutic device to reverse foot drop (for the first time) and restore safer independent walking after stroke, and conducts a rigorous randomized clinical trial to establish clinical proof for this new market application. Based on five positive clinical studies using a tethered lab robot, including our randomized study showing 18 sessions on treadmill durably reverses foot drop and restores a safer heel-first foot landing, we finalize a portable ankle robot (AMBLE) for untethered robot use during physical therapy (PTR). Commercial units meeting FDA requirements will reach design freeze the first year (Phase 1); feasibility of which is supported by our precedent battery operated version already showing proof-of-function in stroke patients, leading into Phase II (3-yrs) with a blinded, randomized clinical trial comparing 9-weeks (18 sessions) of PTR vs. PT alone to reverse foot drop based on biomechanical and blinded clinical outcomes, identifying a new market application and filling an unmet need.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Project Narrative/Public Health Relevance: Hispanic/Latinx families, especially immigrants, experience twice the rate of food insecurity than non- Hispanic/Latinx families which contributes to disproportionate health disparities. Evidence-based food insecurity interventions, such as the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP, also known as food stamps), have been demonstrated to improve mental and physical health outcomes for individuals facing food insecurity, yet is an under-utilized program especially among Latinx immigrant communities. The proposed research will develop a SNAP enrollment intervention as a prototype that will advance our understanding for how to identify community-driven strategies for implementing evidence-based social interventions across diverse communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (RELEVANCE) The development of a new therapeutic strategy to eradicate human immunodeficiency virus type-1 (HIV-1) is an urgent and unmet need. By focusing this proposal on how HIV upregulates certain host proteins to avoid apoptosis and to promote cell survival, we can develop and optimize a new strategy designed to overcome the inherent resistance of HIV-infected macrophages and microglia to viral cytopathicity while sparing uninfected cells. This low risk, high reward approach is fundamentally different from traditional strategies that target HIV itself, and we expect it to be highly complementary with current antiretroviral therapy strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research will be the first longitudinal study to examine the effects of early-life exposure to breast milk poly- and perfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) on infant growth trajectories and risk for childhood obesity in the context of the infant gut microbiome and fecal metabolome. Study findings will address a critical gap in our current understanding of breast milk PFAS and their obesogenic effects. Results from this proposal are expected to have significant implications in terms of identifying alterations in gut bacterial species and/or fecal metabolic pathways that contribute to obesity risk. These findings can be used in future novel intervention modalities applicable to Hispanic infants who are at increased risk of early-onset obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The training of young scientists that will become the next generation of virologists is essential for our nation's capacity to respond to existing, emerging, and future viral diseases. Furthermore, research on viruses continues to lead to fundamental discoveries in biology. Through the Institute for Molecular Virology and this T32 program, the University of Minnesota-Twin Cities campus has established itself as a leader in virology research, with particular strengths in HIV, influenza virus, herpesviruses, along with emerging and other highly pathogenic viruses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed K24 Midcareer Investigator Award in Patient-Oriented Research aims to best enable the Principal Investigator to: (1) advance her research program in neurocognitive disparities in aging and Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRDs); (2) deepen her commitment to mentoring junior clinical scientist pursuing research careers in this area, particularly trainees from underrepresented minority backgrounds; and (3) develop tools to most accurately detect neurocognitive impairment associated with ADRDs among older Spanish- speakers in the United States. These activities will advance the field of ADRD disparities research and support the diversification of the aging research workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Oxygen metabolism is mediated by several metalloenzymes, and one of the most complicated and least understood of these is the oxygen-evolving complex in photosystem II containing a manganese-calcium cluster, which is the only enzyme in nature that is capable of oxidizing H2O to O2. This proposal is directed towards using the newly available ultra-fast X-ray free electron laser, to take snapshots of the geometric and electronic structural changes of photosystem II and its metal center, in real time under physiological conditions, to understand the mechanism of water oxidation and oxygen evolution, and extending our studies to the study of other related Fe/Mn/Ni containing metalloenzymes of importance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Sorsby fundus dystrophy is a rare inherited disease caused by mutations in Tissue Inhibitor of Metalloptroteinase-3, that leads to loss of vision and has striking similarities to age-related macular degeneration (AMD). The exact molecular and pathological mechanism(s) that lead to vision loss in either of these conditions has not been identified. Given that mutations in TIMP3 always cause SFD (100% penetrance), knowledge gained from examining the abnormalities in the RPE and retina due to these variations is critical to understanding the pathogenesis of retina/RPE/choroid dysfunction in macular dystrophies. The knowledge gained from these studies will not only contribute to our understanding of fundamental principles of retinal physiology and pathology in SFD, but may also lead to the development of new therapeutic approaches for SFD as well as AMD and other macular degenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project is relevant to public health because it would provide crucial information to inform the design of bundled payment programs implemented by the Centers for Medicare and Medicare Services. Given the size of the Medicare program and the national implementation of bundled payment, even minor improvements to bundled payment programs have the potential to improve outcomes for thousands of older Americans. Understanding the impact of bundled payment for coronary artery disease is particularly important to older Americans because they have greater clinical risk and are more susceptible to poor outcomes related to common cardiovascular procedures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: 8. PROJECT NARRATIVE Apolipoprotein L1 (APOL1) risk variants may contribute to African American living kidney donors’ even greater (3.3-fold) risk of end-stage renal disease post-donation than white living kidney donors. However, transplant physicians do not consistently use APOL1 genetic testing or counsel African American living donor candidates about APOL1, which may undermine candidates’ ability to give informed consent about donating and exacerbate health disparities in living donation and transplantation. By evaluating the effectiveness of a culturally competent APOL1 genetic testing program, the proposed study will provide valuable knowledge about the potential to rapidly scale up APOL1 testing nationally as a novel and ethical approach to protect African American living donors’ safety and enhance their informed consent.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on functional and mechanistic studies of a transport protein – OATP1B1 that is involved in the uptake of various endogenous molecules and drugs into hepatocytes, which is the first step in the process of drug processing in the liver. Due to the promiscuity of OATP1B1, various co-administered drugs could compete with each other, resulting in elevated plasma levels of the drugs, and risking adverse side effects. Also, some cancers overexpress OATP1B1 and it is the conduit through which anti-cancer medications or hormones that promote the growth of the cancers enter the cells. Thus, deciphering the structure and mechanism of OATP1B1 would advance our understanding of these processes, and aid in drug design that minimizes drug-drug interactions, which is relevant to the NIH’s mission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH NARRATIVE Malaria elimination is a reachable goal in many countries of the world. Nevertheless, many countries have had a regression in their advances and are battling to get malaria elimination back on track. Some of the explanations for these difficulties are the presence of asymptomatic reservoirs and infection importation from neighboring countries. This project will investigate the relative importance of asymptomatic reservoirs, infection importation, and host immunity in the context of reduced parasite antigenic diversity to understand transmission dynamics in northwest Ecuador, a model pre-elimination setting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE T-cell lymphomas (TCLs) are highly diverse and patients with relapsed disease have a dismal prognosis. The PI3K-δγ inhibitor duvelisib induces response in 60% of patients with TCL through tumor cell-intrinsic and immunomodulatory mechanisms, but nearly all responders ultimately develop resistance. We hypothesize that the integration of spatial data, including neighborhood analyses to identify para- and juxtacrine interactions, with genetic and transcriptional alterations will inform predictive models for duvelisib response and nominate mechanisms of de novo and acquired resistance that can aid therapeutic selection and broadly applied across tumor types.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV and associated co-morbidities are prevalent in South Africa, with immunologically mediated adverse drug reactions (IM-ADRs) affecting one in five people treated for HIV and associated complications, such as tuberculosis (TB). We will establish the largest South African network of phenotype and causality adjudicated cases of severe IM-ADRs paired with a biorepository of DNA, PBMCs, blister fluid cells, plasma and skin from adults and children. This will be used to 1) identify HLA and other genetic risk factors associated with these IM- ADRs related to prevalent drugs used to treat HIV and its complications; and 2) elucidate the impact of IM-ADRs on HIV and TB treatment outcomes, as well as long-term complications of IM-ADRs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  In a previous cycle, we showed that, in older hypertensive subjects, there is an optimal blood pressure (BP) that maximizes cerebral blood flow (CBF) and decreases the risk of white matter damage. Despite these new discoveries, there is a large variance in CBF and cognition due factors other than age and BP, suggesting the need for further fine-tuning of the model for optimal BP. In this competitive renewal of our R01 HL111724 we will examine whether incomplete variants of circle of Willis increase the risk of hypoperfusion and Alzheimer's disease pathology in subjects with hypertension.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Gene expression is regulated by the integration of DNA methylation (DNAme) and other chromatin features, including chromatin accessibility, histone post-translational modifications (PTMs), chromatin remodelers, and transcription factor binding. However, our understanding of how DNAme co-occurs (and coordinates) with these features to control gene expression is limited by a lack of reliable genomic tools. Here, EpiCypher is partnering with New England Biolabs (NEB) to develop an ultra-sensitive multiomic mapping technology that delivers high resolution DNAme (5mC/5hmC) profiles at defined chromatin features, providing a powerful new approach to advance our understanding of chromatin regulation and unlock the full potential of epigenetic-targeting therapeutics and diagnostics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aging is a process that is shaped by experiences across the life course, such as social inequality and social support, yet the ability to quantify individual experience over the long human lifespan remains a hindrance to aging research. Chimpanzees, a long-lived species with close genetic and physiological similarities to humans, offer a tractable way to approach life course studies due, in part, to decades of detailed, objective observations conducted on the two longest-studied populations in Africa. Building on an initial study that developed and validated non-invasive measures of health and aging in wild chimpanzees, these aims will investigate the cumulative influences of infection and social processes on health and mortality outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Salt sensitive hypertension (SSH) is responsible for 51% of all cases of hypertension in the United States, and is a major risk factor for development of cardiovascular disease with serious social and economic impacts. Our preliminary data suggests that abnormal orexin signaling in the paraventricular nucleus (PVN), a major cardiovascular control brain region, may increase sympathetic outflow and upregulate hypothalamic-pituitary- adrenal (HPA) axis following a high salt intake, resulting in the development of SSH. Our study proposes to investigate the role and mechanism of orexin signaling in the development of SSH by means of genetic knockdown or chronic overexpression of the PVN orexin receptor combined with electrophysiological recording, as well as molecular and immunohistochemical approaches to further elucidate the signaling pathways that lead to excitatory neurochemical release, inflammation, and subsequent increased SNA outflow and dysregulated HPA axis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The inability to successfully block metastatic spread remains a significant barrier to long-term cancer survival. A key early step in the progression to metastatic disease is an increase in cell state plasticity that allows some cancer cells to adapt to new environments and take on new migratory and invasive capabilities. This flexibility involves changes in non-permanent, but relatively stable chemical modifications to the DNA packaging material and a loss of control over which genes are expressed and by how much. Our studies will determine how such epigenetic modifications cross-talk to the transcriptional machinery to enforce cell state stability and suppress breast cancer cell invasion, providing new potential avenues for therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study directly addresses recommendations from the National Cancer Institute (NCI) and American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) to urgently design and test interventions to decrease financial toxicity in cancer care. This proposal offers a proactive financial navigation program, one of the first large-scale interventions to address financial toxicity, and goes beyond evaluating financial outcomes to look at health and social outcomes in cancer patients and their spouse caregivers. Findings from this study will address the role of financial navigation in mitigating household financial hardship and its psychosocial and medical consequences and could support the inclusion of financial navigation as an essential component of high-quality cancer care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDA) is a highly aggressive cancer that up-regulates autophagy and lysosomes – acidic organelles where autophagic cargo is degraded – to maintain growth. We have identified a new role for the autophagy-lysosome pathway in targeting the major histocompatibility complex class I (MHC-I) protein for degradation as a mechanism of immune evasion. Our proposal will determine the underlying molecular mechanisms responsible for MHC-I dysregulation, with the ultimate goal of identifying new nodes that can be targeted to restore MHC-I on the surface of PDA cells and enhance immune cell mediated tumor killing.
