IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Legalization of cannabis use for adults has the potential to increase rates of cannabis, alcohol, and tobacco use among teens, young adults, and parents, all of which are serious public health problems associated with significant morbidity, mortality and poor functioning. Guided by theory that has proven useful in disentangling multiple influences on these behaviors, this project will provide information vital to preventing underage and problematic cannabis use and preventing increases in alcohol and cigarette use in the context of legalized cannabis use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Advanced non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) is the leading cause of cancer mortality worldwide with limited treatment options. This proposal utilizes biochemical and immunological techniques to investigate the mechanism of a novel pathway that induces tumor regression in NSCLC. The findings from this study will have a direct impact on the development of new therapeutic strategies for patients with this deadly disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The PLC-gamma isozymes are important clinical targets for the treatment of various cancers, yet, there are no efficacious and selective inhibitors of the PLC-gamma isozymes that can be used as leads for drug development. We propose to develop and implement a high-throughput platform to identify efficacious and selective inhibitors of the PLC-gamma isozymes. These compounds will be essential as chemical probes to dissect cellular functions of PLC- gamma isozymes and will also serve as leads for the development of drugs to treat human diseases promoted by aberrantly active PLC-gamma isozymes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Early recognition of chronic kidney disease (CKD) delays progression to kidney failure. However, preterm born children, who are high risk for kidney disease, are not routinely screened for CKD and often do not experience symptoms until the kidney damage is severe and irreversible leading to a 4-fold increase in healthcare costs. This project aims to develop a clinical risk stratification tool to help clinicians identify preterm born infants at the highest risk for kidney disease in early life to support quality screening practices and early interventions to reduce progression of CKD, improve health outcomes, and reduce health care costs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE We aim to combine wheat germ cell-free protein expression platform with active microsomes of different origin to synthesize influenza virus-like particles (VLPs). These particles will undergo detailed morphological and compositional examination using electron microscopy and native mass spectrometry to understand the architecture of obtained products and to learn the mechanisms of their assembly and composition variability. We hypothesize that this approach will be suitable for a stable and streamlined generation of Influenza VLPs and will further serve as a rapid prototyping platform for influenza vaccine development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Our Program plans to focus on a vital unmet need in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF), understanding the etiologic and initial pathogenic events in lung fibrosis so we can prevent the development of progressive and irreversible pulmonary fibrosis. We will accomplish this through 3 highly interactive Scientific Projects, 3 Research Cores, and an Administrative Core and by focusing on the initial pathogenic mechanisms, dominant risk factors, and a two-hit model of disease pathogenesis. In aggregate, we will identify key mechanisms that are critical to initiation of the fibroproliferative process that may serve as new targets for drug development, especially in early stages of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Ultrasound-triggered destruction of intravenous microbubbles has shown promise for sensitizing hepatocellular carcinoma in both preclinical models and in recent therapeutic clinical trials. However, microbubbles are constricted to the tumor blood supply and generate less than ideal shear stresses during cavitation, which may limit the total degree of tumor radiosensitization. This application will investigate the use of two acoustically- sensitive phase change nanodroplet formulations to improve radiosensitization of hepatocellular carcinoma and compare their performance to both micro- and nanobubbles.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The purpose of this proposed Midcareer Investigator Award is to mentor the next generation of patient-oriented pediatric pain scientists focused on improving the lives of youth with chronic pain and their parents. The overall objective of this K24 is to expand my current patient-oriented research and mentoring to integrate patient engagement from research to dissemination of care to improve the biobehavioral care of youth with chronic MSK pain. The proposed studies provide the ideal context for enhancing mentorship opportunities via hands- on training and scientific development in the biobehavioral aspects of pediatric chronic pain applying patient- centered methods.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research will test the hypothesis that objective social isolation and loneliness are linked to neurobehavioral mechanisms involved in social perception and motivation in individuals with and without serious mental illness. Moreover, it will investigate the specific dynamic interactions among these experiences in daily life and how they, and their neurobehavioral predictors, are linked to cardiometabolic health. The findings of this project could provide novel targets for therapeutics aimed at improving health and overall quality of life in individuals with serious mental illnesses, as well as quantitative phenotypes for use in early detection efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Recently, SPI1 gene (encoding PU.1 protein) was reported as a genetic risk factor of Alzheimer’s disease in large-scale genome-wide association studies. PU.1 is a transcription factor that is mainly expressed by myeloid lineage cells, such as microglia, monocytes, and macrophages. The overarching goal of this application is to understand the role of PU.1 in microglia and the mechanisms by which PU.1 contributes to the pathogenesis of Alzheimer’s disease using systems biology approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative It is well known that a small pool of persistently HIV-infected cells is the major obstacle to curing HIV infection. This study will examine the changes in the size of the HIV reservoir in samples collected from participants of the MERLIN acute HIV infection study (Lima, Peru) over approximately 7 years of treatment with anti-retroviral drugs. The goal is to identify features of infected cells and of HIV itself that affect the body’s ability to reduce and possibly eliminate the HIV reservoir.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pregnant and postpartum women, particularly low-income women of color, are at increased risk for developing mood and anxiety disorders. This study investigates the association of specific hormonal factors with mood and anxiety symptoms in low-income pregnant women of color. Findings can help to identify biological factors contributing to perinatal mood and anxiety disorders in at-risk populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Older adults are prone to cognitive impairment due to neurodegenerative diseases and other medical conditions with increasing age. Early identification of cognitive impairment may be identified by decision- making capacity in a variety of domains, from finance, functional outcomes, medical decision-making, and more. Based on a national consortium of interdisciplinary experts, ARMCADA will develop and validate a set of decision-making measures across the full spectrum of cognitive and decision-making competencies and incorporate nationwide dissemination into existing studies. We will also facilitate the nationwide public dissemination of these measures to target the early identification of older adults with cognitive impairment and evaluate the efficacy of potential interventions aimed to mitigate cognitive decline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Multicellular life is three-dimensional in nature, but is often reduced to a 2D planar data set to simplify analysis. Here, we will develop the methods to determine the true 3D behaviors that direct cellular motility in epithelial sheets. This is critical as epithelial tissues must be able to dynamically remodel their dimensions to generate adult tissue morphologies during development, as well as permit new cells to replace aging cells during homeostasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Prion disease is a rapidly fatal neurodegenerative disease that arises from a single protein, the native prion protein (PrP), which post-translationally converts into a misfolded, pathogenic prion; lowering PrP in the brain is robustly protective against prion disease, but difficult to achieve at the needed whole-brain scale with large gene, biologic or even oligonucleotide therapeutics. Having recently identified two small molecules that potently lower PrP with good proteomic selectivity through unknown mechanisms, we will combine targeted genetic perturbations and molecular biology follow-up with proteome-, transcriptome- and genome-wide methods in order to illuminate these novel mechanisms governing PrP expression, while also probing their in vivo relevance. Together, this work will uncover one or more new pathways networked to prion biology and provide much-needed new directions for translational efforts against this deadly disease, potentially offering clues to aid development of the first PrP-lowering small molecule drug.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Metabolic reprogramming by oncogenes and tumor suppressors has a central role in the initiation and progression of cancers, including high-risk neuroblastoma. In this application, we will investigate a new mechanism by which the oncogene MYCN integrates cholesterol synthesis with nucleotide and amino acid metabolism, which may suggest new therapeutic strategies against this deadly pediatric cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this proposal is the development of fundamentally new and more effective approaches to cancer therapy and disease pharmacology in general that will complement and enhance existing therapies. This project will develop new pharmacophores with the capacity to target the interactions between proteins and membranes directly, explore the modulation of binding properties at the protein-membrane interface, and screen for new principles governing cell permeability of small molecules which is a fundamental requirement for the bioactivity of most drugs. Combined, these approaches will create new classes of pharmacophores and methods to address cancer signaling (e.g. KRAS, PI3K, PCK etc), membrane-integrated targets (GPCRs, ion channels, enzyme- linked receptors, transporters etc.), and soluble intracellular targets at large.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The NIMH Research Domain Criteria (RDoC) represents a breakthrough framework for understanding the etiology of mental disorders, but it has no clinical traction at present. Of the RDoC units of analysis, self-report measures can be most feasibly implemented in a clinic, but many self-reports for RDoC’s Negative Valence Systems (NVS) constructs have psychometric shortcomings and lack normative data. We seek to develop psychometrically sound, brief, and validated self-report measures (questionnaires and interviews) of each NVS construct with strong normative data, contributing to advancements in psychiatric research, diagnosis, and intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative It is increasingly recognized that exposures to toxicants affect health and disease by not only mutating genes, but also by modifying the epigenome, alterations to DNA that are heritable and lead to disease when deregulated. Our research will advance the understanding of the effects of perinatal exposures (e.g. metals such as lead and endocrine disrupting chemicals such as phthalates) on the epigenome and health risks as well as develop new tools, based on the PIWI-interacting RNA (piRNA) system to transform precision environmental health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Liver damage leads to scaring of the liver in a pathologic process known as cirrhosis. This leads to many different complications resulting from high pressure in the major vein feeding the liver; this leads to severe intestinal bleeding, fluid build-up in the abdomen, and others – and to a poor quality of life. This proposal seeks to understand the cause of the high-pressure liver complications and ultimately to provide insights that will lead to new therapies to treat this problem.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative / Relevance Drug resistance remains common in advanced basal cell carcinomas (BCC), and while we have shown that the polarity kinase atypical protein kinase C (PRKCi) amplifies Gli activity and confers resistance, the mechanism remains unknown. We have found that isoforms of the Lamina-Associated Polypeptide 2 (LAP2) bind to the Gli and protect it from degradation or nuclear export while PRKCi prevents nucleoplasmic LAP2-HDAC1-GLI degradation and promotes movement from the nuclear envelope to chromatin. Completion of the project will deepen our mechanistic insights into transcription factor trafficking and regulation in the nucleus, help optimize rational BCC therapy, and identify new therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  Telomere-associated diseases, including telomere biology disorders (TBDs), are prevalent among the aging population. TBDs have diverse clinical manifestations and are characterized by multisystemic phenotypes that pose a major challenge in diagnosis. The proposed study will develop a low-cost and accurate telomere test to improve the diagnosis and management of telomere-associated diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Ectodermal dysplasias linked to mutations in the TP63 gene are characterized by severe skin erosions. The erosions subject patients to life-threatening infections and decrease patients’ quality of life. This proposal aims to uncover the pathological mechanisms causing these devastating skin manifestations, allowing for the identification of novel therapeutic strategies to treat patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: HUGO W. MOSER RES INST KENNEDY KRIEGER
PHR: Project Narrative Children who experience out-of-hospital cardiac arrest (OHCA) are at high risk for difficulties with daily functioning skills, and their caregivers experience a lot of burden. This is an ancillary grant proposal for the funded Pediatric Influence of Cooling duration on Efficacy in Cardiac Arrest Patients (P-ICECAP). The goal is to extend the follow-up period of children enrolled in P-ICECAP from the planned 1-year follow-up for up to an additional 3 years in order to learn more about later changes in function and what helps children and families continue to make gains in the years after OHCA.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it seeks to develops non-hormonal birth control directed at an ion channel in the cervix. Ion channels regulate the characteristics of mucus secreted from the body, producing mucus that can keep sperm out or allow sperm to pass through and fertilize the egg. This research would support the NICHD's mission of ensuring every person is born healthy and wanted.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: OVERALL CENTER PROJECT NARRATIVE To improve clinical translational research in a highly vulnerable population (pregnant women and fetuses), we will use our five distinct humanized feto-maternal interface organs on a chip (Microphysiologic systems [MPS]) that uses cells from pregnancy to test its utility in preclinical drug trials. We will test the repurposing of 4 FDA- approved drugs during pregnancy by testing their kinetics, metabolism, and toxicity at the feto-maternal interface. Further, these devices and cells will undergo a qualification process to determine their translational properties by closely engaging with the pharmaceutical industry end-users and submitting the data to the FDA.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: The learning health system is designed to “to generate and apply the best evidence for the collaborative healthcare choices of each patient and provider; to drive the process of discovery as a natural outgrowth of patient care; and to ensure innovation, quality, safety, and value in healthcare.” Vanderbilt is committed to establishing the Realizing Accelerated Progress, Investigation, Implementation, and Dissemination in Learning Health Systems (RAPID-LHS) Center to develop a cadre of scientists formally trained and well versed in the best methods for engaging and improving the learning health system. The RAPID-LHS Center will train future scientists and provide support in the following areas of strength: 1) patient-centered outcomes research; 2) dissemination and implementation science; 3) health policy/public health; 4) stakeholder engagement, community health, and health equity; 5) methods advancement.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Narrative Within VA, among Veterans who have hypertension or diabetes, racial/ethnic minority Veterans are less likely than white Veterans to have these conditions under control. Some of the factors that can lead to poor control of these conditions may be related to the type of health care that the person receives, whereas other factors may be outside of the control of the health care system. Health care sites can sometimes deliver care in a way that will result in more patients achieving good control of their hypertension and diabetes. Our aims are to identify health care sites where there are fewer differences by race/ethnicity and by socio-economic status in the percentage of patients with good control of hypertension and diabetes, and to understand what some of the characteristics of patients, and their health care settings are that are associated with better control of these conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this two-site proposal is to determine whether and by what means insulin resistance, in the form of impaired insulin regulation of microvascular perfusion, leads to decreased exercise capacity in men and women with type 2 diabetes. Data from our two research teams suggest that the cardiac and skeletal muscle microvascular dysfunction present in people with T2D contributes to limitations in cardiac and skeletal muscle oxygenation and function associated with impaired function exercise capacity (a major predictor of CV and all cause mortality). Understanding the role of microvascular disease in the diabetes-mediated exercise impairment may offer novel targets for intervention to improve exercise capacity, functional status and longevity in people with diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Memory B cells are important for immune defense against influenza infection and for successful vaccination. Influenza-specific memory B cells reside at systemic sites and in the lung, where they provide protection to against infection, however, we do not understand how memory B cells in different locations are related, what their functional properties are or what subsets might be triggered by vaccination. This proposal will define the lineage relationships and functional properties of influenza-specific memory B cells.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative  Successful ovulation and subsequent corpus luteum formation and development are essential for female fertility. In the present proposal, we will demonstrate for the first time that the FOS/AP-1 transcription factor plays an essential role in ovulation and corpus luteum formation in both humans and mice. Information derived from the present proposal will provide novel insights into the mechanism(s) underlying ovulation and luteal formation and can be applied for promoting and inhibiting the critical facet of ovarian physiology, thereby allowing us to effectively manage fertility in women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This Centers of Biomedical Research Excellence (COBRE) proposal establishes a Center for Rural Health Care Delivery Science at Dartmouth-Hitchcock Health (D-HH), a rural academic health system. The Center will concentrate its efforts on understanding and solving challenges associated with the provision of health care in rural areas, focusing on a community-engaged approach to research. It will also mentor and support a critical mass of early-career clinician-scientists as they transition into independent researchers dedicated to decreasing health care disparities in rural communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative (Public Health Relevance Statement) Copper is an essential metal nutrient that is required for physiological functions spanning respiration and metabolism to antioxidant defense. Loss of copper homeostasis resulting from a combination of genetics, environment, diet, and lifestyle is connected to diseases including cancer, heart and neurodegenerative diseases, and metabolic disorders like obesity and diabetes. We are developing new chemical reagents for copper imaging and proteomics in biological systems to help decipher how copper contributes to healthy and disease states and target copper-dependent disease vulnerabilities, focusing on the contributions of copper and oxidative stress in cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Five and a half million Americans are being robbed of their functioning brains by Alzheimer’s Disease (AD), without benefit of any drug to halt their decline into dementia. To develop effective drugs, we take the approach that has been effective for treating cancer and HIV-AIDS: structure-based drug design. Applying the powerful tools of electron microscopy and x-ray diffraction, we learn the atomic structures of the toxic aggregates believed to trigger AD, and then knowing the placement of atoms, design drugs that interfere with formation of these aggregates, disaggregate them, and inhibit their toxic spread throughout the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative With the development of proteolysis targeting chimeras (PROTACs), a new dimension in drug discovery has emerged. This project proposes to develop and test novel cancer therapeutic PROTACs aimed at targeting the PD-L1 receptor protein, thus infringing upon tumor inhibition of T-cell activation which is a common immune evasion strategy of many cancer types. Conclusions drawn from this study will provide important preliminary insight as to whether PROTACs that recruit extracellular E3 ubiquitin ligases can be utilized to induce degradation of cancer-associated membrane proteins, thereby showcasing a new frontier in oncological drug discovery research.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE Historically, Colombia has been a focal point of tropical and infectious disease research. The post-conflict strategy of the government of Colombia has prioritized development and improvement of health in rural areas impacted by over 5 decades of conflict. Communities in these areas are among the most affected by leishmaniasis and other vector-borne and emerging infectious diseases and have chronically limited access to healthcare. This training program will prepare a cohort of new investigators in CIDEIM and other Colombian institutions and strengthen their research and training capacity to enable the implementation of the results of research on these diseases, into practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Morbidity of SARS-CoV-2 in Malawi and other sub-Saharan African countries have been lower than elsewhere in the world. One possible explanation is the high prevalence of infectious diseases such as malaria and helminthiasis that can elicit immunity that may affect susceptibility to progression of SARS-CoV-2; the same factors may influence immunity induced by SARS-CoV-2 vaccines. Understanding the epidemiology for SARS- CoV-2, as well as the population immunological substrate in countries like Malawi will be important to define cost-effective SARS-CoV-2 vaccination policies to the region.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: This project proposes to assemble the largest biomarker cohort of African Americans for Alzheimer disease (AD) by leveraging on both the existing biomarker samples and data from five major biomarker studies of AD and prospectively collected biomarker samples and imaging scans from these studies. The potential racial disparity in molecular biomarkers of AD, as well as in their predictability to subsequent cognitive outcomes, if confirmed by the proposed study on the largest AA biomarker cohort, may imply differential treatment responses between races, and hence will have profound implications to the design and analyses of ongoing and future prevention and treatment trials of AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to use state of the art bioengineering to model the 3D laminar circuit of the human cerebellum, growing human pluripotent stem cell-derived cerebellar Purkinje cells and granule neurons in layers on glass wafers and defining their functional connectivity and transcriptome vs native tissue. We will then develop the first protocols to differentiate unipolar brush cells to modulate the circuit. This platform will prove invaluable for modeling human cerebellar function and dysfunction as well as for drug discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This multi-PI project focuses on the role of the long ascending and descending propriospinal neurons (LAPNs, LDPNs) in the control of locomotion and recovery after a spinal cord injury. We will use a combination of viral based synaptic silencing, retrograde and trans-synaptic tracing and comprehensive gait and kinematic analysis to aid the development of a neuro-biomechanical computer model and to generate important new knowledge of spinal locomotor circuitry.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Toddler milk, an ultra-processed milk-based drink recommended for children ages 9-36 months, often contains added sugar in its composition as well as scientifically unsupported marketing claims on the front-of-package (FOP) label. Research is urgently needed about parents’ understanding of toddler milk FOP claims, and this study will directly fill this gap by examining how toddler milk marketing influences parental perceptions and beliefs via a systematic review, packaging content analysis, and focus groups with parents. Contributing scientific evidence related to the food industry's marketing practices of toddler milk and how they affect parents' beliefs and perceptions of the product could inform the FDA and policymakers, informing future regulation of toddler milk packaging.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Neighborhoods that experienced historical segregation and community-level disinvestment based on decades of discriminatory race-based policies rooted in racism have infant mortality rates (IMR) that are over 20 deaths per 1,000 live births (2%) with racial disparity ratios nearing three. The objective of this proposal is to describe historical and contemporary discriminatory policies influencing IMR and other maternal and child health experiences and outcomes across generations of Black women and importantly, demonstrate how community re-investment can be designed to target and rectify historic and contemporary structural racism and discrimination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is the third leading cause of mortality in the US and worldwide. Mucus hypersecretion and tissue damage in COPD contribute to severe airflow obstruction and death, but they are not effectively treated. This proposal aims to identify mechanisms of how excessive mucus contributes to tissue destruction, and whether disruption of mucus production is protective in COPD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: OVERALL: DIRECTOR'S OVERVIEW & SIX ESSENTIAL CHARACTERISTICS  PROJECT NARRATIVE The Chao Family Comprehensive Cancer Center (CFCCC) of the University of California, Irvine (UCI) is the only academic cancer center based in Orange County, the sixth most populous county in the United States with over 3.2 million residents who embody substantial socioeconomic and racial/ethnic diversity. Designated as a comprehensive cancer center by the National Cancer Institute since 1997 and backed by the research enterprise of UCI, a member of the Association of American Universities, the CFCCC carries out research across the spectrum of cancer including fundamental mechanisms of cancer development, novel modes of detection and imaging, new anti-cancer drugs and devices, and cancer susceptibility, prevention and survivorship. Through its research programs and supporting resources, the CFCCC translates these discoveries through the pipeline into clinical treatments and interventions that are directed specifically towards reducing the burden of cancer on the multi-ethnic population of Orange County and surrounding areas, and advances this new knowledge onto a wider stage to change clinical cancer practice across the country.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ABCD Study consortium uses multimodal brain imaging, cognitive and clinical assessments, bioassays, mobile monitoring, and careful assessment of substance use, environment, psychopathological symptoms, and social functioning in 11,878 9-10 year-olds to be followed over 10 years, to determine the effects of substance use on adolescent brain and cognitive development. This ABCD Research Project Site will follow and assess participants enrolled in the study. These data will be shared with the scientific community to address a comprehensive range of questions concerning youth development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NRG Oncology seeks to improve the lives of adult patients with gender-specific malignancies (breast, gynecologic, prostate cancers) and/or localized or locally advanced cancer through the development and conduct of a portfolio of timely and relevant clinical trials. NRG uniquely focuses on this large and relatively under-investigated group of cancer patients and has extraordinary scientific accomplishments specific to the group's three specific aims. NRG actively assists in the management of the NCI - National Clinical Trial Network (NCTN) and collaborates with the other NCTN partners in the overall conduct of all NCTN trials.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Every day, 50.1 million children ages 5 to 18 years attend grades K-12. About 27% of those children suffer from at least one medical condition requiring them to take medication at school. Up to 48% of school nurses reported that they made a medication administration error at school. In this study, we will be implementing a technology, similar to the one used in hospitals, to reduce medication errors at schools.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Assuring Medication Safety in K-12 Schools: Implementing and Evaluating the Electronic School Medication Administration Record (E-SMAR) System

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE: Clamping and cutting the umbilical cord at birth occurs for each of the 140 million neonates born annually. The significant public health advantages of delayed cord clamping (DCC) over early cord clamping (ECC) for healthy newborns has not been studied in neonates with critical congenital heart disease (CCHD), a population with a high frequency of adverse outcomes and, correspondingly, the potential for substantial benefit from ameliorative interventions. The studies described in the present proposal are relevant to NIH's mission to understand the processes of human growth and development, by determining, via a multicenter randomized clinical trial, whether, among neonates born with CCHD, DCC provides better outcomes post cardiac surgery or catheterization, as measured by a validated composite measure (global rank scores) and neurodevelopmental outcomes, than are observed with ECC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Greater than two-thirds of mid-life and older adults are overweight or obese, and older adults with obesity face greater risk of disability, cognitive impairment, impaired mobility, and higher medical expenses. Thus, lifestyle interventions which promote moderate, sustainable weight loss among mid-life and older adults with overweight or obesity are needed. As there are currently no evidence-based water intake recommendations for weight control, we aim to address this research gap by investigating premeal water as a low-cost dietary strategy that could be incorporated into clinical practice guidelines for obesity treatment, and improve adherence to a hypocaloric diet prescription through reduced hunger, increased fullness, and improved cognitive function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will determine the contribution of defects in oxidative phosphorylation to the development of fibrosis in benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). Specifically, this project aims to investigate the mitochondrial changes associated with aging to develop a better understanding of how oxidative phosphorylation is driving disease. This work will provide new avenues for biomarker development and treatment targets.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Humans begin as fertilized eggs that coordinate the transformation into our familiar forms with biomolecules called proteins. Malfunctioning proteins can consequently result in birth defects, and emerging data has revealed many novel small proteins with the potential to affect human development. This study will discover the roles of these small proteins in development using an innovative system that targets and destroys protein making templates in the developmentally informative model zebrafish towards a better understanding of the players that cause human birth defects and diseases with developmental origins.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Adults with traumatic brain injury (TBI) have deficits in flexible and goal-directed behavior that have been linked to disruptions in the frontal lobes, but treatments designed to target the frontal lobes, and their functions, do not yield significant improvements in behavior, community reintegration, or independence. We propose that the frontal lobes may be too limiting a means for improving flexible and goal- directed behavior and aim to show the contribution of hippocampal relational memory to the observed behavioral dysfunction and poor outcomes in individuals with TBI. This proposal is unique in the field and uniquely promising for understanding the nature of behavioral dysfunction in TBI and, ultimately, improving rehabilitation intervention outcomes

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ABCD Study consortium uses multimodal brain imaging, cognitive and clinical assessments, bioassays, mobile monitoring, and careful assessment of substance use, environment, psychopathological symptoms, and social functioning in 11,878 9-10 year-olds to be followed over 10 years, to determine the effects of substance use on adolescent brain and cognitive development. This ABCD Research Project Site will follow and assess participants enrolled in the study. These data will be shared with the scientific community to address a comprehensive range of questions concerning youth development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to reveal mechanisms of communication between skeletal muscle extracellular matrix and the fibroadipogenic progenitor cells that produce progressive fibrotic cycles in muscular disease. The robustness of the fibrotic cycle will be tested by interrupting the pro-fibrotic signaling through clinical gene therapy of the initiating muscle instability. Investigation of these mechanisms and their durability using innovative methodologies in mice and humans with fibrotic muscular dystrophy uncover specific targets for therapies to block and reverse progressive fibrotic pathologies and augment the efficacy of potential gene therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Neural degeneration of the cholinergic neurons within the pedunculopontine nucleus (PPN) correlates with the severity of motor impairment in Parkinson's disease (PD). However, the role of the PPN within the basal ganglia circuit for motor output has not yet been comprehensively dissected making it unclear how its degeneration contributes to motor deficits in PD. This study is relevant to the mission of NIH because it aims to characterize the synaptic properties, regional connectivity, and closed-loop circuits between the major inhibitory basal ganglia nuclei, SNr and GPe, and rostral and caudal PPN to suggest new therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite representing only 1% of all children in the US, children with medical complexity (CMC) account for one third of hospital expenditures and have 30-day readmission rates of 20%. The overarching goal of this study is to design a heath literacy-informed tool and test its efficacy in improving parent comprehension of/adherence to discharge instructions and reducing post-hospitalization morbidity for CMC. This study has the potential to transform discharge processes for CMC, providing a model for a family-centered, evidence-based, scalable approach to achieve National Academy of Medicine goals of safe, effective, patient-centered, and equitable transitions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative We will use high-throughput mutagenesis to map which amino acids in the protein sequence are essential for function and which subset of these are involved in communicating the coupling of DNA binding and ATP hydrolysis in a DNA polymerase clamp loader, a member of the family of complex molecular machines called AAA+ ATPases. We will also use statistical models trained on genome sequences of clamp loaders from diverse organisms to infer the essential constraints on and between amino acids in clamp loaders and test these inferences in a biological context. The aims of this project represent a unified body of work to use new assay systems to understanding clamp loader and AAA+ mechanism, and to test the potential for engineering complex macromolecular machines using our sequence-based design.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We offer a comprehensive two-year multidisciplinary training program in cardiovascular epidemiology for MDs and PhDs to pursue a successful scientific research career addressing contemporary training needs of the specialty. The program will graduate five postdoctoral scholars every two years in three different training tracks (clinical translational epidemiology, statistical genetics-genomics, and bioinformatics-computational biology), with enrollment of at least 50% women and 20% scholars from underrepresented groups. We will provide our scholars with multidisciplinary training that includes a broad educational curriculum to develop core competencies, research projects under the supervision of outstanding faculty, comprehensive mentorship, and appropriate career and professional developmental support to ensure their future success.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have discovered a new pathway, which we have termed Secretory Autophagy during Lysosome Inhibition (SALI), that promotes packaging and secretion of extracellular vesicles and particles. This proposal will dissect whether and how SALI controls the delicate balance of secretion and intracellular trafficking of disease-relevant proteins in microglia to promote neurodegeneration in Frontotemporal Dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is significantly more common in females than males, and females carry greater risk for developing AD; however, the reason for these sex differences remains unknown. The proposed project aims to explore the interaction between the menopausal transition and accompanied decreases in estrogen on brain networks supporting memory in females at risk for AD. The insight gained from this research will increase our understanding of the neurobiological and neuroendocrine processes underlying sex differences in AD and will aid the early detection of AD, which is crucial for intervening and slowing disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative. Targeting of immune negative checkpoint regulator (NCR) pathways is revolutionizing the treatment of human cancers and has established that these pathways are proven clinical targets in human disease. VISTA (V-region Immunoglobulin-containing Suppressor of T cell Activation), is a recently identified, NCR ligand/receptor and we have produced antibodies that can trigger through VISTA and induce immune suppression. Our studies show that triggering through VISTA can exert significant impact on the inflammation mediated by the innate immune system. The studies presented will provide comprehensive insight into the mechanisms of suppression of innate immunity by anti-VISTA. .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative RNA splicing is a fundamental step in normal gene expression, involving the precise removal of non-coding segments during the maturation of messenger RNA. Abnormal RNA splicing due to mutations in gene sequences that control the process, or to alterations in the splicing machinery, gives rise to a wide variety of diseases. By studying the fundamental mechanisms responsible for RNA-splicing specificity, and ways in which this process can be manipulated, the proposed research will facilitate the correct classification of mutations that affect splicing, and the design of more effective RNA-targeted therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Though Alzheimer’s disease was first described more than a century ago and the protein hallmarks (plaques and tangles) were identified decades ago, we now know that the proteins of both the plaques and tangles are composed of Aβ and tau prions, respectively. Being able to measure these two prions using rapid cultured cell bioassays in conjunction with transgenic rodent models, we are now able to attack many areas of Alzheimer’s disease research that were previously inaccessible. Structural transitions that feature in the transformation of the Aβ and tau proteins into prions can now be investigated at the atomic level as described in this application.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Aging is often accompanied by cognitive deficits and is also the major risk factor for Alzheimer's disease (AD). This multi-component research program studies a rodent model of naturally occurring variation in cognitive aging, with the goal of understanding the neurobiological basis of impairment and preservation of brain function that could contribute to vulnerability and resilience, respectively, in AD. Building on existing therapeutic progress, work within this program will continue to contribute to the development of effective therapeutic interventions for cognitive decline in aging with potential for slowing late-onset AD progression in its earliest phases.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JAMES H QUILLEN VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE Patients with HIV infection often do not respond well to HBV vaccinations, and this phenomenon is also observed in other immunocompromised hosts, including the elderly, but the overall efforts to boost vaccine hypo- responsiveness in these subjects have been futile - in part due to our poor understanding of the underlying mechanisms that blunt vaccine responses. We have shown that chronic HIV or HCV infection can accelerate premature T cell aging due to telomere attrition - a hallmark of cellular senescence; however, the underlying mechanisms remain largely unknown. In this proposal, we will investigate how chronic HIV infection induces telomere attrition and T cell aging and how these molecular changes lead to HBV vaccine failure during HIV infection. This study will enhance our understanding of the fundamental mechanisms underlying immune aging in chronic viral infection and develop effective means to restore immune competence and improve vaccine efficacy in HIV-infected patients. It will also provide insight into common mechanisms of vaccine hypo- responsiveness under other immunocompromised conditions. It is thus clinically significant and timely.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This project brings together the complementary expertise of two laboratories to tackle the challenges of developing a wide variety of organo- and metal-catalyzed amination reactions to prepare structurally diverse chiral amines. Olefins will be directly converted to enantiomerically enriched NH- and N-alkylaziridines via catalytically-generated N-electrophilic oxaziridines, ketimines and ketiminoesters will furnish fully-substituted amines upon catalytic asymmetric allylation, while arenes will be converted to the corresponding chiral and sterically hindered N-alkylanilines via catalytic C-H amination and using novel electrophilic aminating agents with previously inaccessible structural complexity. The resulting unprotected amine products are highly prized by the synthetic/medicinal chemistry communities and the new environmentally friendly chemical transformations (i.e., green chemistry) that emerge will expedite synthetic access to and reduce the production cost of highly functionalized nitrogen-containing materials and ultimately will lead to the faster development of new medicines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Altered levels of FGF23, a bone-derived hormone necessary for regulating blood phosphate and vitamin D levels, is associated with several human diseases that affect bone development and bone health, as well as the integrity and the functioning of some other organs, such as the heart. We aim elucidating the mechanisms governing FGF23 production in bone, focusing on a mechanistic cellular pathway that has not been previously recognized to be involved in this important process. Our studies will likely aid in the generation of new and effective treatments for disorders caused or affected by altered FGF23 levels or activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Our ability to understand patterns in energy intake (EI), and to intervene on them to improve health, is limited by our inability to unobtrusively and reliably monitor EI in the context of daily life. We propose to investigate the use of smartwatch and smart ring devices to automatically detect intake gestures (“bites” of food, “drinks” of beverage) during mealtimes, and to evaluate the degree to which key demographic variables and contextual factors (e.g., dietary composition, food source) can be used in combination with intake gesture counts to reliably estimate EI. We will validate this sensor-based EI estimation approach across multiple settings (cafeteria, home, and free living) by comparing the sensor-based EI estimates to ground truth EI from video recordings (in cafeteria and home) and remote food photography (during free-living), and will implement the optimal validated approach via a free and publicly-available platform that guides researchers/clinicians in executing sensor-based EI self-monitoring protocols.

PHR: Narrative The proposed program will provide support for postgraduate research training in the Department of Anesthesiology at McGovern Medical School as part of the University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston to qualified applicants who have committed to or are enrolled in postgraduate training in anesthesiology. The goal of this training is to provide the next generation of physician- scientists and researchers with the tools and training necessary for those who seek to improve medical care in areas relevant to perioperative care, palliative care, acute and chronic pain and health services delivery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The primary goal of the U-RISE program at San Jose State University is to improve the academic preparedness and research training in biomedical research for high performing undergraduate minority students. We have gained extensive experience in training URM students over the past 30 years and the U-RISE program will allow our highly dedicated research mentors to continue playing a pivotal role in this process. We ultimately intend to prepare our trainees to enter competitive Ph.D. or M.D./Ph.D. programs where they will be highly productive scientists who will not only help contribute to the improvements in human health for many years to come, but will also increase the diversity of the scientific workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative-Relevance to Public Health We propose to develop a novel bioinspired 1-cell culture technology for isolating cancer stem cells (CSCs) that are capable of cross-tissue multilineage differentiation from cancer patients’ tumors, and to further utilize the CSCs for engineering 3D vascularized tumors using an innovative bottom-up strategy. This project may lay the foundation for creating novel high-fidelity CSC-based 3D tumor models to accelerate cancer drug discovery and for developing effective CSC-targeted therapies to combat cancer drug resistance-induced cancer recurrence and metastasis that are the main causes of mortality in cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Nearly half (46%) of US women diagnosed with breast cancer are overweight or obese and at an elevated risk for poor prognosis. The proposed research will improve the understanding of how energy imbalance affects breast cancer outcomes and the role of mTOR pathway activation as a targetable mediator in breast tumors, which will ultimately reveal novel strategies for improving clinical outcomes. The proposed research is in line with the part of NIH’s mission of developing fundamental knowledge that will contribute to reducing the burden of breast cancer.

PHR: Project Narrative Implementation science focuses on the translation of successful interventions into practice so that the people that need those interventions receive them. The Vietnam Implementation Science Advancement program will provide training to Vietnamese academic faculty, policymakers, program leaders, and students to develop HIV- related implementation science capacity. The program uses a depth and diffusion model to rapidly expand implementation science knowledge and skills in Vietnam.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ABCD Study consortium uses multimodal brain imaging, cognitive and clinical assessments, bioassays, mobile monitoring, and careful assessment of substance use, environment, psychopathological symptoms, and social functioning in 11,878 9-10 year-olds to be followed over 10 years, to determine the effects of substance use on adolescent brain and cognitive development. This ABCD Research Project Site will follow and assess participants enrolled in the study. These data will be shared with the scientific community to address a comprehensive range of questions concerning youth development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Breast cancer is the leading cause of cancer among women, with breast conserving surgery (BCS) often recommended as a standard treatment. Residual tumor left after BCS is a persistent concern due to its association with cancer recurrence, need for additional surgery, potential to cause patient anxiety, and risk for poor cosmetic outcomes. Here, we offer a new imaging strategy that can provide real-time feedback to the surgical team during the operation, as opposed to after the surgery has ended, to better guide breast tumor removal to reduce the need for additional surgeries and improve patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK STATE PSYCHIATRIC INSTITUTE DBA RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR MENTAL HYGIENE, INC
PHR: 8. Project Narrative Research to date has found inequities in cardiovascular disease and related health behaviors in the U.S. gender minority population. This study will be the first to determine the relationship between minority stress, resilience, mental health, and cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk factors (blood pressure, sleep and physical activity, tobacco use, and BMI) in a diverse sample of the U.S. gender minority population, using both self-report and objectively measured data. Findings will inform the development and testing of future intervention strategies aimed at reducing CVD risk and promoting the health and wellbeing of this and other vulnerable populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Various age-associated chromatin changes have been causally linked to aging. The cellular response to chromatin architectural defects (CAD response) is activated by chromatin stress and promotes longevity. This project will investigate the specific roles of CAD response in antagonizing age-associated chromatin changes and the mechanistic details on its regulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tuberculosis (TB) remains a global health problem with an estimated 10 million new infections and 1.2 million deaths per year despite existing effective chemotherapies that are long due to the presence of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) subpopulation called “persisters”. We have discovered that arginine starvation leads to rapid sterilization of Mtb in vitro as well as in mice and, by using fragment-based drug design, we have identified two scaffold molecules that bind and inhibit the enzymatic activity of ArgB. This proposal seeks to optimize scaffold molecules to novel drugs that rapidly sterilize cultures of Mtb and expanding the drug target space by further validating other enzymes in the pathway as potential drug targets providing new drug possibilities and new insights to shorten TB chemotherapy and to treat Multidrug-resistant Mtb strains.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In humans, risk factors for Alzheimer’s disease (AD) include aging and genetic risk factors implicated in altering brain inflammation and microglia, the resident immune cell of the brain, suggesting that factors that shape these responses can alter pathology. We have shown that CD8+ T cells increase in the CNS during the process of tauopathy or age-associated amyloidosis, lending evidence to an emerging idea that peripheral adaptive immune cells (i.e. CD4+T cells, CD8+ T cells, B cells) may also play a role in shaping central nervous system (CNS) pathology and microglial function. The goal of this proposal is to determine how CD8+ T cells impact cognition, neuroinflammation, gliosis, microglial transcriptomes and pathology observed during the process of age-associated amyloidosis or tauopathy, the two hallmark pathological features of AD, and define the transcriptomic profiles of CNS CD8+ T cells.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Zebrafish International Resource Center 1) provides a central repository for zebrafish wild-type, transgenic, and mutated genetic stocks, and other research materials, 2) provides consultation and pathology services, and 3) researches and develops husbandry standards such as the composition of diets, nutrition requirements, and food management strategies that support ZIRC and research community husbandry goals. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Hereditary Multiple Exostoses (HME) is a potentially severe disorder that affects about 1 in 50,000 children and adolescents worldwide and is characterized by benign cartilage tumors called osteochondromas. HME is associated with growth retardation, skeletal deformities, chronic pain, limited mobility and fatigue, and is linked to life-threatening malignant transformation in about 2-3% of patients. There are no cures or effective treatments at the moment, and this project thus aims to further clarify the mechanisms of osteochondroma pathogenesis and test specific therapeutic treatments to prevent their formation and growth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have been extremely successful in mapping genetic determinants of common disease and traits, however, they do not identify the causal variants and genes per se, and a large fraction of heritable risk/variation remains unmapped. Our proposed studies are based on the hypotheses that a) common sequence variation in specific cis-regulatory elements (CREs) influence expression of specific genes and, thereby, underlie disease risk or trait variation, and b) genes underlying diseases and traits are often functionally related and expressions of functionally related genes are often co-regulated. In this proposal, we develop strategies to identify specific CRE variants and causal genes at mapped electrocardiographic QT interval GWAS loci, and to uncover additional, yet unmapped QT interval genes through regulatory networks, and expect the knowledge gained to have a significant contribution to genetics of QT interval variation and sudden cardiac death risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: LEGACY EMANUEL HOSPITAL AND HEALTH CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Powerful memories are associated with drug-taking behavior over extended periods, and these memories drive relapse to drugs of abuse. We will use a well-established rodent model of cocaine addiction to identify how the prefrontal cortex and associated circuits can be modified to reduce cocaine relapse. These studies have translational potential in humans because disruption of cocaine-related memories is expected to help break the cycle of relapse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Approximately one in two individuals with bipolar disorder (BD) are non-adherent with medication, often leading to severe and negative consequences. Unfortunately,there is no widely used evidence -based approach to target poor adherence among individuals with BD. Building upon positive efficacy trial r esults, the proposed project will test the effectiveness of technology-facilitated Customized Adherence Enhancement (CAE) vs. enhanced treatment as usual (eTAU) using a prospective randomized controlled design in public mental health care settings and preferentially enrolling poorly adherent/high-risk individuals with BD. Deliverables include a curriculum-driven adherence enhancement approach that can be implemented in public healthcare settings and which can improve outcomes for the most vulnerable groups of people with BD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Malaria affects over two billion people, killing over 400,000 individuals each year mostly children in Africa. A powerful tool is needed for eliminating Plasmodium falciparum malaria from defined geographical areas. The ideal tool would be a highly effective, long-acting vaccine that prevents infection, and thereby disease and parasite transmission. There is currently no alternative to clinical trials for demonstrating that a vaccine candidate exhibits performance superior to current SPZ vaccines Therefore, in this project we will develop in vitro assays and/or non-human primate (NHP) models that indicate if a human will be protected against Pf infection by a SPZ vaccine, and use them to show superiority of new SPZ vaccines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Co-use of tobacco and cannabis has been increasing, especially among young adults. Recent changes in the popularity of electronic nicotine delivery systems (ENDS) as well as in the growing number of states legalizing recreational cannabis use increase the public health concern related to the upsurge in co-use. The overall goal of this study is to examine the situational, momentary factors associated with the different patterns of tobacco and cannabis co-use, how they may vary by delivery mode, and how they are associated with changes in behavioral outcomes (e.g., dependence, changes in rates of use, problem behaviors) – data which will be helpful for informing prevention, intervention, and policy approaches to reduce harm from both products.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative One major reason for the current obesity epidemic and its associated lack of effective treatment is due to incomplete understanding of neuronal control of complex feeding behavior. Using a combination of optogenetic and mouse genetic approaches, the current proposal will define a novel neural pathway from melancortin receptor 4-expressing neurons in the paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus (PVH) to Leptin receptor expressing neurons in the lateral septum neurons that regulates feeding through a glutamatergic monosysnpatic projection. The results will identify a previously unknown circuit that are critical for feeding regulation and therefore form a foundation for effective treatments for aberrant feeding behaviors and obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The protein on the surface of the HIV virus is coated with a dense network of carbohydrates. Some of the best antibodies generated in natural HIV infection bind to these carbohydrates, but such antibodies normally arise too late to eliminate the infection, if they arise at all. This project will develop synthetic, stabilized variants of these carbohydrates, which will be tested as vaccines to stimulate carbohydrate- binding antibodies that may protect against HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Breast cancer is the leading cancer in women and claims about 40,000 lives in the United States every year. Metastasis account for 90% of breast cancer deaths. In order to develop effective treatments against cancer, we need to better understand the cellular and molecular mechanism underlying metastasis. Using clinical specimens, patient-derived xenograft models, and other cell line and models along with cutting-edge technology, this project aims to identify a novel mechanism critical for circulating tumor cell cluster formation and targeting strategies to block metastasis, thereby eventually contributing to a reduced mortality rate of breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Over 850 million people suffer from some form of proteinuric kidney disease worldwide, which is more than double the number of diabetics, but current drugs remain woefully inadequate in preventing the resulting progressive loss of kidney function. Proteinuria is caused by diseases that impair the normal function of kidney podocytes thus disrupting the kidney filtration barrier leading to protein loss in urine, but how podocyte function is impaired at the structural level is unclear. In preliminary studies, we show that activation of a specific podocyte receptor by disease elicits maladaptive changes in podocytes, which we propose to define at the atomic structure level and aim to effectively prevent in preclinical studies using novel inhibitors of this receptor.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite dramatic improvements in outcome for children with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), a significant number of children and more adolescents/young adults fail frontline therapy and their prognosis is dismal. While patients with prolonged remission have a better prognosis, most eventually succumb to their disease due to the emergence of resistant clones, despite increased intensity of frontline therapies. In this study, we will investigate how the reorganization of 3D chromatin architecture contributes to transformation and patients’ relapse in the most common form of ALL, B ALL.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: The goal of this project is to provide better ways of understanding relations between the different domains or levels of language in language disorders and language development. To do this, we will provide complete phonological and fluency annotations of 200 transcripts taken from the databases for aphasia, dementia, child language disorders, and childhood disfluency. We will improve the capacity of the Phon program and the TalkBankDB database search system to operate with data across these different data types. This will allow us to conduct analyses of patterns that consider relations between the different language domains of phonology, fluency, lexicon, grammar, and discourse. These patterns will also be captured through analyses that seek to align the profiles of individual participants with comparison groups from the larger database.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Currently, there are limited home-based exercise fall prevention interventions, especially those built on scientific evidence, available for broad dissemination to community-dwelling older adults who are at high risk for falls. This project evaluates an evidence-based tai ji quan intervention that is delivered in a home setting via videoconference technology. The intervention is intended to help older adults reduce falls and improve physical and cognitive function, and the results from this study will inform alternative preventative strategies for utilization of evidence-based fall prevention interventions in clinical and community settings.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Post-traumatic osteoarthritis can result from a single or repetitive injury and is a major cause of disability in younger individuals as well as a major concern for Veterans who are at an increased risk from this condition. Currently, there is no effective treatment for this disease. Regenerative medicine therapies involving reparative cells, such as stem cells, reveal promising evidence in healing osteoarthritic lesions. Following transplantation, stem cells face several stress factors such as inflammatory mediators and oxygen-free radicals. This environment induces cell death and apoptosis after transplantation. We propose a hypothesis that a two-step anti-inflammatory and antioxidant-nanosome treatment strategy can improve the toxic micro- environment of the arthritic knee joint by delivering TPCA1-nanosome, and also prolong the ASCs’ viability to obtain enough time to survive by their immune-suppressive activity. We will use this interventional approach for the treatment of the knee in a PTOA animal model for pre-clinical translational research for patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol consumption is an important modifiable lifestyle risk factor for cardiovascular disease (CVD). Advances in high-throughput technologies have made it possible to measure and analyze a variety of ‘omics’ (DNA methylation, gene expression, protein and metabolite) in relation to alcohol consumption and CVD in a cost- efficient manner with existing resources. With completion of this project, we will have better understanding of the alcohol-associated molecular mechanisms between alcohol consumption and CVD, and highlight novel targets for the prevention and treatment of alcohol-associated CVD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed program represents a multi-faceted approach to multi-disciplinary undergraduate education, involvement of individuals from diverse groups in gerontechnology research, and preparation of individuals at many levels to meet the nation's need for gerontechnology research. The result of this project will be to educate groups of undergraduates in a multidisciplinary manner to prepare them for graduate school and research careers in the field. Additionally, the remote speakers, online materials, and symposia will bring in other researchers, teachers, and industry members to help spread knowledge about this field and its long-term impacts on our society. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project narrative Through a randomized control trial and subsequent stepped-wedge designed study in high- volume facilities providing male circumcision (MC) in South Africa, we will demonstrate that two- way texting (2wT) between providers and patients increases adverse event (AE) ascertainment while reducing provider workload as compared to routine, in-person follow-up. Implementation science methods and costing analysis will rigorously evaluate 2wT, determining how to optimize 2wT-2-SCALE within routine MC program settings. It is expected that 2wT-2-SCALE will be a cost-effective method to improve MC efficiency and AE ascertainment at scale, enabling rapid, sustainable improvement in the quality of MC services at the population level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) and its relatives are important drivers in several cancers, and are the targets of therapeutic inhibitors that block activation by attacking either the growth factor-binding or signaling kinase domains. The work proposed in this application will leverage our new mechanistic insights – alongside accumulating clinical mutation data – to explore whether agents that bias rather than block receptor signaling may reprogram cancer cells, and will also provide new insight to guide optimal inhibitor choice in different cancer settings where resistance occurs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE BARD1 (BRCA1-Associated RING Domain protein-1) is an essential partner of the breast cancer susceptibility protein BRCA1 and is included in clinical panels of genes used to evaluate patients with suspected hereditary cancer predisposition, especially breast and ovarian cancers. Despite this, almost nothing is known about the cellular role of BARD1. This project aims to address this serious gap in knowledge by defining at a molecular level how BARD1 contributes to DNA damage repair and transcriptional repression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cellular volume control and protein phosphoregulation are fundamental processes in biology, and their misregulation have been linked to several diseases and developmental defects. Using novel genetic tools in the model plant Arabidopsis, we will elucidate PP2C phosphatase function and regulatory mechanisms in the control of cell expansion mediated by the hormone auxin. These studies will identify components and phosphoregulatory mechanisms employed by eukaryotes to modulate cell size during growth and development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative St. Mary’s University is a Hispanic-serving institution in San Antonio, TX, with a long history of successfully preparing underrepresented minority students to enter professional schools. The URISE program will advance the research culture at St. Mary’s, increase the number of students interested in pursuing research careers and Ph.D.s in the biomedical sciences, and produce responsible biomedical scientists. Equally important, is that the broad exposure to biomedical science research will be beneficial to students who are not seeking higher degrees in STEM but, as a result, stay in STEM and join the biomedical workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative. The process to develop new therapies involves multiple studies and clinical trials that can be time consuming, expensive, and potentially redundant depending on the available information. In this project we propose developing novel statistical methods that facilitate information sharing across data sources and are incorporated into adaptive trial designs that are more flexible than traditional designs. This work aims to improve the efficiency of clinical trials by incorporating supplemental sources of data to reduce the overall time needed, minimize the exposure of participants to less effective study arms, and conserve resources by taking advantage of previously collected sources of data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Alcohol use disorder (AUD) affects millions of people in the US. Although genetic studies have identified loci associated with AUD, its genetic etiology has not been fully explained. This project aims to 1) develop integrative methods for analyzing large-scale genomic datasets of AUD to increase power for genetic discovery, and 2) elucidate the genomic architecture of AUD by using systems biology approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Given the obesity epidemic, it is critical that we understand how energy balance regulates hunger and satiety. While much has been learned, we still do not know how hypothalamic hunger / satiety neurons engage higher limbic/reward brain sites to control eating. This is because the “relay” between these hypothalamic neurons and the limbic/reward brain sites, the parabrachial nucleus (PBN), is a “black box”. This grant uses single neuron transcriptomics, mouse genetic engineering and neuron-specific neuroscience “tools” to: a) more clearly delineate the PVH satiety neurons that are upstream of the PBN, b) deconvolute the PBN interoceptive “black box” relay, and c) identify the PBN satiety neurons – ultimately leading to a mechanistic understanding of how alterations in energy balance compel or restrain eating.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Spinal muscular atrophy (SMA) is an oft-fatal motor neuron disease caused by low SMN protein. SMN repletion appears to benefit some patients, but very little is known about how the protein protects the motor neurons and muscle, or if the currently available SMA treatments will be entirely curative. Here we wish to investigate these vitally important questions. Our research will result in a fuller understanding of the biology of SMA and is thus expected to inform improved treatments for this and similar neurodegenerative disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Narrative: Interruption of blood flow to the brain during ischemic stroke results in extensive brain damage. However, restoration of blood flow to oxygen-starved tissue by reperfusion produces free radicals that induce additional brain damage. We will investigate the ability of near infrared light, which non-invasively penetrates tissues, to prevent the formation of these free radicals through inhibition of a key metabolic enzyme in the process responsible for generating free radicals under conditions of stress.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The importance of circadian clocks in human physiology and mental health is evident from their ubiquitous influence on a wide range of cellular and organismal processes, and the malfunction of the clock is known to be associated with several forms of human psychiatric illness and with sleep disorders. On the other hand, codon usage biases are found in all organisms examined and play an important role in determining gene expression levels and protein structures. A better understanding of these two fundamental mechanisms will potentially lead to better understanding of diverse biological processes and potential therapeutic approaches for treating human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Dry mouth due to radiation therapy is a significant toxicity experienced by many head and neck cancer patients, for which there is no effective treatment. We will perform a clinical trial to test the safety of injecting mesenchymal stromal cells (MSCs) isolated from a patient’s bone marrow into their salivary glands to treat this debilitating condition. It is our long-term objective to develop this innovative approach into a new and effective treatment to improve the lives of our patients suffering from dry mouth caused by radiation therapy.

PHR: Project Narrative Research has established that compounds aimed at neuropeptide Y (NPY) receptors are protective against dependence-induced alcohol drinking, and our recent findings show that compounds targeting NPY receptors are also protective against excessive binge-like drinking in mice when targeted to regions of the extended amygdala.
