IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: BUCK INSTITUTE FOR RESEARCH ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although the field has discovered many hallmarks of aging, the causes and connections between these hallmarks are largely unknown due to the fact that we do not know how each protein changes in a proteome during aging. To fill the gap, we have developed a new high-throughput method and machine learning tools to systematically track the fate of each individual protein, including its expression, localization, aggregation, and timing of these changes (4D fate map), during the replicative aging of budding yeast. Our pilot test of this method revealed novel aging mechanism of mitochondria and the proposed work will advance both the breadth and depth of our molecular understanding of aging by establishing a 4D reference map of aging proteome for the field, which will help determine the new mechanisms and connections between different aging hallmarks (e.g., mitochondrial and vacuole/lysosome dysfunction).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative The opioid crisis has shifted into a ‘fourth wave’ of high mortality, characterized by the mixture of synthetic opioids with stimulants. This project will integrate time-sensitive medicolegal death investigation data on fatal drug overdoses, which are currently unavailable to the public. We will leverage both structured and unstructured data from death certificate, toxicology, police, and coroner/medical examiner reports to identify points of intervention and prevention strategies to combat the rapidly evolving opioid crisis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE The most abundant divalent cation, Mg2+, is essential for cellular functions and perturbations are associated with several clinical conditions, including obesity, cardiovascular diseases, diabetes, nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), chronic kidney disease, and cancer; however, the molecular events that directly link Mg2+ to metabolic disease progression are still elusive. Our proposed studies will reveal a previously unexplored mechanism linking mitochondrial Mg2+ dynamics to key hepatic metabolic pathways, which may offer new therapeutic approaches for the treatment of T2DM and comorbidities such obesity and NAFLD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: NARRATIVE This project will complete a longitudinal data infrastructure including most of the U.S. population from 1940 through 2020. The new data resource will enable health scientists to use information on early-life and ancestral experiences—such as parental economic status, childhood environmental exposures, policy conditions, social institutions, and neighborhood characteristics—to investigate of the health, well-being, and mortality of Americans over their lives and through generations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  While stroke is the third leading cause of death among African Americans (AA) and blood-pressure is a major risk factor of stroke, genetic susceptibility to stroke and hypertension of AAs is less well studied than that of other ethnic groups. The objective of this study is to identify variants predicting various types of genomic features in AAs, and to integrate the functional regulation information into AA-specific genetic association analysis of stroke and blood pressure. Discovery of genetic variants that predispose to stroke and blood pressure is a crucial step toward understanding genetic mechanisms that may lead to novel prevention and treatment strategies in this under-studied ethnic group.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The inability to target preventive therapy to children at highest risk of tuberculosis (TB) progression is a major barrier to its scale-up in high burden countries. This study will identify novel host biomarkers and determine the best biomarker panels (i.e., biosignatures) that can meet the World Health Organization-recommended diagnostic accuracy thresholds for a test of TB progression in young children. If successful, the results will be the first step needed to make progress toward addressing the critical unmet need for better tests to target TB preventive therapy.

PHR: Project Narrative The objective of the present proposal is to transform the design experience for BME undergraduates at UAB, from freshman to senior year. Activities include a new freshman/sophomore clinical innovation course, a summer clinical immersion for rising juniors, and enhanced design and engineering content in the senior capstone experience. Direct exposure to clinicians and their problems, using clinical matchmaking software developed at UAB, will provide invaluable experiences in needs finding, customer discovery, and the development of engineering solutions that have market potential.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We aim to determine the clinical utility of ‘dynamic tractography’: a novel method for visualizing electrical neural transfers that incorporates the underlying white matter tracts and supporting linguistic processing. We will also determine how well objective electrophysiology biomarkers will improve the prediction of language outcomes following epilepsy surgery. This project will ultimately optimize understanding of how the human brain develops its language network dynamics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Almost half of all people diagnosed with HIV in the United States are older than 50 years and are expected to live near normal life expectancies given effective antiretroviral therapy; however, people aging with HIV are at increased risk for dementia, as well as depression and cardiovascular disease. In this project, we will develop a multimorbidity simulation model for dementia, depression, cardiovascular disease, and HIV and will use the model to project chronic disease outcomes, quality of life, and costs associated with aging. The overall goal is to investigate the long-term clinical and economic consequences of different strategies to reduce dementia and multimorbidity among people aging with HIV.

PHR: The emergence of multi-drug resistance in already challenging Gram-negative infections and the dry pipeline of broad-spectrum antibiotics demand alternative strategies to preserve activities of clinical antibiotics. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The  ABCD  Study  consortium  uses  multimodal  brain  imaging,  cognitive  and  clinical  assessments,  bioassays,  mobile monitoring, and careful assessment of substance use, environment, psychopathological symptoms, and  social functioning in 11,878 9- 10 year- olds to be followed over 10 years, to determine the effects of substance  use  on  adolescent  brain  and  cognitive  development.  This  ABCD  Research  Project  Site  will  follow  and  assess  participants  enrolled  in  the  study.  These  data  will  be  shared  with  the  scientific  community  to  address  a  comprehensive range of questions concerning youth development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  Neurons are among the most long-lived cell types in our bodies, as they are generally never replaced and must a maintain function for our entire lifetime. One vital aspect of maintaining neuronal health is the preservation of a healthy pool of the energy-producing organelle within the cell, the mitochondria, as multiple neurodegenerative diseases are caused by defects in mitochondrial function. The work in this proposal will study a newly discovered way in which neurons break down their damaged mitochondria through outsourcing this breakdown process to their cellular neighbors known as glial cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Second generation antipsychotics (SGAs) produce highly variable effect/side effect profiles in patients, and most patients cycle through several medications before finding one with a tolerable therapeutic window. I propose that differences in receptor signaling and trafficking properties at the D3 dopamine receptor in response to distinct SGAs contributes to their variable effects. My research will refine our understanding of a non-canonical signaling pathway directly impacted by SGAs and could ultimately inform new avenues for more effective treatment of neuropsychiatric conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Fundamental new synthetic approaches and new synthetic methodology and their use in the discovery of new therapeutics for the treatment of cancer will emerge from the studies, and a fundamental understanding of the mechanism of action and the interaction of biologically active natural products with their biological target will be developed. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: RELEVANCE Deep brain stimulation (DBS) is a powerful clinical technology, positively impacting the lives of tens of thousands of patients worldwide. However, DBS surgical targeting technology and post-operative programming practices have been relatively stagnant over the history of the therapy. We propose that new tools are needed to analyze the effects of stimulation on individual patients and evaluate novel stimulation strategies. Therefore, the goal of this project is to apply the latest advances in magnetic resonance imaging, DBS computational modeling, and holographic visualization to the clinical practice of subthalamic DBS for the treatment of Parkinson’s disease.

ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative RNA viruses like SARS-CoV-2 cause devastating impacts on public health, the economy, and our daily lives in the U.S. and worldwide. To fight these pathogens, scientists need simple techniques to study the effect of viral mutations and how they impact disease severity, transmission, or evasion of vaccine- or natural-derived immunity. These studies will develop novel techniques and tools, enabling more scientists to research how mutations impact viruses and may serve as the basis for future vaccine candidates or diagnostic tools.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Genomics Research Experience for Master’s Students (GEMS) Fellows R25 summer research program will train students enrolled a master’s degree in biostatistics, statistics, data science, computer science or related quantitative discipline in sophisticated statistical and computational methods for the analysis of cancer genomics data and precision oncology. GEMS is hands-on, immersive and interdisciplinary with several components that make the program unique: access to the world's leading resources of cancer genomics data and tools; dual- mentorship team science model by Memorial Sloan Kettering (MSK) faculty comprising basic, translational, biostatistical, epidemiological and clinical scientists who are leaders in their fields; student pairing with a peer advisor; and a lecture/mini workshop series on cutting-edge genomic technologies and high dimensional data analysis given by program faculty who are world experts. GEMS fellows will execute an impactful research project as well as experience scientific discovery through collaborative multidisciplinary team science.

PHR: NARRATIVE Understanding the process of atherosclerosis and its progression is essential to decrease cardiovascular disease burden. The results of this research will enable continued scientific progress toward an understanding of cardiovascular disease etiology.

PHR: Narrative The Nonhuman Primate Reagent Resource (NHPRR) develops, manufactures, and distributes research reagents for more than 21 years. These species-matched immunologic tools help investigators develop and utilize preclinical monkey models of human diseases–from infectious diseases to organ transplantation. This application describes the scientific and operational goals for our resource program's next cycle, using new reagent development methodologies and expanded community outreach plans to maximize the NHPRR's impact in nonhuman primate research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Repeated cycles of binge alcohol intoxication and withdrawal are associated with impaired social behaviors, compounding interpersonal problems associated with alcohol abuse and hastening the progression to alcohol use disorder (AUD). Unfortunately, few treatment options are currently available that specifically address the social symptoms of alcohol abuse. This study will employ a rodent model of binge alcohol consumption to elucidate serotonergic mechanisms of alcohol’s deleterious effect on social behavior, with an eye toward developing new treatments for AUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative To capture the landscape of somatic mutations at the single-molecule level from a range of cell or DNA input using Tn5 transposase, the proposed research aims to develop a Tn5 based duplex sequencing (Tn5-duplex-seq) method in a single-well workflow, which resolves complementary strands by strand orientation from simple PCR-based capture. Tn5-duplex-seq technology can transform our understanding of somatic mutations through the innate comprehensiveness of this technique, by capturing both clonal as well as the rarest somatic mutations, and providing the basis for determining somatic single base or structural variation accurately. Ultimately, our tool will be accessible, cost-effective, and scalable to be used by the larger scientific community and easily integrated with pipelines of the Somatic Mosaicism across Human Tissues (SMaHT) Network.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Relevance to Public Health Biomarkers for pre-clinical stages of Alzheimer's disease (AD) have become increasingly important for the development of preventative interventions. For neuroimaging, positron emission tomography (PET) imaging of amyloid beta (Aβ) and tau protein provide early imaging markers of AD and can track disease progression but are expensive and require the use of radioactive tracers. This project aims to develop and evaluate a noninvasive, quantitative and economical imaging marker of AD based on the complexity or regularity of resting state functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Public health relevance In addition to its nutrient-absorption functions, gut epithelium is the site in which neural, immune, microbial and dietary factors interact. These multi-system interactions critically regulate whole-body physiology ranging from metabolism, immunity to cognition. At the foundation of these interactions are the healthy and balanced number of gut epithelial cells. As the largest exposed surfaces of the body, billions of cells are shed from the human gut epithelium every day. These lost cells are constantly replaced by intestine stem cells. Activity of intestine stem cell has to be precisely controlled or it may cause tumorigenesis. Currently, 200,000 new cases of gastrointestinal tract cancers are reported each year. Therefore, deciphering the mechanisms that regulate intestine stem cell behavior and gut homeostasis is important for understanding how gut homeostasis is maintained in normal conditions but altered in diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Social perception is a fundamental feature of social communication, with impairments in this process leading to an inability to form meaningful and stable relationships, severely affecting individuals’ physical and mental well- being. Yet, how the brain perceives and transforms social cues into socially appropriate behavior remains poorly understood. This proposal will identify neuronal populations and genomic pathways in the brain that process social status cues and guide socially competent behavior enabling us to better understand the neurobiology of social perception.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Relapsed leukemia after allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (allo-SCT) is the major obstacle for successful allo-SCT, and its response to donor lymphocyte infusion (DLI) involves reversal of T cell exhaustion. The objective of these studies is to specifically define and target the mechanisms by which exhausted T cell subsets mediate DLI efficacy and are themselves shaped by oncogenic pathways. At the same time, the proposed studies will establish a paradigm for mapping co-evolving cancer-immune interactions within the tumor microenvironment relevant for immunotherapeutic outcomes beyond DLI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Narrative The use of broadly neutralizing antibodies as a therapy or potential cure for HIV is promising, but a major obstacle to testing its potential is determining in what patients it may be most beneficial. We are developing a rapid turnaround assay using a single cell viral outgrowth neutralization assay (scVONA), which obtains information about the functional viral reservoir in patients and its sensitivity to bNAbs within two weeks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Heart disease is the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in the United States and cardiomyocyte hypertrophy is a major hallmark in disease progression. Understanding of the fundamental mechanism of gene regulation at the level of protein synthesis in cardiomyocytes in normal physiology and during cardiomyocyte hypertrophy will provide novel insights for preventive and therapeutic interventions of heart disease. In this proposal, we will investigate the function and mechanism of translation control mediated by a novel double-stranded RNA element in synergy with upstream open reading frames, which is required for maintaining cardiac physiological homeostasis. These studies will provide proof-of-concept evidence to support developement of novel therapeutic targets and RNA-based modality for treating cardiac pathological hypertrophy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Given the central role of mitochondrial dysfunction in Alzheimer’s disease (AD), defining the impact of AD-relevant, pathological tau species on mitochondrial/neuronal function is of critical importance. The genetic model C. elegans provides an excellent system for elucidating the impact of pathological posttranslational modifications of tau on mitochondrial biology and neuronal health as a function of age. The results of these studies have the potential of identifying unique targets for intervention to attenuate disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anxiety can emerge as early as pre-school age (4-6) and is often linked to anxiety in the parent. While we believe that this transmission is driven by both genetics and parenting behavior, we do not understand the moment-to-moment interactions that support intergenerational transmission. The current longitudinal study will examine patterns of dyadic social dynamics captured in neural and physiological synchrony and emotion modeling as the transmission mechanisms, with the potential to translate findings into dyadic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The central amygdala (CeA) is a subnucleus of the amygdala that encodes ‘valence’, defined as the subjective value assigned to sensory stimuli that impacts consequential behavior. It remains unclear whether different valences (positive or negative) are processed in the same or distinct cells, I hypothesize that the corticotropin-releasing factor (CRF)-expressing neurons in the CeA process both valances but in a state- dependent manner. My proposed research will determine whether the order of two experiences holding different valences results in a biased state dependence that favors valence coding by CeA-CRF towards the initial experience.

ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE DNA mutations drive the outgrowth of small populations of cells in normal tissue, years before clinical diagnosis of cancer. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE "Leaky gut" is the proximate cause of susceptibility to necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC), a life-threatening, gastrointestinal emergency affecting 7-10% of preterm infants with mortality as high as 30-50%. This proposal seeks to establish a stool-based immune profile that can identify “at-risk" preterm infants with hyperpermeable intestinal barrier prior to the onset of NEC. The results of this study would facilitate clinical evaluation of preventive and therapeutic measures aimed at improving intestinal maturation and reducing the burden of NEC complications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Children who receive CAR-T cell therapy to cure their leukemia can develop life threatening neurological side effects. We will use neuroimaging and other markers to predict whether a child will develop these severe neurotoxicities and determine whether neurotoxicity-induced brain damage causes long term problems in cognition and behavior. The biomarkers that we will identify will guide future clinical trials of safe and effective treatments to prevent neurotoxicity and interventions to alleviate long term impairments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A major barrier in opioid addiction research is our limited understanding of the organization of the endogenous opioid response system in the brain. Our project will tackle this issue by systematically identifying opioid- responsive brain cell types in clinically relevant opioid use states (dependence, withdrawal, abstinence, pain management) using single cell transcriptomics technology in the entire brain, and circuit mapping and in vivo functional imaging studies in the prefrontal cortex. This study will generate an exceptional resource for the field to explain how opioids change the brain and to discover novel therapeutic approaches to prevent and treat opioid use disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There remains in the United States a critical need for well-trained investigators in dental, oral and craniofacial research. This institutional career development application supports the Buffalo Oral-Research and Specialty Training Program (BORST) Program, an integrated program based in the School of Dental Medicine at the University at Buffalo to help train the next generation of dental specialist-scientists engaged in dental, oral and craniofacial research. Career development opportunities will include clinical dental specialty training disciplines of periodontics, orthodontics and oral pathology combined with integrated graduate research areas of immunology/innate defenses, relationship of oral pathogens to systemic disease, saliva and salivary glands, microbiome, and bone and connective tissues/tissue engineering.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia (a progressive loss of thinking and memory skills) in older adults, and the most common inherited genetic risk factor is the APOE4 allele. However, it is unclear how and why APOE4 increases AD risk. In this project, we will evaluate the role of APOE4-related alterations in the complement pathway within human spinal fluid as a potential cause of increased AD risk, the relationship between complement pathway activation and cognitive decline 7.5 years later, and the effect of modulating APOE protein function/biology on the complement pathway in the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tumor and microenvironment cells often interact to promote cancer progression, but gaps remain in our understanding of how these interactions occur. My recent publication uncovered a novel cilia-enriched “interface” cell state adopted by both tumor and microenvironment cells in melanoma, indicating that the interface may have a critical role in melanoma progression. My proposed work will investigate how the interface is established and how it contributes to invasion, and could provide novel therapeutic targets to prevent melanoma progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: The single-base-pair resolution maps of DNA (hydroxy)methylation will be generated in sorted inhibitory and excitatory neurons at key time points of postnatal brain development and adulthood, as well as in the brains of psychiatrically normal individuals and patients with schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. The data will be integrated with genetic findings for these disorders as well as with other omics data that have been generated by the PsychEncode Consortium. We anticipate that this work will reveal the molecular and cellular mechanisms and causal relationships of genetic associations, and will suggest specific subtypes of neurons that contribute to disease risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Here we hypothesize that the gut microbiota, the metabolites it produces and their effects on immune function play a key role in determining the outcome of surgical injury and infection. In this proposal we seek to elucidate the mechanisms by which key gut microbiota-derived metabolites (butyrate, tryptophan derivatives, etc) program macrophages to express a survival-related phenotype leading to full recovery. The final goal of this proposal is to develop and test a de novo assembled microbial consortia based on the data generated that will enhance macrophage function and improve survival in mice subjected to surgical injury and infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: While recombinant AAV vectors show promise in the clinic, limitations in the technology remain. The goal of this project is to create and isolate laboratory generated chimeric AAV vectors that have substantially enhanced ability to provide therapeutic DNA into the human liver, cross the human blood brain barrier to enhance CNS gene transfer, and improve the efficacy of genome engineering in human hematopoietic stem cells. The appropriate candidate vectors will be validated in humanized animal models and/or non-human primates as a step towards their use in human trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / RELEVANCE Contamination and fouling of surfaces by bacteria is a critical problem in many healthcare settings and can lead to serious and substantial burdens that are costly in economic and human terms. Many materials have been designed to resist bacterial fouling, but all of these strategies ultimately fail when deployed in real-world scenarios or for extended periods. Fundamentally new approaches to the design of robust antifouling surfaces and coatings that move beyond conventional materials design strategies are desperately needed, would have substantial impacts on human health, and are the focus of this project.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a shortage of researchers from diverse backgrounds in Medicine, Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (MSTEM) who devote their careers to issues that affect an aging population. The MSTEM Scholars Trained in Aging Research (MSTEM STAR) program at California State University, Fullerton (CSUF) aims to address this shortage through the implementation of a multidimensional aging science program. Students enrolled in the MSTEM STAR program will complete structured research experiences, an aging- science curriculum, and support and engagement activities, which will prepare them to pursue advanced degrees in MSTEM fields related to aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it aims to address neurobiological mechanisms to understanding how palatable food overconsumption is facilitated after abstinence from such foods at brain circuit levels. Our objective is to identify neural circuit pathways driving the relapse to palatable food overconsumption by characterizing the leptin-responsive circuit that connects the lateral hypothalamus to the brain stem. We also propose to examine how leptin sensitivity in this circuit is changed by palatable food consumption and how circuit- specific leptin sensitivity can have effects on eating and body weight, thereby contributing to provide insight into targeted therapies for eating disorder and obesity patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Tuberculosis is now the world's leading infectious cause of death; a more effective new vaccine is needed to stem this global health crisis. In order to rationally develop a new vaccine, more information is needed about the ways that certain Mycobacterium tuberculosis antigens elicit varying CD4 T cell functions at the site of infection. With studies of antigen specific CD4 T cells in the mouse model, and from the site of infection in human subjects with HIV-associated TB meningitis, I aim to define key determinants of function in this crucial cell type.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: The SARS-CoV-2 virus, the virus responsible for the COVID-19 pandemic, can damage not only lung barrier function but also the blood brain barrier by an unknown mechanism. Stimulant drugs of abuse such as cocaine also can damage the blood brain barrier, allowing increased access of toxins and microbes into the central nervous system. Tis research will determine the mechanism underlying blood brain barrier damage produced by the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein and the potential interaction with cocaine. The results will provide important insight into the potential consequences of contracting the COVID-19 virus by persons with stimulant use disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative A crucial priority for combatting the global TB epidemic is shortening the length of treatment required to reliably cure tuberculosis. Through this proposal we will establish the importance of continued bacterial activity and replication during treatment which could be paradigm shift for understanding the basis of treatment-shortening drugs and accelerating the development of more efficacious, shorter regimens. This proposal represents an important step towards our long-term goal: a paradigm shift for TB drug development pipelines and clinical trials away from culture-based metrics of bacillary load to a new model in which decisions are based on markers of drug impact on the pathogen's physiologic state.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The enzyme ornithine aminotransferase (OAT) is highly upregulated in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). An inhibitor of OAT was shown to suppress the growth of HCC in cell culture and in two animal models with patient-derived HCC implanted. We propose to design, synthesize, and evaluate new compounds for their selectivity toward OAT and to test them as inactivators of HCC and other cancers we have found with overexpressed OAT both in vitro and in vivo, as well as study the inactivation mechanisms of new inactivators.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Astrocytes are non-neuronal cells which are key components of cortical circuits underlying goal-directed, learned behavior, yet their mechanisms are poorly understood. We will examine the role of astrocyte-neuron circuits in mediating critical components of reinforcement learning that involve norepinephrine release, using cutting edge experimental methods combined with computational models. These findings will provide insight into how dysregulation of astrocyte function may influence brain disorders and diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to improve our understanding of pulmonary arteriovenous malformations (PAVMs), which are common sequelae of surgical palliation for univentricular congenital heart disease. To achieve this goal, we will study a circulating protein (soluble vascular endothelial growth factor receptor 1; sVEGFR1), which we recently identified as a candidate factor that may prevent PAVMs. By studying the role of sVEGFR1 in vascular remodeling and PAVM prevention, we anticipate that this new knowledge will improve our understanding of pulmonary microvascular biology and may lead to development of targeted medical therapies for patients with univentricular congenital heart disease and PAVMs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: We propose an innovative approach toward rapid and facile next generation neutralization resistance tests based on direct detection and quantification of antibody-target binding within the native virus populations of people living with HIV. The underlying premise is that potent bnAb neutralization ensues because of virion binding; while escape variants are by nature poorly (or are not) immunoreactive. Successful translation of this concept would provide valuable new tools to boost the efficiency and quality of bnAb trials and meet the needs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Addictive disorders such as alcoholism share bidirectional links and common neural pathways with chronic pain syndromes, such that protracted pain may affect alcohol use patterns, and chronic alcohol use may precipitate or otherwise influence pain responses. The proposed research is an interdisciplinary approach that aims to examine the association between alcohol use disorder (AUD) and chronic pain, and predict the risk of chronic pain development in AUD patients in relation to their alcohol abuse history.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease affecting about 5 million Americans over the age of 65, and this number is projected to increase 2-3 folds by 2050. Despite the unequivocal genetic links between microglia-specific gene mutations and late-onset AD, how AD-relevant subsets of microglia are regu- lated and how they contribute to AD pathology remain unknown. By investigating these important microglial subsets, this application will shed light on the cellular and molecular mechanisms of AD and lay the groundwork for the development of precise microglia-based interventions to treat AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Appropriately regulating attention in accord with current need is essential for survival, and dysregulation of this process is associated with numerous neuropsychiatric diseases, including substance use disorders and eating disorders. Our project will determine how dopaminergic circuits integrate physiological need and regulate attentional behavior. Obtaining a mechanistic understanding of how attention is regulated by these circuits will provide a foundation for developing therapeutic interventions for attentional dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Somatic sequence variants contribute to defects in tissue function and can lead to disease. Current methods for identification of rare sequence variants often fail to identify variants in cis regulatory elements (CREs) and also fail to determine the functional effects of each mutation. We will develop a new technology that fills both of these gaps, allowing high sensitivity detection of variants in CREs and coding regions, while simultaneously annotating their effects on CRE activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Data are converging around the hypothesis that the root cause of IPF is telomere dysfunction in AEC2 cells. Studies outlined in this proposal will generate data establishing molecular drivers distal to telomere dysfunction that lead to lung remodeling and whether increasing telomerase activity leads to favorable molecular and functional changes in IPF AT2 cells. These data would support the development of novel telomerase-based therapies for IPF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project seeks to benefit public health by evaluating a four-week mindfulness-based mobile health intervention on symptoms of depression and anxiety within a symptomatic sample, with participants randomly assigned to two different dosages of mindfulness practice. Ultimately, this line of research is aimed at producing mobile technologies for depression and anxiety that are both highly accessible and optimized based on patients' needs and preferences. The current study will provide crucial training and pilot data for a future randomized controlled trial that will include a wider variety of dosage conditions and both active and waitlist control groups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer occurs when cells acquire changes that convert them from a normal to a malignant state. Oncogene- induced senescence is a cellular brake that prevents aberrant cells from becoming cancer; and oncogene- induced senescence also controls the tumor microenvironment which adds mechanistic complexities to the processes of tumorigenesis and metastasis – and therapeutic successes or failures. Therefore, it is important to investigate the pathways that control oncogene-induced senescence to understand how cancer may be prevented, diagnosed, and clinically treated.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ABCD Study consortium uses multimodal brain imaging, cognitive and clinical assessments, bioassays, mobile monitoring, and careful assessment of substance use, environment, psychopathological symptoms, and social functioning in 11,878 9-10 year-olds to be followed over 10 years, to determine the effects of substance use on adolescent brain and cognitive development. This ABCD Research Project Site will follow and assess participants enrolled in the study. These data will be shared with the scientific community to address a comprehensive range of questions concerning youth development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Alcoholic liver disease (ALD) is one of the most common forms of chronic liver disease in the United States and results in significant morbidity and mortality. This proposal will test the novel paradigm shifting hypothesis that stressed hepatocytes in ALD released microRNA enriched extracellular vesicles (EVs) that promote the transition from chronic asymptomatic alcoholic steatohepatitis (ASH) to fatal alcoholic hepatitis (AH) and are released into the bloodstream providing a signature or “barcode” that can be used to develop novel mechanism-based biomarkers of ALD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research will develop and validate an advanced magnetic resonance elastography (MRE) method to provide diagnostic information unavailable using conventional imaging techniques. Recent studies have shown that multiparametric MRE of the liver and spleen has a promising role in detecting and monitoring portal hypertension, a life-threatening problem in patients with chronic liver diseases, as an alternative to invasive hepatic venous pressure gradient measurement. This proposed study’s success will maximize the clinically relevant information provided by hepatosplenic MRE to substantially advance our understanding and ability to diagnose and monitor liver disease progression or regression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Persistence of the latent HIV reservoir in people living with HIV (PLWH) remains the critical barrier to an HIV cure. Here we will employ novel high throughput single cell strategies to understand the genetic mechanisms that allow HIV infected cells to persist. Understanding how infected cells survive and persist within the body will allow targeted development of HIV cure strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dysregulation of melanocytes or melanocyte stem cells leads to diseases that significantly affect an individual's quality of life, ranging from fatal cancers to hyper- and hypo-pigmentation disorders. The goal of this project is to better understand the biology and pathology of these cells through studying the function of a new uncharacterized gene involved. Unlocking the mechanism of this gene will provide new therapeutic targets for manipulating these cells to treat vitiligo, hyper-pigmentation disorders, and melanoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diabetic cardiomyopathy is an independent risk factor for heart failure, and is characterized by striking changes in cardiac fuel metabolism. Alterations in fuel metabolism may lead to energy deficits in the heart, which can promote or exacerbate cardiac contractile dysfunction. In this proposal, we aim to investigate whether a recently discovered circulating peptide can reverse metabolic changes in the diabetic heart, and lead to improved cardiac function in pre-clinical diabetic cardiomyopathy models.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Narrative We propose to explore whether maternal immune activation results in a cerebrospinal fluid volume increase in subarachnoid space in non-human primate models. If the results of this study will support that such association exists, MRI-detectable cerebrospinal fluid volume increase might be a good biomarker for children whose neurodevelopment was susceptible to maternal immune activation. Early biomarkers allow starting the intervention before behavioral symptoms manifest with better outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  The number of older Americans will double in the next 4 decades to nearly 90 million, placing an unprecedented financial and resource burden on the health care system. Exercise has clear and demonstrable physical benefits, but a more precise understanding of how exercise supports cognitive function is essential. Demonstrating definitively that exercise as recommended by public health entities has benefits for cognition would have enormous public health implications, encourage the public to adapt more active lifestyles, and stimulate the development of effective exercise delivery programs.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The project will generate genetic reagents that will allow the study of the function of 2,300 fly genes and their human homologs. The reagents that we propose to generate here will greatly advance our understanding of functions of these genes by providing the most sophisticated tools available in any model system. These tools/reagents also often allow the replacement of the fly gene with its human ortholog, making it possible to study specific human disease-causing variants, including orphan disease variants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE This study will evaluate whether CDC’s National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) provides accurate population-based human biomonitoring levels for seasonal chemicals. It will provide information that will enable CDC to reconsider their sampling logistics to better represent seasonal and regional variations or will enable us to quantify the extent to which NHANES underestimates US population exposures. This, in turn, will make it possible to apply a multiplicative factor to future exposure estimates from NHANES to obtain a more accurate assessment of exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE HEALTH SCI CTR
PHR: Childhood obesity is one of the most serious public health challenges because of its harmful consequences, such as type 2 diabetes, cardiovascular disease, and psychological problems. To identify risk factors for childhood obesity at the very beginning of life, we propose to use an innovative metabolomics approach (a high-throughput method for testing metabolites in biofluids) to systematically identify metabolites in the plasma of pregnant women which can predict the risk of childhood obesity. The study findings will significantly contribute to a better understanding of the biological mechanisms underlying the early origins of childhood obesity and the development of early and effective tools for preventing childhood obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The proposed research develops and applies a new class of Multiple Synonymous Substitution models that include both selected and neutral synonymous changes in estimates of evolutionary change. Our hypothesis is that the current definition of what constitutes neutrally evolving sites is importantly wrong in that it biases the estimation of selective forces (by underestimating the rates of neutral changes), and that improved estimates without that bias will provide significantly better and more accurate understanding of the action of natural selection in a broad array of evolutionary contexts. We will apply and validate these methods across a broad array of taxa and develop news comparative and population genetic tests of selection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project studies how regulating factors called sirtuins influence defense against TB. Sirtuin levels fall when immune cells are infected with the germ that causes TB, which helps in the immediate defense against TB but can lead to lung damage during chronic infection. New knowledge gained by this project will increase knowledge about the role of sirtuins in TB and could identify new treatments to hasten TB cure and improve lung heath by restoring the proper balance of sirtuin activity during antibiotic treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Survivors of immune thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (iTTP) experience significant neurologic morbidity including cognitive impairment and high rates of stroke that impact their functioning and quality of life. We have identified that silent cerebral infarction (SCI) or ‘silent stroke is common in iTTP survivors and contributes to cognitive impairment. By examining whether SCI progress during iTTP clinical remission and increase the risk of future stroke and testing whether novel ‘microthrombi targeting’ treatments for acute iTTP (caplacizumab) reduce the risk of SCI and associated cognitive impairment, this study will identify the optimal timing, targets, and clinical endpoints for interventions to alleviate the devastating neurologic sequelae of iTTP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The results of this research will yield an improved understanding of how a common condition termed “femoroacetabular impingement syndrome” alters the shape and biomechanics of the hip and will determine if these data are associated with image-based measurements of the structure and composition of hip cartilage and labrum health provided by quantitative magnetic resonance imaging. Our findings should offer more direct evidence linking hip anatomy and biomechanics with biochemical changes associated with hip osteoarthritis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Urine output tracking is an essential clinical practice for detecting and treating fluid imbalance in heart failure patients. However, urine output data are typically obtained from collection vessels, which are error-prone due to the manual nature of vessel handling and patient non-compliance. Here, we will develop a toilet-based device, designed specifically for the hospital setting, that will enable automatic, accurate, and timely tracking of patient urine output to enable physicians to more effectively manage volume overload in heart failure patient and avoid the use of indwelling urinary catheters.

PHR: Project Narrative Macrophages, a component of our immune system, have a paradoxical role in cancer – they can promote metastasis. We previously discovered that macrophages spill their internal contents into cancer cells during metastasis, but what is the functionally important information in the contents? We recently discovered that mitochondria are transferred, and we seek to answer how thieving even small amounts of mitochondria can drive big changes in cancer cell metastasis.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: HENRY M. JACKSON FDN FOR THE ADV MIL/MED
PHR: Project Narrative Lower limb amputations are debilitating injuries that result in impaired mobility with a majority developing secondary musculoskeletal impairment and pain that further impacts function. A novel surgical technique that restores the dynamic coupling between agonist and antagonist muscles improves proprioception and the ability to actively control residual limb muscles with the goal being to control muscle-driven prostheses. This proposal aims to determine if there are near-term functional benefits of this surgical technique when using a conventional prosthesis.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA SALT LAKE CITY HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: This proposed proof of concept (POC) project seeks to consolidate and harmonize neuroimaging and fluid biomarker data from two large, prospective, longitudinal studies in Service Members and Veterans (SMVs). In concert with related POC proposals, we will integrate this data into a unified dataset, and create infrastructure and validate methodology which will be later applied to additional datasets. This work will allow examination of the use of biomarkers in identifying factors that can improve diagnosis, prognosis, and response to treatment in order to improve total brain health in Veterans. This line of research will create the platform essential to personalize the care provided to SMVs by leveraging multiple levels of data in an integrative manner, thereby allowing for a better understanding of individual variations that shape recovery from TBI and associated comorbidities, and lead to the development and maintenance of chronic symptoms. This allows us to both prevent risk, and to provide novel interventions based on improved understanding of integrative mechanisms.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Female manual wheelchair users experience shoulder pain and pathology at far greater rates than males. This proposal seeks to reveal sex-specific mechanisms underlying shoulder pain by quantifying the effects of wheelchair use in childhood and adolescence on (Aim 1) glenohumeral muscle morphology, (Aim 2) scapula shape, and (Aim 3) static and dynamic scapular kinematics. The proposed research is critical to the development of updated wheelchair use guidelines as well as sex-specific targeted interventions for the early detection, prevention, and rehabilitation of shoulder pain and pathologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The widespread contamination of drinking and other water sources with per- and polyfluorinated alkyl substances (PFAS) represents an urgent public health issue due to adverse health effects associated with PFAS exposure. The current strategy of removal through adsorption or filtration does not fully address the problem and leads to further spread of PFAS in the environment. When paired with PFAS capture on adsorbents, the micelle- accelerated photoactivated reductive defluorination technology developed at Enspired Solutions can provide a safe, efficient and cost-effective approach for on-site PFAS capture and permanent destruction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Glioma stem cells (GSCs) form a minority cell population within the human brain cancer glioblastoma (GBM) that is responsible for treatment resistance, progression and uniform lethality within 2 years or less. Since it has proven very difficult to target GSCs with traditional therapies we propose to modulate electrical signaling with a powerful neuroscience tool, optogenetics, to “reprogram” GSCs to less malignant and more treatment responsive states. The demonstration of GSC reprogramming through electrical manipulation will open the door to new therapeutic strategies expected to overcome treatment resistance and improve outcomes for GBM patients.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To maximize the therapeutic effects of transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) interventions on poststroke hand function, they must be delivered during poststroke brain states during which TMS most strongly activates the residual corticospinal tract and enhances its transmission. In this project, we will test the feasibility of real-time personalized brain state-dependent TMS in chronic stroke survivors (Aim 1) and establish poststroke hand impairment inclusion criteria for future clinical trials that investigate this promising personalized brain stimulation approach (Aim 2). Results are expected to directly motivate an R01 proposal that evaluates the therapeutic effects of personalized brain state-dependent TMS on poststroke hand motor control.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Unilateral cerebral palsy is the most common pediatric neurologic disorder of movement and prevents functional independence during early childhood. The goal of the current proposal is to characterize how brain pathways controlling movement adapt to early injury in children with unilateral cerebral palsy, and to examine these patterns in relation to movement deficits. The knowledge gained from this study will provide the foundation for testing future precision-based approaches to neurorehabilitation and will have broad clinical implications for pediatric movement disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Chronic Hepatitis B Virus (HBV) affects 250-300 million people and leads to 800,000 deaths each year, mainly from liver failure and liver cancer. While HBV spread can be controlled by vaccines and chronic HBV can be treated to suppress virus production, there is currently no cure for curative solution to treat HBV. This proposal focuses on developing a new class of antivirals that can lead to a curative solution for HBV.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: Project Narrative As most youth living with HIV (YLH) now survive into adulthood, transition from pediatric to adult-oriented care has become a pressing public health issue with implications for ongoing efforts to end the HIV epidemic (EHE) in the US. With the integration of statewide multilevel data (e.g., electronic health records) from multiple sources, the current study aims to assess the HIV care transition status and identify the barriers and facilitators of successful transition for YLH in South Carolina. The in-depth assessments of the transition status of YLH could help policymakers and HIV care providers improve systems and services to better support YLH as they move from pediatric to adult-oriented HIV care and inform state health department to devise more precise, targeted intervention strategies for YLH, especially those who are socially disadvantaged.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Complex neural circuits in the brain regulate feeding behavior. We recently identified a previously unknown 3- node neural circuit that connects the cholinergic neurons in the basal forebrain to the hippocampus, and then to the hypothalamus, and this circuit suppresses food intake. In the proposed research we will establish the functional relevance of this circuit in the regulation of feeding behavior and how it impacts long-term body weight control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE T cells are a part of the immune system able to control tumor growth, but are ineffective in most cancer patients. Our lab has made the groundbreaking discovery that T cells entering tumors experience an extreme response to stress that rapidly shuts down their ability to generate energy and make and process proteins. Our proposal will formally prove that targeting the stress response holds the power to revive essential T cell functions and invigorate tumor control to allow multiple types of immunotherapies to work better for cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Lipids are a class of biomolecules that are not only a major component of cellular membranes, but they also function as cell signaling mediators. Dysregulated lipid metabolism is associated with Type 1 Diabetes (T1D). Quantitative profiling of lipids in nonobese diabetic mouse – a widely used model organism that shares similar physiology with human T1D, is an important step toward understanding the role of lipids in human T1D development.

PHR: Low milk production is a cause of low breastfeeding rates and infant mortality. Excessive glucocorticoids disrupt lactation. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The ApoE protein plays many important roles, including the transport of cholesterol across different tissues and cells and clearance of amyloid β (Aβ) from the brain, and ApoE4 is the major genetic risk factor for Alzheimer's disease (AD). The molecular mechanism of how ApoE4 contributes to AD pathogenesis remains unclear. In this grant application, we propose various experimentation to dissect its crosstalk with a cytokine- mediated transcription factor C/EBPβ.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: OVERALL PROJECT NARRATIVE The Cleveland Digestive Diseases Research Core Center (DDRCC) is focused on pathogenic mechanisms of Digestive Inflammation/Tumorigenesis (i.e., inflammatory bowel disease, colon cancer, Barrett’s esophagus, etc.) and Liver Disease/Metabolism (i.e., hepatitis, metabolic syndromes, obesity, etc.), which affect millions of people in the US. By providing state-of-the-art services to DDRCC investigators at two major Cleveland institutions (Case Western Reserve University and the Cleveland Clinic Foundation), the Center fosters multi- disciplinary collaborative research, leading to new discoveries and treatments, thus having a large impact on the health of patients suffering from digestive diseases.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The main goal of the University of Chicago (UChicago) Digestive Diseases Research Core Center for Interdisciplinary Study of Inflammatory Intestinal Disorders (C-IID) is to foster and facilitate interdisciplinary and innovative and patient-oriented research in the field of complex inflammatory digestive diseases, to understand and therapeutically exploit discoveries to improve the health of patients with DD. The C-IID has successfully met its goals of advancing the science and translation of discovery in complex diseases of the bowel. The C-IID is greater than the sum of its parts. It provides strategic vision, cutting-edge, high quality, and cost-effective services and resources, and gives opportunity to current and next generation scientists to flourish in a highly collaborative and productive environment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Thin-film surface microelectrodes (uECoG) are a novel neurotechnology that can detect microseizure events over large areas of the brain at fine resolution. This project seeks to evaluate the potential of uECoG to improve the diagnosis and treatment of neocortical epilepsy by investigating the cellular mechanisms and clinical significance of microseizure events. The results of this project will advance the standard of care for epilepsy diagnosis, and inform the future development of implantable uECoG devices to diagnose and treat a range of neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Autistic individuals are at high risk for increased suicidality and suicide mortality, and require suicide prevention research tailored to their unique needs. This research involves examining suicide risk and protective factors, as well as developing and piloting a novel community-based suicide prevention intervention for autistic individuals. The use of community-based participatory research methods will promote the ultimate goal of reduced suicidality and enhanced quality of life in the autistic community.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Households with children are disproportionately affected by food insecurity, and in food-insecure households, adolescents are more vulnerable to experiencing disrupted eating patterns than younger children. Food-insecure adolescents face elevated risk for obesity in the United States, which is a significant public health concern due to its wide-ranging physical and mental health consequences, yet the reasons underlying this increased risk are not clear. By examining binge eating as a novel mechanism to explain the increased risk for adolescent obesity associated with food insecurity and evaluating potential approaches for promote food security and healthy weight among adolescents affected by food insecurity, findings from the proposed project will inform interventions to mitigate obesity risk in youth from under-resourced backgrounds. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Beneficial and pathogenic bacteria thrive in communities termed biofilms in which bacteria synthesize, secrete, and enmesh themselves with diverse biopolymers. Biofilms are linked to difficult-to-treat infections that can exhaust treatment options, yet there are no blueprints for how bacteria build these seemingly ordered architectures and uncovering these details can accelerate discovery of new anti-infectives. This research project introduces a multidisciplinary and broadly applicable approach to define fundamental assembly and organizational principles underlying the remarkable biofilm architectures formed by E. coli using functional amyloid fibers termed curli and newly discovered phosphoethanolamine cellulose.

PHR: Project Narrative In accordance with the mission of the National Institute for Neurological Disorders and Stroke (NINDS) this grant will seek fundamental knowledge about the brain and nervous system and will use that knowledge to reduce the burden of neurological disease, specifically the feasibility of a novel delivery platform for epigenetic DNA-binding domains such as CRISPR/Cas9. This research holds great relevance for the advancement of treatment for those suffering from genetically-linked neurological disorders. The funds used for this research award will be used to develop a research pathway to critically evaluate an engineered stem cell delivery platform in a translationally relevant animal model to facilitate this approach towards clinical trials.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Up to 12% of pregnant women experience a new episode of depression during pregnancy, but less than half of these women initiate psychotherapy (ie, talk therapy) or antidepressant use. The goals of this study are to identify factors that predict whether pregnant women with new episodes of depression initiate psychotherapy or antidepressant use and to assess the effects of these treatments on their infants (including preterm birth, low birth weight, small for gestational age birth) and breastfeeding continuation (at 1 week, 2 months, and 6 months after delivery) while accounting for depression severity. This study will inform our understanding of the ways in which pregnant women cope with depression and has the potential to improve decision making for optimal depression management during pregnancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Hyperglycemia in the hospital is common and has been associated with increased hospital complications, length of stay, and mortality. Insulin therapy has been shown in randomized controlled trials to be effective reducing hyperglycemia and hospital complications but is cumbersome and contributes to rising health care costs. We propose a randomized controlled trial to assess whether continuation of home oral antidiabetic agents during hospitalization can be used as a safe and effective alternative to insulin therapy in the management of diabetes in the hospital.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As the face of the overdose crisis changes, focused attention on marginalized populations and the social conditions affecting overdose is critically important to forestall deaths and reduce widening inequities. The proposed study uses a stepped wedge cluster randomized controlled trial and qualitative interviews to examine the implementation of evidence based practices to prevent overdose in permanent supportive housing— housing that serves formerly homeless individuals who face disproportionately high risk for overdose—in New York City and New York’s Capital Region. Findings will lay the groundwork for widespread implementation of overdose prevention practices in permanent supportive housing, as well as inform similar implementation efforts for other housing settings that serve at-risk populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The medial ganglionic eminence (MGE) is a progenitor domain in the ventral telencephalon that generates both locally-projecting interneurons and long-distance projecting projection neurons; how this delineation occurs is currently unknown. We have identified a transcription factor, St18 that strongly biases MGE progenitors to pro- jection neuron identity. We will examine how St18 does so in gain- and loss-of-function studies as well as at the molecular level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE Eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE), a recently recognized disease with rapidly increasing incidence, prevalence, and recognition, is characterized by the abnormal presence of eosinophils in the esophageal lining, leading to difficulty swallowing, progressive esophageal stenosis, and food impaction. The goals of this pilot/feasibility project are to estimate the effect of allergen-specific immune signature-directed dietary elimination compared to sham elimination on esophageal eosinophil counts and symptoms of dysphagia in patients with EoE, and assess serum eosinophil peroxidase as a non-invasive biomarker to estimate effect sizes for monitoring dietary elimination treatment response in patients with EoE. The proposed research will set the stage for a definitive clinical that will impact the treatment and monitoring of EoE by individualizing dietary elimination and streamlining monitoring of dietary elimination using non-invasive biomarkers, so patients can avoid the time, effort, and risk of repeated endoscopies to identify dietary triggers.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Research on human milk composition and the lactational influences on offspring health after gestational exposures are lacking. The proposed research will study how human milk nutrient profiles susceptible to maternal metabolism and diet during pregnancy and lactation impact offspring growth. Understanding the functional implications of human milk composition on children at risk of adverse metabolic health is relevant to public health and the NIH/NICHD priority for human milk research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the existence of antiretroviral therapies (ARTs) that can keep the virus at bay for extended periods of time, there exist an actively growing population of HIV-1 infected patients as well as issues of compliance and resistance complicating current treatment. Therefore, there exists an active need to study HIV biology to identify therapeutic targets in areas currently less understood, which is why the focus of this study is RNA-related processes, specifically focused on genome dimerization. Successful completion of this proposal will give us a greater understanding of the mechanism of HIV-1 genome dimerization, a critical step to viral replication and genome packaging, while also clarify the role HIV-1 sequence variation has on this process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Complete resection of lung tumors results in decreased tumor recurrence rates and extended patient survival. Surgical guidance with activatable near-infrared fluorophores can enhance detection of millimeter-sized lesions leading to more accurate margin excision and optimal tumor removal. In this application we employ fluorophores targeted to cPLA2α, an enzyme upregulated in lung adenocarcinomas, for their ability to intraoperatively detect small foci of residual tumor and aid in complete tumor excision in canine patients with operable spontaneous lung carcinomas.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA SALT LAKE CITY HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Project Narrative: Percutaneous osseointegrated (OI) devices are becoming a viable alternative to socket suspension of artificial limbs. Although patient satisfaction with this device is high, the weaker link is the vulnerable epidermis-to-implant interface, where interfacial epidermis grows down uncontrollably and produces a sinus tract. Literature indicates that percutaneous healing may be directly related to the biocompatibility of the device material, and importantly, the epidermal adhesion and proliferative patterns. The lack of epidermal integration with the device keeps the interfacial epidermal cells in a migrative phenotype. It is believed that the key for preventing epidermally mediated downgrowth is to use surfaces that promote epidermal cells to form adhesion with them. Our in vitro and non-weight bearing animal studies data indicated that sintered fluorapatite (FA) surfaces could induce such adhesion and differentiation of keratinocytes. Thus, this study proposes to test this unique FA-coated surface in a weight-bearing animal model before the clinical introduction.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pediatric in-hospital cardiac arrest most commonly occurs in pediatric intensive care units and carries extensive morbidity and mortality making prevention the best approach. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Multiple sclerosis is marked by inflammatory brain lesions. Most of these lesions start to heal with time, but a small portion remain chronically active and likely contribute to the brain shrinking at a rate about 2-4 times faster than normal. This project aims to look at how to better identify these lesions, as well as potential treatment approaches to halt the chronic inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a critical need for more physician scientists engaged in ophthalmology and vision research, and particularly those from traditionally underrepresented backgrounds. This research training program is intended to increase the number and diversity of medical students who have interest and experience in research relevant to ophthalmology and vision science. Through a combination of direct firsthand mentored research training, didactic activities, career development, and networking activities, this program will expand and diversify the ophthalmology research workforce to better meet the needs of an increasingly diverse population of patients suffering from ophthalmic conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative This research will elucidate basic molecular mechanisms that regulate neurotransmitter receptor function, synaptic transmission, plasticity and learning and memory in the brain but it also has broad relevance for many brain disorders. Dysfunction of neurotransmitter receptor function, synaptic transmission and synaptic plasticity underlies many neurological and psychiatric diseases. This research may therefore reveal novel targets for the development of therapeutic treatments for several disorders including pain, drug addiction, schizophrenia, autism, intellectual disability and Alzheimer's and Parkinson's disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Recent studies on mice show that the effects of extreme stress in males can be transmitted across multiple generations through environment-induced changes in sperm micro RNAs (miRs) across multiple generations that influence embryo development upon fertilization. Here, we will attempt to add support for this concept in humans by expanding our recent published work that implicated sperm miRs-34c/449a in this process in both mice and men. We will 1) test which types of trauma affect these sperm miRNAs in men, 2) test the possibility that reduced levels of these sperm miRNAs might be a markers for early life or adult exposures to trauma and/or their effects in men and 3) search for evidence that fathers exposed to trauma transmit both reduced levels of these sperm miRNAs to their sons, as well as elevated symptoms of anxiety/depression and/or PTSD to their sons and/or daughters.

PHR: Project Narrative Psychotic Spectrum Disorders (PSD) are severe mental syndromes associated with significant lifelong impairment and high prevalence. In this proposal we aim to employ non-invasive imaging technologies to test that deficiency in brain iron, an essential element for brain functioning, is a feature of PSD. The results of this study may provide new targets for treatments aimed at alleviating psychotic symptoms and cognitive dysfunction in PSD patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to use a two-stepped study to examine both the adoption of the three dietary patterns as presented by the United States Dietary Guidelines (USDG) and testing of a refined, culturally-tailored one- year intervention examining the three diet patterns. For this study, African American adult participants with overweight/obesity and ≥three type 2 diabetes (T2DM) risk factors will be recruited to participate in this two- step study. Step 1: formative pilot work to culturally-tailor a dietary intervention of the three healthy eating patterns presented by the USDG for 12 weeks: 1) U.S.-Style, 2) Mediterranean, or 3) Vegetarian and Step 2: Using the findings from Step 1, conduct a one-year intervention using revised culturally tailored materials to examine differences in diet quality and T2DM risk factors among participants randomized to one of the 3 dietary patterns.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Lyme disease is a significant public health problem in the U.S. One potential approach to the control of Lyme disease is to reduce carriage of the organisms in their wild-life reservoirs. In this proposal, we outline a strategy to develop a new antibiotic that does not cause the development of resistance to antibiotics used for human treatment, to be administered to mice and ticks that serve as the reservoir for the bacteria that causes Lyme disease. By decreasing carriage of the organism in the wildlife reservoirs and vectors, we hope to reduce the incidence of human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE  Terpene compounds from Cannabis sativa have been suggested as non-opioid, non-cannabinoid therapies for pain; however, the literature on their use in pain is limited. In this proposal we will thus rigorously evaluate the therapeutic potential of select terpenes in producing pain relief in neuropathic pain with limited side effects and also determine the molecular mechanism(s) of terpene pain relief. Together these studies will provide a firm translational and basic science basis to move terpene compounds forward to clinical testing for neuropathic pain management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Most heritable differences among humans, including in disease risks, arise from small genetic differences at numerous genes. Yet we still do not understand how a gene’s contribution to heritable variation in complex traits relates to its importance to the biology of those traits, or how the genetic makeup of the population changes in response to changing selection pressures on complex traits. We will develop mathematical models and conduct data analyses to elucidate these central questions in human and evolutionary genetics.

PROJECT_TITLE: The population genetics of disease risk and other quantitative traits

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Developmental and epileptic encephalopathies (DEE) are a devastating group of neuropsychiatric disorders where seizures (that begin early in life) and an underlying genetic mutation or brain lesion result in developmental delay, intellectual disability and a complex spectrum of neurobehavioral disturbances. In this proposal, we apply a mouse model of DEE to clarify the molecular and circuit-level mediators underlying such behavioral syndromes using a novel homecage approach to measuring mouse behavior.
