IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This project can promote our fundamental understanding of two important biological processes: 1) the regulation of host autophagy, which plays a crucial role in the degradation of protein aggregates, dysfunctional organelles, and bacteria; and 2) the pathogenesis mechanisms utilized by intracellular bacteria such as Legionella pneumophila. Given the implication of autophagy in neurodegenerative and immune-related diseases and the strategies used by various intracellular bacteria to cause infection, increasing our knowledge in these topics can lead to the development of novel treatments for a wide range of diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Brain aging poses a significant challenge to the modern society. Infusion of aged blood into young animals decreases neurogenesis and impairs cognition, which suggests the existence of age-elevated systemic factors detrimental to brain health. We propose to identify systematic pro-aging factors in the blood, to investigate the mechanism underlying their damaging effects on neuronal synapses, and to search for means to restore the expression pattern of such factors to the healthy young state in order to rescue synaptic defects and improve cognitive functions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Non-healing diabetic wounds are the most common cause of amputation in the United States with a 5- year mortality of nearly 50% and annual cost to the healthcare system of $19 billion. Our preliminary data demonstrate that epigenetic changes in diabetic keratinocytes, driven by JAK/STAT/SETDB2, regulate the activity of inflammatory cytokine production (i.e., TNFα). Increased production of TNFα by diabetic keratinocytes then functions to impair keratinocyte migration and further promotes inflammation by promoting a pro- inflammatory macrophage phenotype. The success of the human and animal studies outlined in this proposal may lead to improved understanding of the pathophysiology of non-healing diabetic wounds and test novel therapeutic targets and allow me to develop as a translational scientist.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will inform on the potential for using the immune checkpoint molecule, B7-H3, as a novel therapy for medulloblastoma, the most common malignant pediatric brain tumor. This will be accomplished by comprehensively evaluating its efficacy as a direct anti-tumor agent and as a modulator of the tumor immune microenvironment. This project will assess the ability of B7-H3 to penetrate the blood brain barrier and extend the survival of tumor-bearing mice while monitoring for any central nervous system toxicity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Plant meroterpenoids are a large and diverse class of molecules producing by flowering plants, fungi, and liverworts. While the cannabinoids, from Cannabis sativa, have held the focus of the scientific community for the decades since they were discovered, alternative scaffolds from other producers studied to-date have unique pharmacology, suggesting they are interesting targets for therapeutic development. In this proposal, I describe my plan to repurpose biosynthetic pathway enzymes to chemoenzymatically produce new designer plant-like meroterpenoids, discover new enzyme cyclases capable of generating scaffolds with unique stereoselectivity and large steric modifications, and evaluate the potential of these new molecules as therapeutics through GPCR pharmacology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Brain glucose sensing plays a critical role in maintaining the blood glucose balance, but the underlying mechanisms remain to be fully understood. Here we will delineate the mechanisms by which a novel neural population in the brain can rapidly sense a glucose fall (hypoglycemia) and then prevent severe hypoglycemia. This study may provide a framework for the development of novel strategies to treat or prevent severe hypoglycemia.
